From: kawakami@noc.usfca.edu (Sea of Sin)
Message-Id: <9303032207.AA11390@noc.usfca.edu>
Subject: Come/Unity
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Date: Wed, 3 Mar 1993 14:07:51 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL8]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 3773      

I just got back from the after party (which is still going on). So I'll
give you my reviews of Come/Unity before I end up passing out from lack of
sleep. On Tuesdays, my classes are the worst. I was dead tired to begin
with and I don't understand where I ended up getting all my energy for
Come Unity.  I did take a two hour nap before I went though. I was
surprised how many people were on vrave when I logged off around 10ish and
logged back on around 2. Anyway, I picked up Chris (ccat) and we went to
Come Unity. It was packed. The vibes were definately there, unless it was
Chris's vibes felt because he was showering it everywhere. The first thing
I did was to check out the vrave location. I thought I might run into a
lot of the SFRavers there. (Actually my alterior motif was to get in vrave,
my true addiction).  I saw Stevie on the computer talking to Susie.
Unfortuately she was the only one on. Eventually I saw Mykl G, Derek, Joe
(Doom), Leah, Brian, etc. soon after. It was great to see some familiar faces
and actually  meet some of the people that are on the net. By the way it was
great meeting you all... Garth was spinning from 3-7. He was great! The only
thing I have to comment about Garth was that he would through in some
ambient type music towards the end and I was confused whether or not he
was going to end his set. Well anyway, it ended a little after seven.
Several of us: Doom, Mykl G, ccat, Derek Chung, Geoff White, and me went
out to breakfast. Geoff White gave two guys a lift from the rave. They
came in with Geoff. I remember one of the two guys came with from the rave. He
was yelling some weird things when people were leaving. He introduced
himself as Mad Dog and said it was he's 20th birthday. All I can say is
that Mad Dog and his friend was weird. Apparently when they tried to pay
their check (we sat in different tables from them) they couldn't pay their
check. Plus they really made a mess of their table. After giving them a
dollar and some change, we left. I had to go to class at 10, so I couldn't
go to the after party with Geoff, Mykl, and Joe. But I said I'd stop by
after my class. Around 11:30 or so, I ended up at the after party place in
Golden Gate Park. There was no music and people were just sitting around
talking or eating some junk food. I saw Geoff, Mykl, and Joe and they said
that the generator didn't work, so someone had to go get another one. Then
they finally got the old generator to work, but it ran out of gas. Both
the people who went to go get gas and a new generator came back at the sam
time and the party started up again. I really liked the guy who was
spinning, his name was Gavin. And the second guy dante wasn't that bad. 
What the weird thing was that we saw Mad Dog and Brian again. Mad Dog had
more flowers in his hand and he his legs and feet were very muddy, like he
purposely wen through the muddy areas of the grass.  Well after a while of
listening to music and sitting in the sun, I decided to go home...I have
to write a paper as well as clean my room. Overall, it was a great night. 
I don't know how I'm going to survive tonight, but I'll manage.:):):)

(=)
Cindy 
aka sin on vrave :)

 
seaofsinseaofsinseaofsinseaofsinseaofsinseaofsinseaofsinseaofsinseaofsin

shut, with dull ears, with dormant thoughts. Perhaps it's
just as well; and it may be that it is this very dullness that
makes life to the incalculable majority so supportable
and so welcome." -Joseph Conrad
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

from Tower Record's advertisement/magazine Pulse:

RAVE ON: The premiere this summer of the movie "E - Dancing to a
Different Beat" will mark the most conspicious act thus far in the 
continuing commercialization of rave culture.  The film also marks the
directorial debut of Shabba Doo (aka Adolfo Quinones), who, having starred
in "Breakin 2 - Electric Boogaloo" and "Lambada - Set the Night on fire",
has a lot of experience milking waning pop-culture dance crazes.

This is to announce the release of the debut e.p. of ISLAND UNIVERSE, a San
Francisco rave group. The e.p. features ambient and techno house tracks as
well as a cyberdelic introductory interview. The Record release party will be
on Friday, March 12 at 2:00 A.M. (which is actually Saturday morning). The
party will be at 1015 Folsom St. in the basement and will feature DJ Special
K from Release. New music will be featured from ISLAND UNIVERSE, NOVA BASS,
and TASTI BOX. Cover is $5. Call or FAX 415/777-9005 for info or to leave
your address to be added to the mailing list.

THANKS, 
from: The G of ISLAND UNIVERSE
P.S. Could you please call me or E-mail me the number of your direct modem
line for you BBS.

From sfraves-request@medisg.Stanford.EDU  Wed Mar  3 17:46:25 1993

	id AA09715; Wed, 3 Mar 93 17:36:57 -0800
Message-Id: <9303040136.AA09715@soda.berkeley.edu>
From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf (Vitamin B))
Date: Wed, 3 Mar 1993 17:36:56 -0800
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: Too many people!


        Last night's Come Unity was probably the best production I've ever
seen at 1015 Folsom ever.  Visuals everywhere were top notch, the sound 
system was great (they did a rather intelligent thing - put all the bass bins
low to the ground and the tweeters high, so they could crank it and the 
danger of blasting people's ears is diminished), and I saw tons and tons of
familiar faces - both sfraves and non-sfravers, and even people I've never
met but seen dozens of times at my favorite raves.  When the sun rose and
the grey light came into the dance floor, there was a great vibe going on,
the best of the entire night.  When the music finally stopped around 7am, 
there was still a packed dancefloor.  Amazing for a Tuesday night.  

        The only down points: I spent most of the time in the chill-out 
bassment working on vrave; the overhead projector setup failed to work
well enough to make it worth the trouble, but the screen was big enough
for three or 4 people to sit around and interact.  There were up to 21
people online at one point in the night; unfortunately most people were
on the dance floor, to other come/unity-ites didn't get a chance to sample
it until only 5 or 6 remained.  I was also pretty tired during the whole
night, so for most of the time my luv phasers were in the holster packed
away... the few times I ventured out to the dance floor it was PACKED, which
made it hard to dance in place and get a groove without having people bump
into me.  They opened the second floor, which was really a good thing; if
they hadn't there would have been a SERIOUS crowd-control problem.  There
were more people there than I had ever seen at something at 1015.  And true
to form, the vibe shot up an order of magnitude when the bars closed at 2
and the bustier-and-suit crowd moved on...

        So to sum up, it was a great event (oh yeah, the visuals and music
in the bassment were terrific!  thanks to synergy visuals and spacetime..)
but not the best overall C/U I've been to.  I really am in NO position to
say how each DJ did since I heard maybe only half an hour's worth of each
DJ.  But definitely worth the effort.... hope the afterparty happened without
incident...

        Brian

p.s. - there's a rumor going around that Markie Mark has joined our tribe...
tres cool...

fantastic evening...destroyed my wednesday, which was spent sleeping
until rehearsal, but what a night!

Good to see all of you again, and very nice to be introduced to so many
nice new fresh faces...especailly good to see Mykl, Bri, Stevie, Leah,
Janella (haven't seen you for a loong time!) and all and all...

good time. Ernie was great, but Simon tore it UP...Garth was great in
the beginning of his set, but I am getting tired of Jeno's 
we are family closing...but his set was pretty damn cool, as usual.  
It was my first come/unity, and I am happy that I was able to make...
it...definitely worth the horrible caltrains ride back to school this morning.
Next time we should all go to breakfast or something...my 7:15 in the
morning Patty melt and salad is just going nutso right now in me stomach..

Well, anyway, the vibe was great, the sound was good, it was a great
cool evening.  It was really my first really good rave this year..I meanm
I like the Wickeds okay, but there is something about having out 18-20
year old friends with us..the energy is better or something...not 
as many attitudes last night...of course it was tuesday night...there was
something glorious about having the place PACKED at 4:30 on a wednesday
morning........long live all of us!!

The rave scene isn't dead at all...it's just waiting until we 
make ourselves rediscover it again...

take care!  good night!!

mike..
I)  <sleeeeepy)

From: Jim Milles <MILLESJG@SLUVCA.SLU.EDU>

                        CALL FOR ARTICLES
          ARACHNET ELECTRONIC JOURNAL OF VIRTUAL CULTURE

              SPECIAL ISSUE: VIRTUAL CULTURE AND LAW

       Issue Editor: James Milles  
(millesjg@sluvca.slu.edu)


The Arachnet Electronic Journal of Virtual Culture (EJVC)
announces a call for papers for a special issue on Virtual
Culture and Law, to be published in June 1993.

Virtual culture is computer-mediated human experience,  
behavior,
thought, meaning, action, or interaction, such as  
electronic
mail, conferences, and journals; information distribution  
and
retrieval; the construction and visualization of images,
representations, or models of reality or worlds; and  
global
connectivity.  The Arachnet Electronic Journal on Virtual  
Culture
is a refereed journal whose purpose is to foster,  
encourage,
advance, and communicate scholarly thought, (including  
analysis,
evaluation, and research) in multiple disciplines about  
virtual
culture.

Papers for the special issue may address any aspect of the
intersection of virtual culture and law, from the  
practical (such
as copyright and liability issues) to the theoretical (the  
law
and virtual communities; computer-mediated communication  
and the
future of law.)

EJVC seeks authors who do not have established publication
records, as well as established authors with reputations  
as
scholars and experts.  All manuscripts will be given at  
least
three blind reviews by a jury of referees.  EJVC uses  
multiple
styles, flexible among articles but consistent within any  
given
article.  Any recognized standard of style shall be  
acceptable;
however, for the Special Issue, either _The Bluebook: A  
Uniform
System of Citation_ (15th ed.), or APA style, modified for  
ASCII,
shall be the preferred style, allowing for creative  
styling if
essential to the integrity of the article.

Each contribution shall conform to the following minimal  
form:

    Articles shall start with an abstract/description
      (< 200 lines)
    Number paragraphs and pages
    Provide internal/in-text citation
    Provide electronic references where appropriate
    Superscripts in text/endnotes ^2^
    Use blank line separators between paragraphs, which
      shall have no indentations
    Provide only substantive endnotes

All submissions must be by electronic mail to James  
Milles, Saint
Louis University, Special Issue Editor  
(millesjg@sluvca.slu.edu).
The deadline for the June 1993 special issue is May 1,  
1993.

----------------------------------------------------------- 
------

Hey there!

Sorry to bother those of you who don't snowboard, but since I know many
of you do, thought this would be worth posting.  I am selling my old
snowboard.  It's a Burton Free 5 (150 cm) with Flex bindings, and it's in
excellent condition.  No nicks on the bottom, edges are great; I've
probably only ridden it around 15 days total.  This is a great all around
board!  They don't make the Free 5 anymore, the equivalent is now the
Air 5, which sells for about $450.  But I am willing to unload mine
for the amazing bargain price of $200, or (most likely) b.o.  So if you're
interested e-mail me at laurak@leland.stanford.edu.  Wish I could join
you on the sfraves snowboard trip and meet some of you in real life, but
unfortunately I'll be on my way to Sun Valley for 8 days of fun in the
snow.  Yeah, I know, life's rough.  Again, apologies to those of you who
could care less about snowboarding.  Hope to hear from someone . . .

peace and powder,
laura

MykL's instant analysis of Come/Unity and the afterparty:

Come/Unity:  solid, excellent music and vibe but definitely not
extraordinary.  Claustrophobia factor quite high on the main floor, despite
the entire
upstairs and basement being open.  The basement "ambient" space was
the star of the show this time, with Jonah (SpaceTime) mixing with great
inspiration, the Synergy video folks (from AfterLife, TAZ, the last Come/Unity)
and best of all live VRAVE connectivity spanning the planet!!!

Marx Meadows:  as close to perfection as you could imagine (after a couple
of generator related delays).  A sonic picnic for a family of 120.  INCREDIBLE
weather, great spinning from Gavin and DJ Dick.  No appearances by authority
figures of any stripe.  A sure sign that spring in San Francisco has arrived,
and a hopeful glimpse into the next six months of future...

<< Image:  watching two dancers cavort barefoot in the slimy mud invoked
memories of an earlier, headier and much larger festival... >>

----____----____--__--__--__--__-_-_-_-_-_-__--__--__--__--____----____----
         MykL G             Look to the future!      mcg@netcom.com
____----____----__--__--__--__--_-_-_-_-_-_--__--__--__--__----____----____

Received: by netcom2.netcom.com (5.65/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id AA22445; Thu, 4 Mar 93 10:14:35 -0800
Date: Thu, 4 Mar 93 10:14:35 -0800
From: taxi@netcom.com (TAXI)
Message-Id: <9303041814.AA22445@netcom2.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: ComeUnity


Wow, this was the best comeunity I've been to.  I got there at around 1am and
didn't detect any 'tudes.  The vibe was raging.  I love raves where people 
cheer at the start of a new song.  I danced most of the night away
and suddenly it was closing at around 7ish or so.  What happened to all that
time?  Well I was sooo tired and so was every cell in my legs so I went home
and turned the alarm clock for 40min later.  Well 4 hours later, I woke up
as I was swearing to myself for missing that alarm.  A buddy and me rushed over
to the park where there was a good mellow gathering going on.  A few people
brought some young kids who they nanny for, like 2 year olds or so.  There were
3 of them and they were dancing in their little circle - those kids know how to
dance to a good beat!  Once again there were the regular rave dogs that I used
to see at many outdoor raves, if I got their identity right:  there were the 
two dogs that like to chase eachother at high speeds through the dance area and
there was this cute little dog that was the same dog I had to deal with at a 
former outdoor rave when it kept grabbing and running off with our paddleball
ball.  I met many new people with a really pure outlook.  It was a great night/
day.  Wow....

TAXI
fractal surfer

James and Gavan (from Tweekin Records) will be spinning together with someone
else but I'm not sure who. For those who were not out last year these parties

outside and there are many different sections to sit and chill, a real nice
venue.

Richard

Speaking of doomsayers predicting the end, I think we should form a
fringe cult called the "Branch Ravidians" to take over marx meadow at
Golden Gate park and play loud music and dance (and hold each-other
hostage) continuously until they let us broadcast inane blatherings on
KGO during  commute hours for one week... We should be heavily armed
with Love-Phasers to protect us from mounted police, (and sugar cubes
to make their horses more friendly).

talk broadcast in Texas as ransom for release of his hostages? The bits
I did hear of it (broadcast on KPFA) were uh... hilarious... and
obviously made for sampling/cutting-up/putting-into an industrial bob
dobbs meets techno-industrial music-form.

Come/Unity only began happening for me around 5AM (even tho i got there
at 1AM) and rose steadily till closing at 7. Park was the whipped cream
on the pie-in-the sky....

	id ab00732; Thu, 4 Mar 93 12:08:26 PST
To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU
Subject: comeunity
From: Desi the Three-Armed Wonder Comic <jondr@sco.com>
Sender: jondr@sco.com
Date: Thu, 4 Mar 93 11:30:02 PST
Message-Id:  <9303041130.aa23373@scotty.sco.COM>

we wandered up to comeunity a little past 2 AM.  we drove by and saw
hordes of people in the street and figured it was going to be a pain
getting in.  we resolved that if we didn't find a good parking space
within five minutes that we'd take off.  my housemate jeff is a good
luck charm for parking though - we found a primo space instantly.

so, we were standing outside, looking at the line, debating whether we
really wanted to deal with it when we heard jeno drop the jon williams
remix of The Trip.  that sort of clinched it, although i don't know
why.  i just have that reaction to hearing my own records played, i
guess.  fortunately, we found a friend who let us cut in line.  even
with that, we didn't get past the hand-stamper until the record was
over so i didn't get to see how the crowd reacted to it.  :(

inside, it was a nightmare - wall to wall flesh, jeno doing a
startlingly lackluster set on a deafening sound system (and me without
my earplugs), and many kids with good fake IDs drinking way too much.

we stayed for about 30 minutes and that's only because we found a
friend that we talked to for 15.

i did manage to run into a few people i knew, even in that brief time.
a crazy ill shout out to leah, derek and brian!

Jon Drukman (edited for television)                             jondr@sco.com
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Always note the sequencer - this will never let us down.

Subject: Come/Unity and on
Date: Thu, 04 Mar 93 16:17:57 -0800
From: doom@leland.stanford.edu


Well, these things are ultimately subjective... but I think
it you didn't like Jeno's set last night maybe you need to
get out and do something else for awhile... Garth was cool
by me too, though I don't understand why he kept killing the
beat and letting the ambient/intro run.  I think people kept
cheering because they thought it meant his set was over.
Oh, and I thought Plastech's set was good too, though that
may not have been part of your subjective rave that evening.

I didn't think the crowd was that excessive, mostly because
I just went where they weren't, e.g. up on the over looking
balconies, up on the stage, down in the chill space.  

Music was good down in the "chill" area, but clearly much
too loud ("So vrave is up again", "WHAT?", "I SAID VRAVE
IS..."). 

Vrave was an appreciated addition... Pat Dote logged in
after his show was over, making a surprise reprise into my
existance after I thought that part of the subjective rave
was over with.  

There's something about looking out over the crowd and
suddenly realizing that you can actually see everyone, that
the sun is about to rise...  

Hanging out at the GG park after party was excellent, though
I was most annoyed to find that my car had been towed away
while I was there.  What, me park in front of a drive way?

From: arthurc@sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu (Arthur Chandler)
Message-Id: <9303050052.AA29497@sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu>
Subject: Breakin' versus Ravin'
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Date: Thu, 4 Mar 93 16:52:57 PST
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]

  A flame war over the virtues (or lack of) of Turbo and Shabba Do in sfraves
has great comic potential; but I decline the gauntlet....
  However...
  Break Dancing had a distinctive set of moves all its own, and had juice enough to pull in other steps from other styles.  Some of the dancing (and dance-
 fighting) scenes from the two films have a lot of style and energy.
  Is there a rave dancing style as identifiable as break dancing?  *Breakin'*
1 and 2 did capture a lot of the mood and moves of the break dancing movement.
If raves have a dance style -- and I'm not sure they do -- but if they do, then
why not let an ace dancer have a shot at putting it on film?

From sfraves-request@medisg.Stanford.EDU  Thu Mar  4 18:07:22 1993
Received: from medisg.Stanford.EDU by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA09421; Thu, 4 Mar 93 18:07:22 -0800
Received: by medisg.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA09895; Thu, 4 Mar 93 16:16:42 PST

	id AA09890; Thu, 4 Mar 93 16:16:40 PST
Received: by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA23121; Thu, 4 Mar 93 16:13:04 -0800
Message-Id: <9303050013.AA23121@soda.berkeley.edu>
From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf (Vitamin B))
Date: Thu, 4 Mar 1993 16:13:04 -0800
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu, sfraves-calendar@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: This week's RAVE guide

Before showing the calendar, let me just say...

		HAPPY 1-YEAR BIRTHDAY SFRAVES!

For those who have been on since the start you have participated in the
creation of a real virtual community, a living organism (borg?) with a
unique psychology.  This past year has been the most intensely wonderful
year of my life and I owe it all to this.  The list has not been without
its low points, but it makes the highs so much more enjoyable.  I thank
all of you who continue to pour positive energy into the list and who
don't unsubscribe at the first sign of negativity but instead set their
luv phasers on stun and turn the situation around (damn, the "luv phaser"
metaphor should be copyrighted!).  The SFRaves community continues to grow,
and my hopes are that we can continue to have a positive role in helping 
to shape the scene in San Francisco.  At the moment 493 people are in one
way or another hooked into sfraves, with about 259 people on the full-time
mailing list.  Let's see if we can make the virtual energies we feel here
translate into real energies at the parties and in our everyday lives.

Anyways, that was my sentimental view of it all :)


Okay, on to the list:

	Friday looks to be a choice between the funkengruvenness of 
Wicked at 1015, which is usually great but likely to be crowded and
hot, or Future Forum.  I'd go for Future Forum - Mark has been talking
to the head of the permit department for SF and has been cleared to
have parties of around 300 people, so it _won't_ get busted this time.
The DJ lineup is uncertain at this point, but it sounds as if Thomas
and Spun will be there.  Also there will be the Planet 6 crew and 
Spacetime doing their cybernetic jam session.  Also at 1015 that night 
is Martini's - it's more along the lines of a club atmosphere than party, 
but SFRaver Eric Lacy is spinning there from 11pm - 1am, and he's really 
worth checking out. You could also hit Smiling Thru - it starts at 4 am 
and goeson well into morning.  I went last weekend and it's a lot of fun, 
it just needs more people there to make it truely great.  :)

	Saturday night you have a choice between Cool World and I Magi
Nation - I would recommend I Magi Nation highly.  It's gonna be at the
same place in the north-east bay area where the last Basics was held
(I _think_ it's the Vallejo civic auditorium but I'm not sure).  It'll
be 18+, which is a good thing in these days of the retreat-to-the-clubs
mentality of some promoters :(  Vrave will be there too, this time 
providing a direct link with a "sister rave" happening in Vancouver that
night too.  Richard Sun has an impeccible reputation - the last I Magi
Nation back in September went really really well.

	Have fun!  Oh, and after last night's Inspiral Carpets show, I
am gonna start wearing earplugs to every music-related event I go to.
I haven't gotten my full hearing back yet, and I wouldn't be able to LIVE
without my sense of sound!!!

	Brian


****************************************************************************
UPCOMING RAVES IN THE SF/BAY AREA                     Last modified: 3/4/93
****************************************************************************

Friday, March 5th - Future Forum First Friday - Dj's TBA (mostly new
	guys but guaranteed to be good) - jamming live will be planet
	6 and Spacetime - at the Charter Oak warehouse (legal this time!)
	south sf - head east from the intersection of bayshore and 
	industrial, make a right at charter oak and go to the end of the
	street.  the warehouse it on the left.  for more info call 
	Mark at Ameba, 415-750-9368

Friday, March 5th - Wicked late-nighter - 1015 Folsom 21+, 2am - dawn.
	DJ's Garth, Jeno, Simon

Fridays (starting this one) - Mission Rock - DJ's James and Gavan (from 
	Tweekin Records) & others.  Outside dance floor. 
	In China basin at 17th and Illinois.

Friday night/saturday morning - Smiling Thru - Scott & Robbie Hardkiss, 
	Jon Williams, Charle E, Dutch, bam Bam, Spunky, and Hawke (phew!)
	278 11th street @ Folsom, 21+, 4am - whenever.  415-979-LUV-0

Friday, March 5th - Pure Soul - DJ's Garth  Josh  Adonis  Buck  Chris Lum
	415-267-7628

Saturday, March 6th - Ambient Temple of Imagination - "Love is the law"
	Josh, Markie Mark, and Harry Who.  Live acid jazz, poetry 
	readings, performace art by Iaocore and others.  VRAVE will be
	appearing there too. 415-337-4905 - A Richard Sun production.
	ALL AGES

Saturday, March 6th - Cool World - Dance to save our planet.
	DJ's Barry Weaver, DJ Dan, Carlos, Tony, Demigod, DJ Max, Dave Alga
	Tribal Trance Temple by A*T*O*I - Donations will be made to the
	International Indian Treaty Council and the Inner Tribal Friendship
	House of Oakland. "1'st thousand people donating usable clothing or
	canned goods will recieve a discount at the door"
	415-979-4543 - 510-273-9844 - 916-449-3111 - 408-235-1077

Saturday, March 6th - Get Down Get Down Get Down

Here are some weeklies - whether or not they count as real "raves" is 
debatable, but they were advertised by fliers and the music could be
good. If anyone can provide reviews of them, i.e., their 
appropriateness in being on the list, let me know....

Sundays - EndUp from 6am - 6th & Harrison

Sundays - AfterLIFE - six am till...  - 375 11th st * Dj Simon, Spun * 
	Bagels * Fruit Salad * Espresso * Smart Bar * Chill Room

Sunday mornings - AfterLIFE presents PRISM - DJ's Bones, Phil Smart
	and live house music with DUBTRIBE - Full Breakfast Cafe
	Live Ambient Music and Interactive Visuals by Synergy

Sunday nights - boat parties thrown by Eddie of Bulletproof - $20
	(no idea where to get info about this - I think Bulletproof is
	a store on haight that throws this)

Sundays - Team Green 
	3rd @ Harrison, 315 Harrison (City Nights), 21+ ID; Brought to 
	you by the people who promoted "Carefree", $8.00 admission.  
	Carefree alternative Style 

Sundays - flow at Nickie's (460 Haight)
        full house w/dj - 10pm-2am, 21+

Sundays - Zanzibar - 1pm-9pm - James, Gavin, and Felix playing a mix of House, 
	Funk and Rare Groove

Sundays - Sunday Skool at Atlantis	5pm - 4am
	1st & Harrison 

Mondays - Pepper.Deep House with Buck, Josh, Chris Lum & Guests. 668
	Haight, 10-2AM, $3, 21+. "Tis a very merry, dancing, drinking, 
	laughing, quaffing, and untinking time" -- John Dryden. (the 
	oldest rave quote i've seen so far....)

Subject: SF Weekly, on KTVU (Ch 2), on raves


KTVU Discovers Raves!  A recent KTVU newscast found reporter
Bob MacKenzie in an ugly sport jacket, taking a camera crew into the
insidious "underground rave scene" to explain the mysterious world
of "sex, drugs, and techno-pop," a topic that was timely, oh, about
two years ago.  MacKenzie got to the bottom of his story by cornering
two poor kids, Kirby and Dave, whose lives were reduced to the
credit, "Rave Attendees."

			-Jack Boulware
			 SF Weekly, 3/3/93

Yes, this is definitly true. J/G have been playing in SF for about two years 
now. They definitely are the X brand of rave DJ's. A ?guarenteed? purchase
of an mind blowing expereince -- but only sometimes.

Agreeing w/ doom I  think it is wise, but can be risky to break out of
the J/G paradigm. Check out other DJ's for a while then come back to them. You
will notice that the music and mixes show no change. Changing will not only
give you a breath to groove to other DJ's, but to also understand the variety of 
music that's out there. I'm mean you can't possibly beleive that J/G play ALL
the BEST music.


Don't just stick with what you know, learn, learn, learn.


Eric

From: lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9303052223.AA10813@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
Subject: KEYBOARD Techno article (sigh)
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Date: Fri, 5 Mar 93 14:26:48 PST
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]


The April issue of Keyboard has an article on "Techno".  It is long, somewhat
informative, extremely opinionated, and very disturbing.  I've typed in some
excerpts here for yopur entertainment.  I may be writing a letter to the
editor to respond to some of the more ludicrous points of the article, but
I'm not sure I would even know where to begin, or whether I should even take
this article seriously, considering how amazingly idiotic it is.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
	Synth-Rock Apocalypse?
	Disco With Smart Drugs?
	The Next Wave?  The Last Rave?

	TECHNO

	Catch The Buzz.  Eat The Beat.
	Tune In, Turn On, Boot Up.
		by Mark Dery

	Techno.  The name sounds at once monolithic and impersonal, the acronym
of multinational conglomerate, and toylike, as in brightly colored plastic Lego
blocks.  It is retrofuturist, heading in opposite directions at the same 
time: forward, to the seductive dystopia of Blade Runner's Los Angeles, 2019,
and backward, to the psychedelic utopia of the "Summer of Love."  At its best,
itextinguishes the individual ego in the all-consuming beat, a sensation 
somewhere between orgasm, Buddhist nirvana, and the momentary blackout of a 
fighter pilot pulling G's at supersonic speed.  At its worst, it pummels the 
brain to mush with its locomotive rhythms and monorail melodies - melodies as 
enjoyable as a car alarm at four A.M., and not nearly so musical.

{history of house music scene up to the crackdown in England deleted.}

	The Triffid spores have since taken root in California.  In Los Angeles
and San Francisco, acid culture cross-pollinated with the traditions 
represented by Haight-Ashbury and Silicon Valley to create what P-Orridge calls
 "hyperdelic" culture.  Others have dubbed this emergent movement "cyberdelia,"
and its members have been called "zippies", defined by Encyclopedia Psychedelic
a as "a combination of a '60s hippie and a '90s technoperson."

[Anyone who has seen "The Day of the Triffids" knows that the analogy is not 
complimentary.  I personally have never heard the term 'zippy' before, except 
with the comic strip Zippy the Pinhead. -L]

{typical lame description of a rave deleted.}

	Though the underground press has already conducted the last rites for 
rave culture, techno may very well be the Next Big Thing.  In fact, premature 
reports of a genre's death in cloisters of cool are often a sure barometer 
that it is about to be found, alive and well, in the maintstream...

...But Tony Fletcher, writing in Spin, sounds a cautionary note. "For all its 
newfound popularity, techno looks destined to stay underground in the U.S.  
Dozens of 12-inch are released worldwide every week, but few of the producers 
and musicians - there is usually no band - use the same name twicel they form 
short partnerships, release a couple of tracks, and move on.  None seem worried
about fame and fortune; the 'image' of the music is transported from the 
music's creator to its consumer, who, when dancing... becomes a star.  It's a 
revolutionary concept, but a record company's nightmare."
[...]
	Techno is the end of natural law in pop music: the end of harmony, of 
melodic development, of album-oriented marketing, of live performance...of the
 star, of message, of meaning.

[The rest of the article takes on a truly horrible twist. This is easily the 
ugliest distortion of raving I have ever come across. Brace yourselves.  -L]

	A rave, to use black leather theorist Hakim Bey's term. is a 
"temporary autonomous zone," a pirate utopia, a centrifuge in which social 
gravity is artificially suspended, like the student rebellion in Paris in 
1968, a group grope, or Mardi Gras in New Orleans.  Or a lynch mob.  Because 
the suspension of mores and norms that permitted Woodstock also created, in 
the flash of a knife, Altamont; the road to utopia can end in Plato's Republic
or Jonestown.  Raves, which address the utopian yearnings of cynics and true 
believers alike, transcend societal strictures by subsuming the individual 
into the amoebic mass, a technique equally useful in the generation of
communitarian "families" and teenage wolf packs, out for a night of wilding.  
Heads a Love-In; tails, a Two Minutes' Hate, one of the orgies of loathing in 
Orwell's 1984.

[He digs up the following quote from a "young raver"] 

	"We're not wearing fucking daisies in our hair and all walking around 
shouting 'karma fucking peace man.'  Fuck that.  We like the violence, we like
getting off our heads, we like the dancing, the sweat."

[This was the only time the article ever referenced input from anyone 
who actually goes to a raves.  Not what I would call a fail representation.
But wait, it gets better. -L]

  	"Getting off our heads": The obliteration of rationality, and endgame 
played by the anarchic and avant-garde...was, ironically the avowed goal of 
National Socialism.  Tha anti-rationalism of Nazism is evident in the book-
burnings, gobbledygook Teutonic primitivism Then, too, the hypnotic effect of 
drumming has proven useful in deranging the senses, switching off the reasoning
mind, since time immemorial.  It is not without significance that Joseph 
Goebbels, the Nazi minister of propaganda, frequently referred to Hitler as a 
drummer.

[Wow, Hitler with a drum machine, can you just imagine the groovy
beats? -L (desperately trying to keep a sense of humor)]

	This linkage of electronic dance music and Nazism is admittedly 
alarmist.  Even so, the techno aesthetic cannot be viewed in a vacuum. It 
lives on contested ground, bordered on one hand by the skinhead rockers in 
Germany who sing...[inane lyrics deleted. -L] and on the other by cyberdelic 
ravers who have negotiated a detente between ecotopian longings for a 
prelapsarian paradise and cyberpunk's unshakable faith in the liberating powers
of street tech.
	Techno, claims Reynolds [author of Blissed Out: The Raptures of Rock],
signals "the death of the Song, to be replaced by the...unresolved, infinite...
track; the brain-rotting vortex of quick-cutting in video and TV; the
supersession of narrative, characterization, and motivation by sensational
effects.  Blip culture means the death of sequential, linear thought, an 
erosion of people's ability to plan and manage their lives.  There is only a
NOW that is either blissed-out or dreadful."
	Sometimes, it is both.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
So there it is, another fine example of media mutilation.
The rest of the article covers LFO, Orbital, T99, The Orb, Third Eye,
and The Shamen.  Zieg Heil!, er, I mean, Rave On! 

- leg of eel

Subject: Marin's Pacific Sun Recognizes Raves
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu

  And now, to Marin county, where the Pacific Sun announces on the cover:
  RAVES: THE 90S VERSION OF SEX, DRUGS, & ROCK 'N' ROLL"
  The article itself isn't all that bad, if you overlook the slightly
condescending tone and "we've certainly got *their* number" attitude.  But
there is a side bar to the article, a quotation from the *Willamette
Week*, that reads: "Fifteen dead in the last two years.  The victims?
Devotees of England's Rave counterculture."  The article concludes: "But
given the right mix, rave rhymes with grave."
  I'm still mulling over that phrase, "Given the right mix."
  :<+++

Subject: Re: KEYBOARD Techno article (sigh)
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu

In-Reply-To: <9303052223.AA10813@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>; from "Lee Fogel" at Mar 5, 93 2:26 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL0]
Content-Length: 2053

> 	Techno, claims Reynolds [author of Blissed Out: The Raptures of Rock],
>signals "the death of the Song, to be replaced by the...unresolved, infinite...
> track; the brain-rotting vortex of quick-cutting in video and TV; the
> supersession of narrative, characterization, and motivation by sensational
> effects.  Blip culture means the death of sequential, linear thought, an 
> erosion of people's ability to plan and manage their lives.  There is only a
> NOW that is either blissed-out or dreadful."
> 	Sometimes, it is both.
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------------

Ok, I imagine that I am not the only one who will be inflamed enough to respond,
but here goes anyway.. Didn't we leave "Techno" in the dust a while ago? I will
assume that house as a whole is being talked about here, I guess...

I wish that these self proclaimed authorities would stop assuming that their
word is gospel, or at least that those publishing stuff like this would
try to get an opposing viewpoint. I believe that house music/mixing takes
the concept of 'song' to a higher level, where tracks stand alone as a
whole, but when mixed become part of an infinitely complex structure - something
that is a good subjective experience (mix tapes?) but an even better
interactive experience. This experience involves not only you, but the
individual controlling the music, and everyone else in the 'house'. Since
when did a fucking rock critic know dance music from a hole in the ground?
Friends, set luv phasers to 'funkify' and fire when ready! If anything, I'd
say being able to get into a groove and stay there all night is a pretty
amazing thing for us 'blip culture' TV zombies, eh? Ok, put away the luv
phasers. I think that it is time for the luv jackhammers.. hee hee...
Hey Reynolds, I said JACK YOUR BODY! chuggachuggachuggachugga.. Now MOVE!

Subject: KEYBOARD Techno article (sigh)
From: Desi the Three-Armed Wonder Comic <jondr@sco.com>
Sender: jondr@sco.com
Date: Fri, 5 Mar 93 15:53:24 PST
Message-Id:  <9303051553.aa14274@scotty.sco.COM>

lee fogel passes on a poopy article on "techno" from keyboard
magazine:

>[He digs up the following quote from a "young raver"] 
>
>"We're not wearing fucking daisies in our hair and all walking around
>shouting 'karma fucking peace man.'  Fuck that.  We like the
>violence, we like getting off our heads, we like the dancing, the
>sweat."
>
>[This was the only time the article ever referenced input from anyone 
>who actually goes to a raves.  Not what I would call a fail representation.
>But wait, it gets better. -L]

i don't agree with Mark Dery at all, but i do believe that many people
in the san francisco rave scene are ignorant of the rest of the
world's attitude toward raving.  maybe it's the exceptionally nice
weather all the time turning us into hippy peace freaks, maybe there's
another reason, but san francisco is decidedly *different*...  the
music played at raves in just about every other city in the world is
hard, fast and relentless.  no happy melodies, no calls for "unity".
fortunately, just as breakbeat was becoming endemic, san francisco
turned away and embraced progressive house, giving us gentle anthems
like "passion" and "nush".  but while we were holding hands and
getting lovey-dovey, everyone else was listening to "death is my
sect/guess my religion" and "bad trip!  overload!" at 150 BPM over and
over again.  when i went back to boston in november, there was a
really popular song that i don't remember the title of (it was german)
and it was filled with all sorts of hate-filled ranting, apparently.

san francisco is the disney channel of raving.  the sexuality of new
york & chicago, the violence of washington & boston are turned into an
adolescent melange of innocent sensuality and vague mutterings of
peace & unity.  it's marshmallow land.  i like it that way - it's
non-threatening and only requires attention, not devotion.

>	This linkage of electronic dance music and Nazism is admittedly 
>alarmist.

Ah good, now we'll get some balance out of Mr Dery (who wrote a really
dumb piece on industrial "cyberpunk" music too.  I don't know why
Keyboard employs this guy.)

>Even so, the techno aesthetic cannot be viewed in a vacuum. It lives
>on contested ground, bordered on one hand by the skinhead rockers in
>Germany who sing...[inane lyrics deleted. -L] and on the other by
>cyberdelic ravers who have negotiated a detente between ecotopian
>longings for a prelapsarian paradise and cyberpunk's unshakable faith
>in the liberating powers of street tech.

he even phrases the positive stuff in terms so obscure as to be mostly
unparsable by the general public.  a "detente" huh?  maybe we've got
the best of both worlds and he can't bring himself to admit it.

shit, i'm annoyed.  think i'll write a letter to the editor as well.

thanks, lee.

Jon Drukman (99% fat free)                                      jondr@sco.com
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
If you want to touch the sky, just put a window in your eye.           - Coil

In-Reply-To: jondr@sco.com -- 03/05/93 17:01

well, i would like to add that we should consider the connection between
tekno and fascism. it's not as  far fetched as it seems. when there
is this 'melting' of social norms lotsa of things can come out. i can
see the 'progression' : punk, industrial, tekno. this steeping in
esthetics of doom and distruction make perfect environment for fascist
esthetics which worship destruction and violence - hence our ugly 'cousins',
the nazi skinheads ( 'descendent' from punks). so we are 'playing' with
dangerous forces here when we release the unconscious ( 'my dinner with
andre' touches on this too.) we gots to be careful!    i see the way to
'guide' the trip along this chaotic surface towards constructive attractors
to consist in adding in the 'love'
component, so lacking in punk, industrial , tekno. i think that's our
vaccine against embracing fascist esthetics. commnents ?
take care/shalom/salaam/rave out
ovid

When I suggested that I thought that if you were unhappy
with Jeno's set, "maybe you should get out and do something
else", I was kind of hinting that you might be getting jaded
with raving, and you should, like go to the movies, go
hiking, stay home and read or something.  It kind of seems
weird to me that a lot of the hard core here don't seem to
do anything besides go to raves.

What's interesting is that Eric interpreted this as a
suggestion that you should check out some new DJs.  Well,
fair enough, I guess that might help if you're getting tired
of Jeno...

Anyway, I guess Jon was saying that the "problem" is with
me, in that I haven't heard Jeno enough to realize he was
being uninspired.  This is probably true from one point of
view... but who do you think is a bigger part of the
audience?  How many people out there do you think can name
any of the tracks Jeno played?  When the place is packed,
the sweat's coming down the walls and the energy is flowing,
why should Jeno even consider doing something different?

Message-Id: <9303061859.AA02452@nexsys.nexsys.net>
To: sfraves@nexsys.net
Subject: a few words about...

Well I just had another wonderful night of raving, Wicked was wild
and great as usual.  I saw alot of the Family, Garth played a brilliant
set and the vibe was INTENSE in the morning around 6-7.  Went to the 
end-up after and began to look around me in the morning light...
I didn't like what I saw.

Now some of you won't like what I'm about to say and some will
call me self- rightous or what ever but I'm going to say it anyway.

	THE ABUSE OF CRYSTAL IS DESTROYING THE SCENE

The use of this drug will bring it down quicker than any government
repression or hollywood commercialism.  It will destroy it from
within.  People get mean, they stop caring about others and themselves.

Speed kills the Vibe.


There, I said It.

I'm ready to take the flames.

Subject: Upper Abuse / Amateur Philosophy
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu

Recently, Geoff posted -

> 
> ...  Went to the end-up after (Wicked) and began to look around me in 
> the morning light...
> I didn't like what I saw.
> 
> Now some of you won't like what I'm about to say and some will
> call me self- rightous or what ever but I'm going to say it anyway.
> 
> 	THE ABUSE OF CRYSTAL IS DESTROYING THE SCENE
> 
> The use of this drug will bring it down quicker than any government
> repression or hollywood commercialism.  It will destroy it from
> within.  People get mean, they stop caring about others and themselves.
> 
> Speed kills the Vibe.
> 
> 
> There, I said It.
> 
> I'm ready to take the flames.
>   
> 

 I'm not posting to flame - just to add my vague recollection from hippie
history - didn't speed have it's negative effects on the Haight-Asbury 
scene? People were using uppers to give them more energy to do what they
needed to get done, but the speed became an end in itself. Then, to escape
the bad hangover from speed abuse, people began doing heroin. Can any of
the older SFRavers confirm/deny/add to this?

 I've never been a fan of uppers, except coffee and chocolate. I never had
a bad experience with stronger stuff - in fact , I thought I felt too
powerful ( a la Superman ). Therefore, I didn't trust it. 

 Personal theory: Participants in any scene that "requires" the use of an 
external tool ( like drugs or music or computers ) , must eventually work
out a way to be a part of the scene without dependence on the external
tools. There must be an internal change, leading to greater personal
freedom.

 ( I wish I was as wise as a god - then I'd be able to solve everybody's
   problems )

 ( Of course, maybe the cosmic joke is that everybody's problems can be
   solved if they were no longer human ... )

			Larry "Really Serious Now  :-(" Ching
			larryc@netcom.com

(stuff deleted]

> > 	THE ABUSE OF CRYSTAL IS DESTROYING THE SCENE
> > 
> > The use of this drug will bring it down quicker than any government
> > repression or hollywood commercialism.  It will destroy it from
> > within.  People get mean, they stop caring about others and themselves.
> > 
> > Speed kills the Vibe.
> > 
> > 
> > There, I said It.
> > 
> > I'm ready to take the flames.
> >   
> > 
> 
>  I'm not posting to flame - just to add my vague recollection from hippie
> history - didn't speed have it's negative effects on the Haight-Asbury 
> scene? People were using uppers to give them more energy to do what they
> needed to get done, but the speed became an end in itself. Then, to escape
> the bad hangover from speed abuse, people began doing heroin. Can any of
> the older SFRavers confirm/deny/add to this?

This is exactly what I'm talking about. Speed is like a credit card
It doesn't give you more energy, It just let's you "borrow".
Eventually you have to pay.

>  Personal theory: Participants in any scene that "requires" the use of an 
> external tool ( like drugs or music or computers ) , must eventually work
> out a way to be a part of the scene without dependence on the external
> tools. There must be an internal change, leading to greater personal
> freedom.
> 

I'm not saying to people don't use this substance, there is a time and a
place for everything.  Personally, I'd rather see a raver "Do a bump" if
they have to drive 100 miles to get home after raving all night and they don't
think they can stay awake, than get in a car crash because they fell asleep
at the wheel.  But the consistant and habitual use that is starting to take
place is beyond that us ae a tool (as all substances should be).

I for one don't and will never use the stuff, but "I've been there"
so I feel that I can talk knowledgeably about it.  I've seen some
friend's personality change significantly in the last couple of weeks
due to the use of crystal and it worries me.  These people are not bad
but they are getting "hard" and desperate and they are taxing their immune
systems to no end.  I think larry is right on, once a "tool" becomes a
"crutch" it's all over.

Subject: Law and Disorder on the Electronic Frontier

I thought this might be of interest to a few of us SFRavers, given the
recent threads on privacy, virtual culture and the law, etc.  This is
taking place TOMORROW (Sunday), and I'd say there's an 80% chance I'll
be there -- I'd encourage as much SFR participation as possible.

------------  QUOTED FLYER FOLLOWS ------------

        Jacking In:  A Monthly Series on Cyberspace Literacy presents:

        Law and Disorder on the Electronic Frontier

        Computer and telecommunications technologies hold great
        promise for individuals and society.  Increased access to
        information can enhance commerce, political participation,
        community development, and public health and education.

        But, between activities of questionable legality and the
        countermeasures taken by private parties and law enforcement
        officials, these technologies are raising fundamental questions
        about privacy, property, and our freedoms of speech and assembly.

        Join us for an evening of provocative presentations by:

        BRUCE STERLING, author, journalist, editor
        MIKE GODWIN, Electronic Frontier Foundation
        JOHN DRAPER, a.k.a. Cap'n Crunch, reformed cracker
        MITCH RATCLIFFE, cofounder This!Group
        BRUCE KOBALL, Chair, Third Conference on Computers, Freedom,
                        and Privacy

        Sunday, March 7, 7 pm
        $3 - $5 sliding scale

        Modern Times Bookstore
        888 Valencia (19th/20th)    ==> a few doors down from Zanzibar
        San Francisco, CA  94110
        (415) 282-9246

----____----____--__--__--__--__-_-_-_-_-_-__--__--__--__--____----____----
         MykL G             Look to the future!      mcg@netcom.com
____----____----__--__--__--__--_-_-_-_-_-_--__--__--__--__----____----____

From: taxi@netcom.com (TAXI)
Message-Id: <9303071019.AA20337@netcom2.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: RE: techno faschism jism


Hello boys & girls,

I picked up a copy of an LA rave zine, I forgot what it was called cuz I thru
it away already.  It seemed to be a marriage of the house & hip hop scenes. 
Therefore, it had a lot of angry hip hop attitude in it:  full-page ads of rap 
artists giving that 'I'm really trying to be a mean motherfucker' look.  But
what SHOCKED me is that there is a ravewear/skatewear ad in there which shows
a guy on the ground with a red splotch on his back indicating a gunshot wound
and two guys next to him who are running away, while in the foreground is a guy
in a car holding a shotgun.  It's just a gross ad and I guess it says something
about the advertisers who want to glorify something like that.  I thru the mag
away after seeing that.

On a different note, I'm leaving San Francisco for good around March 15.  I'm
driving across the country to end up in Manhattan's lower East side 
temporarily.  It was fun being part of the SF rave scene and sfraves.  Raving,
and the 'vision' I had during Let Freedom Rave changed my life - no joke.  The
scene here is very nice and I'm gonna miss it but sometimes progress requires
change and who knows, I might find/create something just as nice elsewhere.
There's gonna be big changes on Earth in the upcoming years including this one.

Spread the vibe,

TAXI
fractal surfer

Sender: jondr@sco.COM
Date: Mon, 8 Mar 93 10:24:07 PST
Message-Id:  <9303081024.aa25699@scotty.sco.COM>

doom writes:

>When I suggested that I thought that if you were unhappy
>with Jeno's set, "maybe you should get out and do something
>else", I was kind of hinting that you might be getting jaded
>with raving, and you should, like go to the movies, go
>hiking, stay home and read or something.  It kind of seems
>weird to me that a lot of the hard core here don't seem to
>do anything besides go to raves.

i'm definitely into that.  i haven't really *raved* in a long time.
sure, i hang out at clubs where they play techno and i did even drop
in on comeunity but i haven't been in Rave Mode for a while now.

>Anyway, I guess Jon was saying that the "problem" is with
>me, in that I haven't heard Jeno enough to realize he was
>being uninspired.  This is probably true from one point of
>view... but who do you think is a bigger part of the
>audience?  How many people out there do you think can name
>any of the tracks Jeno played?  When the place is packed,
>the sweat's coming down the walls and the energy is flowing,
>why should Jeno even consider doing something different?

nah, problem's not with you.  problem's with me.  i think anybody in
the dj'ing/techno-music-producing biz gets jaded pretty quickly.  and
i've been going out an awful lot.

i also realize that using paradise organisation as an example was a
bad idea.  the one song that really made me go "who is this?  this
can't be jeno" was the infinite wheel - that song is old by any
definition.

on the other hand, my roommate just came back from the FMR and he said
that jeno was incredible - he didn't know what the fuck was happening
at comeunity - "it's like a different guy completely!"   so saith
jeff.  here endeth the lesson.

/j/

Hi fellow ravers!

Mykl asked me to let everyone know when I was going down to SF so's we can 
all get together and grooove!  Well, I and I and part of our tribe (about 
four other members) will be heading down to the Bay Area on March 20 to 
RAVE!!!.  There is no other item on our agenda eXcept to connect with our 
vibe sisters and brothers down there.  

Perhaps someone can suggest a place where we could all meet on Saturday, 
March 20!  If not on that nite, we will be there for a whole week.  A couple 
of the sisters coming with us are under 21.

We are eXcited!  And completely psyched to be going there.  I'm looking 
forward to meeting all the sfravers that can make it out.

Peace, Love, Harmony To You All!!!

Tigger (Glenn) (~)___(~)

From gdpasquinelli@ucdavis.edu  Mon Mar  8 11:38:27 1993

Date: Mon, 8 Mar 1993 11:11:13 -0800 (PST)
Subject: Future Forum
To: SFRAVES LIST <sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu>

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII


THIS IS JUST A SHITTY STORY ABOUT FRIDAY NIGHT...
IF YOU DON'T FEEL LIKE READING IT THEN IT'S NOT IMPORTANT...
But wait...before you go could you clarify where FF is?

        Just wondering how this thing FF went?  I had planned on attending but
trouble struck.  
	It's Friday expectations high...Planning on taking my friend who
likes the commercial raves (Cool World, Sin,...etc.) to an sfr event.
So we go looking for Future Forum.  Didn't really know where bayshore and
industrial are...but as luck has it we end up on bayshore (I thought it
was 101 but instead it's the exit to the Cal Palace just off 101, am I
right so far) 
	Well anyway we find industrial and bayshore...start looking for
Charter Oak...there wasn't really any turn off but the road curved around
so we went to the end looking for cars, listening for the BOOM...BOOM of
our music but nada.  
	Was I in the right place and was just blind or what?
	So we went to rave number two...my friend being slightly agitated
now since he drove up from San Jose...we looked for the one in China Basin
I think it was supposed to be at 17th and Illinois or something...No such
luck.  OK so we look for rave number three...by now it's half past
midnight and friends aren't happy. We looked for Pure Soul just around th
eblock at 16th and Harrison.  Find it...yahoooo...walk up and start
getting bad signs.   About 10 security guards wandering around outside in
their bright yellow jackets.  Oh well...we walk up...get the most complete
frisk job short of a strip search but it was fine, I can deal with it.  OK
buy tickets...I ask how much?...nonchalantly the man says 'twenty'...My
reply 'WHAT???  See ya...
	Friend very pissed at this point as we head back to San Jose
I'm sad...a night wasted.

	Well could someone please tell me if I was in the right place for
FF or what?

Later Dayz...
Gioni
G-man

From: Glenn Fajardo,Cnslt on Mon, Mar 8, 1993 11:58 AM
Subject: Thought For The Day
To: SFRAVES

You don't need to leave your room.
Remain sitting at your table and listen.
Don't even listen, simply wait.
Don't even wait.
Be quiet still and solitary.
The world will freely offer itself to you.
To be unmasked, it has no choice.
It will roll in ecstasy at your feet.

-Franz Kafka

From: Glenn Fajardo,Cnslt on Mon, Mar 8, 1993 11:58 AM
Subject: Thought For The Day
To: SFRAVES

You don't need to leave your room.
Remain sitting at your table and listen.
Don't even listen, simply wait.
Don't even wait.
Be quiet still and solitary.
The world will freely offer itself to you.
To be unmasked, it has no choice.
It will roll in ecstasy at your feet.

-Franz Kafka

From bbehlen  Mon Mar  8 13:26:38 1993
Received: by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA06328; Mon, 8 Mar 93 13:26:38 -0800
Message-Id: <9303082126.AA06328@soda.berkeley.edu>
From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf (Vitamin B))
Date: Mon, 8 Mar 1993 13:26:37 -0800
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves
Subject: The weekend...

        Was something of a drag... it started off well with Future Forum.  
Sorry you couldn't find it, gdpasquinelli, it was pretty good, but small
(which is probably why you couldn't find it).  The crowd was younger than
most I go to (still the average age is well above me), but they seemed a
little more mellow about everything.  The DJing wasn't outstanding but it
was certainly smooth.... what made the event was the sheer amount of STUFF
there, all brought in by various people; Planet 6 and their groovy jamming,
Synergy and their trippy visuals, Bones and moonpup in the basement,...
it definitely had a warm friendly atmosphere.  At least it was until the
nitrous tank showed up (ack :(  )...

	Saturday night I was all set up to go to Ambient Temple of Imagination;
I've talked to Richard Sun before at length, and was expecting an event high
on the vibe and high on the trancedental aspect... and bringing Vrave to it
would have been the icing on the cake.  I was excited to find out it would
be at the Richmond civic aauditorium, since that meant it wouldn't have the
atmosphere a lot of the clubs tend to have and I wouldn't have to scamper
to get my friends in. I was gonna arrive early to set up the computer but
was delayed by an hour to pick up a friend by the airport, so I didn't make it
to the place with said friend until about 11:00 or so... 

	I decided to leave the computer in the car until I was sure about the
space. I started to worry as I approached when I saw youngsta's nothing but
youngsta's, not necessarily ones who'd be attracted to an event whose main
performance of the night was a set by Iaiocore.  Then the music started to
sink in... loud fast hip-hop-break-beat, the kind I haven't been into in ages.
It finally sunk in when I walked to the front, saw fifteen cops, and three
meaty guys with... you guess it... "Cool World" badges :(  I had stumbled
into a Cool World!  Calgon take me away!  :)  They were charging a flat $20
at the door, unlike the $10 Richard said he would be charging.  I felt...
betrayed.  Not that the event can't be cool and people can't have fun at cool
worlds, but it's just not my scene (the smell of fresh $20's was everywhere,
and I don't just mean the greenbacks).  So anyways I left as soon as I came.
The onther things that were possible that night were Groove Kitchen, which
was 21+, and Get Down Get Down, which has a dodgy track record, so my friend
from Boston and I called it quits and drove home.

	On the way we stopped by Berkeley Marina to show him what a great
outdoor rave site it is.  As we pulled into the parking lot, we heard a
voice through a megaphone: "Please do not park, the park is closed".  I
turned around to see a Berkeley Police Department vehicle sitting behind the
bushes.... so I guess no FMR's there for awhile. :)

	Last night I had to skip on the FMR because a Computer Science project
due today had to be done (and still hasn't been completed).,  How was it? Was
it really down at Bonny Doon?

	Brian

Subject: Re: SFRaves was down....& wicked & FMR

In-Reply-To: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu -- 03/08/93 12:30

it was a strange weekend. fri. i went to wicked. it started pretty well, but
at some point around 4 or so i found that i could not get/stay with the
grove of the dj. he would put something down, i'd get into it and then he'd
change it too 'quickly' for me. interestingly, taxi felt similarly. so
i left by 5 am or so.
fmr. it was at one of my favourite locations. there were some technical
ptoblems. so the muzick did not start until about 4 am. at first there
was tremendous energy and excitement. gradually things seem to lose
focus and i felt rather disconnected - i had helped my friend move sun.
so i figured i was too tired. but, no, often times i come tired
to a rave and get energy from the place and the people there. so, i
realised that i got very little eye contact. maybe that was it. i don't
know, the muzick was xcellent and the location was great , but it did not
seem to take off for me. i left around 8 am by which time the cops had
found out about this party and were towing away/ticketing cars parked
illegally. don't know hoe/when it ended and what was it like at the end.
was glad  to meet michael from ne-raves, hope u'r having a good visit.
take care/shalom/rave on/keep the vibe strong
ovid

To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU
From: dgeddes@ucsd.edu (David Geddes)
X-Sender: david@sio
Subject: Re: Upper Abuse / Amateur Philosophy

>>due to the use of crystal and it worries me.  These people are not bad
>>but they are getting "hard" and desperate 


I wholehartedly agree!! I've been involved with the "scene" in L.A. for
about 2 years now and I've seen it change in mood and tone and I think
crystal has alot to do with this change. While I can't be considered an
"old-timer", I was involved when the vibe was truly good.  This of course
corresponded, in part, to the fact that the E was exceptional back then. 
When the E started to turn to shit (at least down here) alot of people
turned to crystal.  BAD MOVE!  The vibe turned increasingly hard, paranoid
and hateful.  In fact Doc Martin has taken loads of shit over his stand
agaist this kind of drug use. Some afterhours I've been to might as well
have been biker bars for the amount of crystal being done and alcohol being
consumed.  gross.

I hope SF stays pure, the events i've been to there have been truly
spiritual at times.  it's nice to know that SF hangs in strong with the
good vibe.  Don't allow what happened to L.A. happen to S.F.

seek satori

d.

Date: Mon, 08 Mar 1993   14:28 -0800 (PST)
From: JACOB%SLACVM.BITNET@cmsa.berkeley.edu
To: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu, sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: Re: SFRaves was down....& wicked & FMR

In-Reply-To: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu -- 03/08/93 12:30

it was a strange weekend. fri. i went to wicked. it started pretty well, but
at some point around 4 or so i found that i could not get/stay with the
grove of the dj. he would put something down, i'd get into it and then he'd
change it too 'quickly' for me. interestingly, taxi felt similarly. so
i left by 5 am or so.
fmr. it was at one of my favourite locations. there were some technical
ptoblems. so the muzick did not start until about 4 am. at first there
was tremendous energy and excitement. gradually things seem to lose
focus and i felt rather disconnected - i had helped my friend move sun.
so i figured i was too tired. but, no, often times i come tired
to a rave and get energy from the place and the people there. so, i
realised that i got very little eye contact. maybe that was it. i don't
know, the muzick was xcellent and the location was great , but it did not
seem to take off for me. i left around 8 am by which time the cops had
found out about this party and were towing away/ticketing cars parked
illegally. don't know hoe/when it ended and what was it like at the end.
was glad  to meet michael from ne-raves, hope u'r having a good visit.
take care/shalom/rave on/keep the vibe strong
ovid

so you all know about casey's afterparty called SMILIN' THRU that
happens at the oasis on saturdays from 4 AM to noon.

this saturday, my roommate jeff headed on over there with robbie
hardkiss and a few others before it actually opened to play some
records on the system.

while they were there hanging out, some guy who got thrown out of the
club on friday night returned with some friends and a handgun and blew
four holes in the bouncer's chest.

needless to say, the party didn't happen.  it was moved to the DNA.

just thought i'd mention it.

Jon Drukman (in stereo where available)                         jondr@sco.com

From mayer@netcom.com  Mon Mar  8 17:42:53 1993
Received: from netcom3.netcom.com by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA08112; Mon, 8 Mar 93 17:42:53 -0800
Received: by netcom3.netcom.com (5.65/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id AA25383; Mon, 8 Mar 93 17:44:46 -0800
Message-Id: <9303090144.AA25383@netcom3.netcom.com>
To: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu>
Subject: add-to-calendar -- rave-kill-file?
Date: Mon, 08 Mar 93 17:44:41 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>


Whatwith the news of I Magi Nation being Cool World, i decided that it
would be cool&groovy if any of us w/ inside information could add
warnings about potential mis-raves to the calendar. Sort of like a
consensual public kill file against bogus rave promoters (e.g. KKKool
World, etc). Now I'm not saying to delete the entries from the
calendar, rather, have a listing at the beginning of the calendar for
any inside info we might glean: voicemail number being the same as some
other large org; promoter who works w/ some other large org. etc.

Currently, I seem to be applying a distance/hassle kill-file to my
raving -- there would have to be promises of an ever-lasting scintilla
of pure joy to get me to drive all the way to Satan Cruz or Richmond...

PS: Those of you that don't like Sharons need not worry no more -- 
someone told me Halim got busted for something nasty. Don't know
anything more about the subject.

PPS: Weekend report -- no raving whatsoever. Though I kinda wished I
had gone to the FMR, I was not willing to risk a drive to santa cruz
just to find out that it got cancelled or delayed till 4AM. I guess
I'll use the excuse of recharging the old Love-Phaser for the
conjunction funktion at Connection.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==           Niels Mayer -- netcom!mayer -- mayer@netcom.com               ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

From taxi@netcom.com  Mon Mar  8 20:49:17 1993
Received: from netcom2.netcom.com by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA24835; Mon, 8 Mar 93 20:49:17 -0800
Received: by netcom2.netcom.com (5.65/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id AA05285; Mon, 8 Mar 93 20:51:11 -0800
Date: Mon, 8 Mar 93 20:51:11 -0800
From: taxi@netcom.com (TAXI)
Message-Id: <9303090451.AA05285@netcom2.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: FMR


Wow, FMR was so amazing.  This ranks up there with one of the best FMRs I've 
been to.  Finally left at 4pm after the music & all ravers execpt 4 were long
gone.  What a magical night.  The little black dog was there again too.

On a mysterious note, I had a UFO sighting last night - no, no it wasn't one 
that a lot a people suspect was due to AltEred stAtes - I really saw something.
I saw a triangular formation of 3 round red spotlights on a thing that was 
flying a way up in the air for about 30 seconds before it
disappeared.  It was zipping around changing direction really quickly.  Did 
anyone else see it?  It happened at about 2:30am and a friend of mine who does
not know what to make of it also saw something.

Also while investigating Bonny Dune road, I saw the aftermath of a scene where
a car had slid off the embankment down the side of the road and was winched up
and towed away.  It looked like it was done very recently from the way the 
grass and trees were stripped down and the way many parts of the front of a
Buick were down there.

Words won't do justice describing the scene at FMR last night.  I would just 
say it was pretty magical.  The vibe was strong and the view was magnificent
and I talked to a lot of people about higher consciousness stuff.

Spread the vibe,

TAXI
Maybe fish look at humans walking and think, "how do they swim so well through
that air?"  Even though we aren't suspended like fish we do kinda swim in this
really really thin fluid called air...........

From doom@leland.Stanford.EDU  Mon Mar  8 22:16:21 1993
Received: from leland.Stanford.EDU by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA03343; Mon, 8 Mar 93 22:16:21 -0800
Received:  by leland.Stanford.EDU (5.57/25-eef) id AA15121; Mon, 8 Mar 93 22:18:22 -0800
Message-Id: <9303090618.AA15121@leland.Stanford.EDU>
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: FMR and next Saturday...
Date: Mon, 08 Mar 93 22:18:21 -0800
From: doom@leland.Stanford.EDU


Hm.  I thought I was the last sfraver in attendance when I
split at 2PM or so.  I wonder how I missed Taxi... anyway,
I cheated by arriving "late"... like 7 or 8 AM.  I felt
really tired Sunday night, so I crashed out early and as a
side effect, I woke up around 5AM and felt like going out.
Thought I might get in a few hours of dancing.  Instead it
was more like a five hour session, including some trash
pick-up, and a brief swimming session...

I didn't notice a *lot* of eye-contact avoidance, but then I
showed up with mass quantities of fruit and donuts and such
that I picked up on the way down.  I guess I have noticed
that a lot of the regulars in the San Francisco in-crowd
(people I see all the time at Full Moons and Golden Gate
park raves) don't quite Get It.  There are quite a few women
around who seem afraid that if they acknowledge your
existance in any way they may be stuck with you until you're
forcibly detached somehow.

Anyway, these days, I don't let it bother me much since I'm
pretty well convinced it's more their problem than mine.

So how long was Markie Mark spinning anyway?  More than four hours?
When he put on a raggamuffin version of "We Are All Family"
at noon, nearly all of the remaining ravers got up to dance.

(Personal aside: Sorry I didn't give you a ride Pat, but I
didn't think you'd appreciate a phone call at 6AM.  And
susie says she really wants to meet you sometime, she
promises not to dis you again.  If nothing else, she'll be
at Connection II).

Another reason for lugging an annoying leather jacket around
at raves:  When you're hauling a garbage bag full of broken
glass up the hill on your back, you worry a lot less about
it.  On the other hand, it doesn't help if rancid beer leaks
out and soaks your hair.  But then, that's what skinny
dipping in the ocean is for...

After the rave, I rambled up the coast to the Three Amigos
for lunch, kept going looking for Grey Whale Cove (again)
and blew it (again) and decided to head up to San Francisco
(again) to visit my home away from home, The Brain Wash,
look for records, and like that.

Along the way I came up with a very interesting flyer:

world premiere performance ov
the Asphyx

Psychedelic
exmperimental
trance
music                    SAT
featuring                March
Paula P-Orridge          13
n Psychick TV            @ the
\Craig of XKP            QUAKE    1748 Haight
                                  S.F.

Anyway, got that?  That's the first serious (in my opinion)
competition for Connection II.  

You know, last Alternity II, I was suprised at the low
turn-out, even among SFravers.  Apparently a lot of people
prefered to go and spend money at Basics.  Now me, I was on
the guest list for Basics that night, but I blew it off to
spend a little money on Alternity, support some friends of
mine in their efforts, and hang out in a smaller, more
intimate setting... 

Just cranking up my guilt phasers in advance. Just in case,
you understand.

From: doom@leland.stanford.edu


Hm.  I thought I was the last sfraver in attendance when I
split at 2PM or so.  I wonder how I missed Taxi... anyway,
I cheated by arriving "late"... like 7 or 8 AM.  I felt
really tired Sunday night, so I crashed out early and as a
side effect, I woke up around 5AM and felt like going out.
Thought I might get in a few hours of dancing.  Instead it
was more like a five hour session, including some trash
pick-up, and a brief swimming session...

I didn't notice a *lot* of eye-contact avoidance, but then I
showed up with mass quantities of fruit and donuts and such
that I picked up on the way down.  I guess I have noticed
that a lot of the regulars in the San Francisco in-crowd
(people I see all the time at Full Moons and Golden Gate
park raves) don't quite Get It.  There are quite a few women
around who seem afraid that if they acknowledge your
existance in any way they may be stuck with you until you're
forcibly detached somehow.

Anyway, these days, I don't let it bother me much since I'm
pretty well convinced it's more their problem than mine.

So how long was Markie Mark spinning anyway?  More than four hours?
When he put on a raggamuffin version of "We Are All Family"
at noon, nearly all of the remaining ravers got up to dance.

(Personal aside: Sorry I didn't give you a ride Pat, but I
didn't think you'd appreciate a phone call at 6AM.  And
susie says she really wants to meet you sometime, she
promises not to dis you again.  If nothing else, she'll be
at Connection II).

at raves:  When you're hauling a garbage bag full of broken
glass up the hill on your back, you worry a lot less about
it.  On the other hand, it doesn't help if rancid beer leaks
out and soaks your hair.  But then, that's what skinny
dipping in the ocean is for...

for lunch, kept going looking for Grey Whale Cove (again)
and blew it (again) and decided to head up to San Francisco
(again) to visit my home away from home, The Brain Wash,

From inhuman@phantom.com  Mon Mar  8 22:28:57 1993
Received: from phantom.com by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA04286; Mon, 8 Mar 93 22:28:57 -0800
Received: by phantom.com (/\==/\ Smail3.1.25.1 #25.21)
	id <m0nVxil-000jrRC@phantom.com>; Tue, 9 Mar 93 01:23 EST
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu, ne-raves@gnu.ai.mit.edu
Subject: Full Moon Rave
From: inhuman@mindvox.phantom.com (Inhuman)
Comments: Feed Your Head
Message-Id: <Das5ZB2w165w@mindvox.phantom.com>
Date: Tue, 09 Mar 93 01:09:24 EST
Organization: [Phantom Access] / the MindVox system

        Wel, this is Inhuman reporting live from Santa Cruz.  I just had 
my first west coast rave experience last night / this morning.  Wow...  I 
went with a friend to Bonnie Doon beach, where the FMR was supposed to be 
held and found a bunch of raverssitting around waiting for the rave to 
start (this was at about 1am).  Several fires were started and we all sat 
around listening to someone's mix tape.  Around two-thirty the sound 
truck finally showed up.  It was really cool, with everyone helping to 
carry the speakers and stuff down into this little cove from up atop 
these sandy cliffs.  After some difficulties, Garth finally got started 
around four.  Everyone was so ready for it to start that the crowd just 
exploded in dance energy.  Garth's set was pretty damn good.  A very 
strong hip-hop influence.  I heard many Public Enemy samples and a lot of 
hip-hop style record scratching.  It really got me moving.  Garth was 
followed by Jeno, who spun a cool set, but nothing terribly incredible.  
The coolest part was the sunrise.  It was cloudy, so there was no 
spactacular sunrise or anything, but just seeing this beautiful cove with 
the waves crashing against the rocks, people up on the cliffs setting up 
tents, and trancey-tribal music resonating everywhere.... WOW.  I ran 
into Susie, fellow dc-raver and she introduced me to a lot of sfravers, s 
o that was fun.  Overall a very cool experience...  So different from the 
east coast.

        See all you sfravers at Connection II!  Sorry for tantalizing all 
you ne-ravers by cross-posting, but I thought you might be interested... 
:-)

Michael                         |  "I've begun to wonder if we wouldn't
(inhuman@mindvox.phantom.com)   |   also regard spelunkers as desperate
                                |   criminals if AT&T owned all the
...trance form...trance send... |   caves."   --John Perry Barlow

From geoffw@nexsys.net  Mon Mar  8 22:42:20 1993
Received: from cdp.igc.org by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA05351; Mon, 8 Mar 93 22:42:20 -0800
Received: by igc.apc.org (4.1/Revision: 1.69 )
	id AA07912; Mon, 8 Mar 93 22:44:36 PST
Received: by nexsys.nexsys.net (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA04835; Mon, 8 Mar 93 22:16:14 PST
Date: Mon, 8 Mar 93 22:16:14 PST
From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
Message-Id: <9303090616.AA04835@nexsys.nexsys.net>
To: sfraves@nexsys.net
Subject: The FMR


	If I die, I hope raver heaven is like last nights FMR.

	It started late but was well worth the wait.
	I got there about 1:15 thinking I was arriving late
	but as usual the sound system hadn't arrived yet.
	There wer maybe 15 people in the parking lot and about
	100 people on the beach.  More people were arriving and
	actually being smart and parking on Bonny Dune road!
	I guess you can train ravers after all!
	For a few moments I thought the FMR massive might have
	changed their minds but around 2:30 I saw one of the folks
	from the british posse and he assured me that the sound
	truxk was on the way. It arrived around 3 and we quickly got
	the equipment down to the beach which is a lot smaller now
	(I guess due to winter storms and stuff).  We had some technical
	problems and one power amp refused to work.  One of Craig Larson's
	sound engineer friends came to the rescue and repatched the system
	to run on one amp.  Not as loud but definately addequate.
	The music was in full swing with Garth leading off.  It was 
	sorta cold but not freezing.  I met a lot of NE ravers
	including inhuman and suzie.  Saw a lot of regulars but surprisingly
	few SFravers. Jeno came on around 6 when it was starting to get light.
	He palyed a typical godlike mind-blasting jeno set that put
	me immediately into deep trance.  In fact it was one of the deepest
	trance states that I have ever attained.  This was particularly
	surprising to me as I was completely sober.  But I guess I know
	beyond a shadow of the doubt, that it's the Vibe and the music
	that does it for me and that it IS possible to rave hard without
	the drugs.  I must have danced for several hours straight without
	crystal or E or A, wow!  It was strange to be in deep trance in
	daytime though with all of the colors and people's faces and stuff.
	After Jeno came Markie and he continued the dance groove, refusing
	to allow people to stop dancing.  I walked around and actually
	talked to a lot of people,  It was great to breath that clean
	air and my lungs actually felt GOOD and clean in the morning.
	Give me an outdoor rave anyday.  If this FMR is what we have to
	look forward to than I'll be happy!

From: rth@netcom.com (Robert Hughes)
