FLAME ON

>of attitude, so i avoid the place...i think that incident has been a
>long time coming....
>

Wonderful attitude for a raver. I've known some Door folks for at least a
decade including Tommy Vision who works at Bottom of the Hill and DNA, and
a fine person. He was shot in the face by some pycho while working the door
at Club Nine, (pre-Stud locaction).  I find if you treat people politely
and don't expect favors if you don't know them, (like getting in if you're
under 21), they treat you OK. I rarely have problems at the door, and if
you do perhaps you should re-align your own attitude. 

I know door persons at several clubs, and they make mistakes just like the
rest of us, but I REALLY don't like you condoning or relishing the fact
that great harm was used against one of them, just because you had a
problem with them. If some one does you wrong it's on their karma, wishing
what you did just drags your own down.

Flame off

Status: OR


I thought about this when one of the first rave I attended got busted.
Think it's a fine idea, perhaps even handing out FM radio headsets at the
door, (have to be a small event. Or if a couple hundred subscribed to Sport
Illustrated when they were offering free FM headsets with a subscription
and then cancelled). 
One of the bigger problems with the idea is sub-woofers have come to play a
large part of the experience, and as FM doesn't go down very far, I think
folks would miss the low end, but it might be interesting for a park type
event to have headsets with a cross-over sending lows to a set of subs, and
the rest to a FM headset broadcast system. Makes a great picture for me.

And on a partially unrelated topic, I've been working a show that had one of the
more advance laser video projectors in existance. Instead of using a Barco
or GE light-valve type projector, this uses a special green-blue laser, and
a red-dye laser and some sort of mask for the picture with a spinning
mirror for the scan. It also has a moving lens aimed at a set of motion
controlled mirrors, (like in an intellibeam), so this machine can move a
bright projected video image all around a large curved screen, (about 200
feet by 60 feet high), all the while correcting for focus and alignment as
well as size and can flip or rotate the image. They cost about a million
each, but have tons of possibilities.

To: ccat@netcom.com, sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re:  Fun idea..!
Cc: fuzzy@media.mit.edu, ne-raves@gnu.ai.mit.edu, socal-raves@ucsd.edu
Status: ORS

Re: Ramsey FM-10 transmitters and raves.

We've talked about this a few times, and there's no real reason you
can't do it. The Ramsey kit is of very good quality sound, stereo, and
not that big a deal to assemble and align for someone who's done this
before. (The modifications commonly described are therefore, optional.
Not really necessary.) You can get the kit at many electronics/surplus
places, and it runs on batteries. It's inexpensive, even if you get
the custom case for it.

One thing I like about the idea is that it virtually eliminates the
possibility of noise complaints. One thing some deejays might not like
is that it makes it easy to tape their sets. 

As for the legality of broadcasting: there is some confusion about how
much power you are allowed to use, however, you do not need much power
to fill a warehouse -- and the structure of the building will tend to
contain the radiation so that it won't carry too much farther. Pumping
up the power is NOT RECOMMENDED, however, since the FCC could
potentially hand you a very large fine.

If I were going to do this, I would probably stick to stock, and use a
small antenna (like the one that comes with stereos). If coverage
wasn't good enough, I'd try a Radio Shack FM "roof mount" antenna. If
reception is still problematic, I'd re-evaluate the site.

Sounds like it's worth a try. Contact me if you like.

bill coderre

From: ccat@netcom.com (Chris)
Message-Id: <9303101647.AA09358@netcom3.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Fun idea..!
Cc: fuzzy@media.mit.edu, ne-raves@gnu.ai.mit.edu, socal-raves@ucsd.edu
Status: OR


 Here's the text of an article I'm working on for Fuzzy Logic.. what do you
folks think of this idea?
-Chris.
Cheaptech blaster/FM TRANSMITTER!

Hey,guys and gals.
Have you ever fantasized about being your own radio dj,playing all your favo-
rite mixes to all your friends .. Well, if you have a minimum skill with a
soldering iron..it's possible to build a small stereo radio transmitter.
This transmitter is so small it can be put inside of a boombox...so you
can take your party on the road!(The ones with mike mixing and built in EQ's
are best!) Imagine the fun when you
and your friends have a picnic in the park..all
listening to the same tune on your blasters.."But where is it coming from..?"
Take the party out to the streets,out to the front of your favorite rave or
club..Anyone
with an FM radio can share in the fun..(For a completely *silent*
party,use headphones,You can all still dance!!!)

The kits that make it all possible are the Ramsey FM-10 microtransmitter
module or the BA 1404 FM stereo module. This and some other systems has been
described in the July 1992 issue of Popular Electronics,along with some
popular mods.The parts are,for the most part,really cheap..so,experiment!

The'mods' may be required to improve certain
characteristics of these transmitters..One good idea would be to replace
the standard capacitors with silver-mica or tantalum capacitors
and possibly (if you are using the FM-10)to replace c7 with a 68 pf capacitor
(to narrow the tuning range..which is quite sharp..)or even better,to
replace c7 and c8 (which are wired in parallel) with a 38 khz quartz crystal
and a 10-20 pf capacitor,wired in series.. This makes it easier to develop
a stable stereo signal!! If you're using an antenna (and not building this
inside a blaster) the ideal antenna length is found by this formula

234/frequency = length in feet 
The frequency should be around 88 or 108 mHz (the ends of the FM band!)
You'll get better reception if you keep the antenna up and away from metal
objects..
If you are building this inside a blaster you'll want to add a "4PDT" tiny
toggle switch to turn on the transmitter,bypass the headphone output of
the blaster into the transmitter,(you may want to add a volume
control for each channel here to adjust the coarse audio level),and
disconnect the antenna from the FM receiver and attatch it to the
transmitter.Label this switch "Transmit"Try to use a good quality switch here,
and keep the leads as short as possible.(You can probably get this
switch at Radio Shack or if you live in NYC,on Canal St.)
An antenna trick might be to add a sheet of flashing copper to the bottom
of the blaster case and
connect it to chassis ground on the blaster.This can provide a 'ground
plane'.Make sure it doesn't make contact with any power wires.This helps the
whip antenna have something to
work 'against'- dramatically increasing your range if you put your
blaster on a car.For more information about radio transmitter construction
techniques check out books on amateur radio at your public library.(If
your town still has one in this era of cutbacks) Remember when doing wiring
to stay far away from any 110 volt wiring in your blaster.This is usually
connected to the power switch and the power plug.(You will want
to have a friend who knows electronics check your work,before you turn it
on,if you have any doubts..)
Good luck!

 Okay,here are the surces for
the kits and information..
The BA1404 transmitter is $2.00 (yes,that wasn't a typo.)from D.C.
Electronics. 1-800 467-7736 or 1-800 423-0700
The manufacturer can be reached at
Rohm Corporation,
3034 Owen Drive
Antioch,TN 37013
(615)641-2020

The FM-10 transmitter can be obtained from Ramsey Electronics at
(716)924-4560 
38 khz crystals are available from Digi-Key
(800)DIGI-KEY (part #SE3314) (be careful when soldering this)

Much higher quality,but much more expensive kits can be bought from
Panaxis Productions,PO Box 130,Paradise,CA 95967
(916)534-0417
There's lots more info I could steer you to,but we have limited space.
For more FM-10 info,there's a mailing list on the Internet that you can join
to get more info..(if you have e-mail access)

It's accessible by sending a quick note to:
fm-10-request@dg-rtp.dg.com
There's also a file available by Internet FTP (file transfer utility)
on related subjects..It's on the 'host' dg-rtp.dg.com in the fm-10 directory.

Also, a small packet on FM-10's can be gotten from Mycal at PO Box 750381
Petaluma,CA 94975. Send him a dollar and a self addressed,stamped envelope
to cover mailing costs. Good luck! Who needs a club to have a rave!!

-Chris.

>Speed kills the Vibe.

O.K. I think I 11th or 12th the motion at this point.  I have known one
and only one person out of the whole bunches of people that I have known
that got into this drug that can handle it (including myself, I tweak hard
on stimulants, even coffee).  I realy don't mean to sound cliche but I have
seen a few good friends and many general aquaintances that have become
unexceptably weird from speed.  It's kinda funny at first to talk
about the little humuorous stories of your tweaker friends exploits and
long binges but it gets old when you have it affect your life and your not
even in that scene.

I'm convinced that one friend that I have has neurological damage.  She has
lived on speed for about 8 years or so now.  She wakes up when she sleeps
(not often) and can't open her eyes or move a muscle and she freeks out
'cause she feels trapped in her body.  Theres too much more to even write.

Another friend feels the need to explain everything and make very loose
associtations between completely unrelated occurances, pysical objecte, ect.
and thinks he is "explaining the universe".  "See that potato chip wrapper
blowing by?  That's a south-blowing wind.  The center of the galaxy is to
the south.  That wrapper is on it's way to the center of the galaxy."  Ya
like that but even worse.

Then this other person who is convinced that "they" are after him because
of his heavy political activism.  Not hard to believe except that he's not
politicly active.  He made some copies of political material for someone
once.

I party with that one individual that I mentioned that can handle speed all
the time but that's cause he can handle it.  He has intense staminia.  I've
seen the guy sick maybe 3 or 4 times in the 8 or so years that I've known
him but maybe his nose is too toxic for germs to survive in.  He also knows
when to eat and sleep and doesn't act unexceptably weird. 

I have heard more than a few times that speed caused or heavily contributed
to the demise of the Haight-Ashbury scene.  I would tend to believe it and
this scares me because I totaly agree with Geoff W., if anything can ruin
the scene, out of everything that we've talked about, speed can.

Sorry for the rant but I could write a book of stories and trouble that
I've seen like the stories above.  Actualy I could write a book about
each individuals trips.  I guess I'm kinda biased about this subject but
I don't generaly preach at people.


-Mark

From sfraves-request@medisg.Stanford.EDU Thu Mar 11 11:21:44 1993

	id AA18874; Thu, 11 Mar 93 11:21:35 -0800

	id AA09262; Thu, 11 Mar 93 11:15:04 PST
Received: from apple.com by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA18282; Thu, 11 Mar 93 11:12:43 -0800
Received: by apple.com (5.61/7-Aug-1992-eef)
	id AA21814; Thu, 11 Mar 93 11:14:53 -0800
	for sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Date: Thu, 11 Mar 93 11:14:53 -0800
From: bill coderre <bc@apple.com>
Message-Id: <9303111914.AA21814@apple.com>
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: Respectfully, a flame
Status: ORS

SFRAVES is a mailing list. This means that it gets delivered to
peoples' mailboxes, one copy to a customer. 

Unlike a bulletin board or a news group, there is no easy way for
people to skip over the material that is not of interest to them. In
addition, that material gets mixed in with their personal email. It
takes up their personal disk space.

This mailing list also generates more traffic than almost everybody's
personal email. I have lots of email pals, and get 100 messages a week
from them. SFRAVES generates more mail messages than that. 

There is no moderator to weed through the chaff. Each person who
subscribes -- over a hundred people last I heard -- has to deal with
this volume of mail. It's their diskspace and their time. 

Now if the volume is mostly junk, people give up and leave. The
mailing list tends to become pure junk, and dies. Junk breeds junk.

Don't send junk.

Don't send stuff that's more appropriate elsewhere. For instance, if
you have an apartment, a car, a turntable, or whatever, or you want
one, check out the numerous and very well stocked usenet newsgroups
for exactly these purposes. Some start with ba.market. More people
read ba.market groups than read this list. More people will help you
sell or buy a car, turntable, or apartment. They are reading those
groups for the specific purposes of doing just that.

Why am I reading this mailing list? To hear about raves. Not
apartments, cars, or turntables. I have tolerated and continue to
tolerate the discussion that strays from my own personal interests.
If I didn't, I would leave. But please realize that when your
submissions to this mailing list are off the topic, you are helping to
kill it off.

If you have any comments about this, feel free to send them to me, at
the address above, if you think they are not germane to the other >99
people who will have to read them and delete them.

bill coderre

	Ayup, looks like slim pickins this weekend.  Gee, I don't have much
to recommend... There's this small thang going on saturday night, but I dunno
much about it... (hee hee hee).

	The thing on Thursday night sounds cool, if only it weren't at the
Sound Factory, which is semi-notorious for being very "clubby" and alcoholic.
But some good events have happened there, maybe I should give it the benefit
of the doubt...

	Friday night I _may_ check out Mister Roger's Neighborhood, only to
Doc Martin and Jeno... and then afterwards hit Smiling Thru. I would also
highly recommend Mission Rock that night too, as a pre-rave cool place to
hang out.  

	Saturday night, of course, is the SFRaves birthday party.  Things
are falling into place VERY nicely for it.  If you decide to go, PLEASE
dress warmly and carry a flashlight.  And set your luv phasers on kill. :)
If you can't make Connection, Ascend looks like it has a pretty good DJ lineup;

	And I hope to see EVERYONE at the GG Park thang on Sunday afternoon.
It's the beginning of something big...

	And if you do go out, DRIVE SAFELY.  See everyone this weekend!

	Brian

	id AA22363; Thu, 11 Mar 93 12:08:11 -0800
Received: by netcom2.netcom.com (5.65/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id AA01888; Thu, 11 Mar 93 12:10:18 -0800
Date: Thu, 11 Mar 93 12:10:18 -0800
From: taxi@netcom.com (TAXI)
Message-Id: <9303112010.AA01888@netcom2.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: More speeding stories
Status: ORS


OK, I personally don't touch the stuff cuz I was born on some sort of natural
speed and I haven't slowed down since birth. Of course, I do need my sleep.

But I have known many friends who tweek.  I can't even think of one that
handles it well.  I'll just talk about three of the worst cases:  one started
mixing it with A and after about a month of mixing, he ended up in a mental
institution - I don't know his whereabouts anymore.  Another lost so much
weight, he looks like he's an anorexic.  Another just got very weird - like
he was seriously "wacko" - *intense* emotions for no obvious reasons.  He 
returned to his "normal" personality again when he quit and once again he's 
quite fun to be around.

I recommend caffeine over speed any day.  But I must mention that studying for
a final a while back, I had a near nervous breakdown after drinking about 10
cups of very, very strong coffee.  I don't even drink soft drinks with caffeine
anymore..........cuz I don't need to nor want to :-)

Remember, TAXI's tips on responsible raving: (they're just tips, not laws)
- don't tweek
- catch up on sleep if you stay awake for the whole night
- bring snacks to give yourself some morning calories after a night's worth
  of dancing and staying up (unless you're into losing weight)
- drink lottsa water over the course of the eve.
- if your piss turns clear by the morning, take a multi-vitamin & mineral pill,
  fruits are great.
- don't drive if you're sleepy
- bring along all this stuff with you when you go raving, you decide what.
- quit your job if you can't handle raving & work <-- jus kidding, ha ha ha 
- don't smoke cigarettes (Raving & cigarettes turned my lungs to mush).

I lost 25 lbs (12% of my body weight) in about 3 months when I first started
raving.  That's when I came up with the "responsible raving" idea.  Sure it
sounds like common sense but I had to force myself to make sure I had a water
bottle (now I bring two), vitamin pill, cookies, extra clothing with me as I
left home in a hurry.  I don't think I've lost anymore weight since then.

spread the vibe,
TAXI
fractal surfer

XDZebra Review #24

I've got a stack of about twenty discs in the queue right now.  Finals aren't
helping much, but I'll attempt to get things out in a timely manner.  Also,
I've started to buy (horror of horrors) vinyl.  Don't expect many reviews on
that though, I don't think my work would take to me putting a 1200 in my
office.

	Addiction
	266 Delmar Ct.
	Salt Lake City, UT 84101-1817

When in Utah call the T A S T E hotline 801-461-3375.

Trying to find these releases?  Try Ear/Rational Music:
FAX 805/893-8553, Phone 805/564-4949, email angst%cs@hub.ucsb.edu

Back issues are available from me by mail or by ftp'ing to soda.berkeley.edu.
They're in the pub/sfraves/music directory.

This is all my opinion.  Flames against a review are pretty pointless, so
don't bother.  Let me know if you have any other comments though.

The number next to the index is the "dance factor". 5 = high, 1 = low

XDZebra Reviews may be reproduced without permission under one condition,
they remain intact and unchanged.  If you publish this in print, mail me a
copy via "Addiction".

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Review #24 Contents:
The Irresistible Force: Flying High
Frankfurt Trax Vol. 3: The House of Phuture
GTO: Love is Everywhere
Ragga Gabba Posse [Dr. Nunu]
Go Bang! Volume 2
System 7: 7:7 Expansion
In Order To Dance: 4


The Irresistible Force: Flying High
Rising High Records: RSN CD5
1       07:42 Spiritual High
2       12:01 Sky High
3       15:33 Flying High
4       09:39 High Frequency
5       08:48 Symphony in E
6       20:04 Mountain High (Live)

Comments: Done up in typical Irresistible Force ambient style (hold, pitch
bend, echo, mutate), "Flying High" is wonderful listening.  Although this
album does dip into a beat periodically, most notably on "High Frequency" and
"Symphony in E" it certainly isn't a dancefloor demolisher.  There are times
when this music tends to irritate me, but when I'm in the mood it locks
perfectly and manages to drop my heart-beat a few levels.  I'd like to see
Irresistible Force put out some dancier stuff though.  His track "Underground"
is one of my favorites.

Summary: 8/10.  For the mind and spirit.  Good variation in a single artist's
ambience is rare, but Irresistible Force does it.


Frankfurt Trax Vol. 3: The House of Phuture
Dance Pool: DAN 472387 2
1   4   03:56 Ace the Space: 9 is a Classic (Ultimate Rave Remix)
2   4   03:57 KillerLoops: Murder One
3   3   04:10 T-Bone Castro: I Want Cha (Women Here Part 2)
4   3   03:59 R U Ready: Uaeth 2
5   5   04:18 Mescalinum United: The 2nd Coming
6   3   03:46 A Lighter Shade: I Start 2 Fly
7   5   03:49 Nasty Django: Ey Loco!
8   4   03:43 Turbulence: Disaster Area
9   5   03:13 The Mover: Comet's Swarm Rising
10  3   04:10 The Possessed: Black Blood
11  4   03:10 Terrorists: The Outside World
12  2   04:04 Dag Tribe: Legalize It!
13  5   03:54 Headshop: Floorlifter
14  3   04:00 Program 1: World's Famous MF (Fractured Skull Mix)
15  3   02:08 Stalker: Walk on Thunderground
16  3   03:26 303 Nation: DetoNation
17  2   02:40 Alien Christ: Of Suns and Moons (Phaze 4)

Comments:  While this compilation of Planet Core, Dance Extasy 2001, Pretty
Asshole, and Super Special Corp artists contains some highly original and
headsplitting tracks, they are offset by cheap hardcore that is just plain
boring.  On the up side, Mescalinum United, The Mover, A Lighter Shade, Nasty
Django, Ace the Space, Headshop, and Turbulence.  Absolute garbage is turned
in by Dag Tribe, Stalker, 303 Nation, and Alien Christ.  What a way to end
what would have otherwise been a stellar collection of hardcore.

Summary: 5/10.  Hardcore fans will rate this higher, but I have a queezy
stomach when a track is just a ten second repeat.


GTO: Love is Everywhere
NovaMute: NMCD 3004
1   5   06:29 Elevation (Troll Mix)
2   4   06:08 Love is Everywhere (Everybody Party Mix)
3   4   06:15 The Bullfrog (Dataflow Mix)
4   4   06:11 Elevation (Sonic Beat Mix)
5   5   05:52 Love is Everywhere (Love Parade)
6   3   05:45 Love is Everywhere (Live & Love Mix)
7   3   05:39 Pure Energy
8   4   04:42 Listen to the Rhythm Flow (Make Some Noise)

Comments: More of an EP than album, GTO gives us three good mixes of the title
track and fills the remaining space with mixes that don't stack up to the
original singles.  The "Troll Mix" of "Elevation" was included on the
"Elevation" single, and is excellent, but played out.  The included mixes of
"The Bullfrog" and "Listen to the Rhythm Flow" long and uninspired.  Finally,
the "Pure Energy" makes you wonder if Newman & Wells were really behind it.
It lacks everything that its title makes it out to be.

Summary: 6/10.  An excellent single with plenty of bonus tracks.  Too bad it
really is an album.


Ragga Gabba Posse [Dr. Nunu]
Thunderpussy: THP 2005-2
1   4   05:04 Raggatrance 2000 pt.1
2   4   05:04 Raggatrance 2000 pt.2
3   5   05:28 Zap Machine pt.1
4   5   05:27 Zap Machine pt.2

Comments: "Raggatrance" is reminiscent of some Fierce Ruling Diva material,
and indeed usually mixes well into each other.  "Zap Machine" kicks hard with
a grooving guitar loop and a pumping beat.  I don't know what to think about
the pt.1 and pt.2 scheme though.  The second parts are definitely not
different enough to be called mixes, but I don't know why they just didn't
merge them into one track with a bit more variety.  Possibly because it would
have looked like you were getting two tracks on a disc?  Well, despite the
break, that is all that you're getting.

Summary: 6/10.  Good music, but at a $10 import for essentially two tracks,
not worth it.


Go Bang! Volume 2
Go Bang!: BANG CD096
1   1   02:15 Shake Inc.: Deep in Space
2   3   04:57 Quazar: Paradise
3   4   05:15 Shake Inc.: Brain Induction
4   4   05:00 Penetration: Basic Penetration
5   5   06:11 Turtable Hype: Techno Nation (NY Rave Reverb)
6   3   03:44 Supermatic: Power of the Dark Side
7   4   05:14 Quazar: Red Alert
8   4   04:49 D-Shake: Tecn0 Bam (Seismic Wow Edit)
9   4   03:03 Supermatic: To Uncommunicate
10  3   03:19 Turntable Hype: Set You Free (S Ozone Mix)
11  3   04:35 Shake Inc.: Rubb-a-Dubb Freestyle
12  5   06:07 Quazar: Dragonfighters
13  5   05:50 D-Shake: East of Eden
14      00:37 Outtro

Comments: A real mixed bag.  A lot of these tracks tend to be very standard
techno with no real progression.  These are prime examples of what makes an
initiate to the style stand back and state, "This all sounds the same."  Yet
tracks like D-Shake's and Quazars "Dragonfighters" are really quite good.  The
Shake Inc. stuff generally stinks, including yet another take on Luc Van
Acker's "Its in My Brain Now" sample with "Brain Induction".  Supermatic's
stuff is plain and unmoving.  Penetration provides a funky beat, but nothing
new.

Summary: 7/10.  The poor stuff isn't terrible, but the good stuff is really
great.


System 7: 7:7 Expansion
Weird and Unconventional/Big Life: BFLD 2
1   3   03:39 Conspiracy Edit
2   3   10:02 Conspiracy Mix
3   4   06:47 Nutritious Mix
4   1   10:10 Double Edge Sword Mix

Comments: Steve Hillage, Youth, and Tony Thorpe produce a mildly dancey,
strongly boring single for the upcoming System 7 album.  Yes, it is a catchy
guitar line Steve, and the the "huh-huh" sample fits beautifully, but what
else is there?  Tastes great, no filling.  The "Nutrious Mix" almost makes it
with some interesting breaks, but still isn't up to par with past System 7
work.  "Double Edge Sword" takes things on yet another burbling brook,
when-can-I-hear-the-theme-please ambient trip.  There is an interesting turn
about nine minutes into this mix, but it is quickly lost to more of the same.

Summary: 4/10.  I wouldn't be so down on this if it was $4 at a domestic
price, but otherwise forget it.


In Order To Dance: 4
R&S/BMG: 74321 122962
Disc 1:
1   4   07:05 Ramin vol. 2: Brainticket
2   3   04:55 C.J. Bolland: Nightbreed
3   5   04:00 N. R. G.: The Real Hardcore
4   4   05:06 Source: Neuromancer
5   4   04:52 House of Usher: Shades
6   3   05:46 DJ Hell: My Definition of House Music
7   4   05:08 Dave Angel: Bounce Back
8   5   05:30 Sven Van Hees: Emotional Rehabilitation
9   5   05:00 TC 1992: Funky Guitar
10  4   06:34 Phase Feat. Dr Motte: Der Klang der Familie
11  4   04:32 Phuture Past: Clinically Inclined (Remix)
12  3   07:15 Aphex Twin: Digeridoo
13  5   07:57 Neuro: Mama
Disc 2:
1   3   07:03 Mundo Muzique: Andromeda
2   4   04:20 Minimal Vision: Magic Staircase
3   5   04:57 The Future Sound of London: Papua New Guinea
4   5   05:33 Electrotete: I Love You
5   3   06:28 Phuture: Rise From Your Grave
6   5   06:19 Jam & Spoon: Stella
7   4   04:46 Aphex Twin: Analog Bubblebath
8   3   10:06 The Infinite Wheel: Lake of Dreams
9   5   05:45 Piece: Free Your Mind
10  3   06:16 Rhythm Invention: Can't Take It
11  5   06:46 Music of Life Orchestra: The Dream
12  4   03:22 Jaydee: Plastic Dreams
13  5   05:11 Golden Girls: Kinetic

Comments:  Hands down, the best dance compilation I have ever bought.  The most
prime cuts of 1992 are on here.  Even though I already have many of these on
other compilations or singles, this brings the best all together.  If you're
looking for an introduction, buy this.  If you're looking for a best of, buy
this.  The first disc is harder than the second disc, but they both cross
zones with Neuro and Rhythm Invention.  Highlighted is the excellent new mix
of "I Love You" from Electrotete.  They've managed to take what they did for
Give Peace a Dance 2 and turn it into a stunning, moving, melodic masterpiece.
One disappointment is DJ Hell's "My Definition of House Music" which rocked
the charts, but is really only a simple remix of David Byrne's "Ava".  I liked
Jack Danger's version better.  Byrne isn't credited anywhere.  This isn't
sampling, it is stealing.  Also, "Digeridoo" sounds really weak for some
reason.  I think it is recorded at a slower speed.

Summary: 10/10.  $25-$28 is a steal for this kind of quality music.  Makes
other comps look like K-Tel.

Date: Thu, 11 Mar 1993   14:05 -0800 (PST)
From: JACOB%SLACVM.BITNET@cmsa.berkeley.edu
To: doom@leland.stanford.edu, sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: Re: Changes at Bonny Doon
Status: R

I was coming home to SF from the south bay on 101 the other day (right
before the full moon) and i noticed the opposite strangeness: very low tide.

You know the part of 101 near the water before candlestick (going south).
In my 10 years of living in the bay area, i've never seen so many rocks exposed
and so much mud/silt exposed. We're talking wicked low tides here. I did
have the thought that the tides would be unusually high for the FMR.

So there.

Niels says:

>I was coming home to SF from the south bay on 101 the other day (right
>before the full moon) and i noticed the opposite strangeness: very low tide.
>
>You know the part of 101 near the water before candlestick (going south).
>In my 10 years of living in the bay area, i've never seen so many rocks exposed
>and so much mud/silt exposed. We're talking wicked low tides here. I did
>have the thought that the tides would be unusually high for the FMR.

This makes perfect sense. All of that water that's coming in to form our
record high tides has to come from somewhere. It's coming from the other side
of the world, resulting in record low tides there. When the earth rotates
180 degrees, we get the record low tides and they get the record highs.

						Pete

From sfraves-request@medisg.Stanford.EDU  Thu Mar 11 19:57:44 1993
Received: from medisg.Stanford.EDU by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA05286; Thu, 11 Mar 93 19:57:44 -0800
Received: by medisg.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA17543; Thu, 11 Mar 93 19:50:59 PST
Received: from soda.berkeley.edu by medisg.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA17539; Thu, 11 Mar 93 19:50:58 PST
Received: from netcom.netcom.com by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA04843; Thu, 11 Mar 93 19:48:43 -0800
Received: from netcom2.netcom.com by netcom.netcom.com (5.65/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id AA13705; Thu, 11 Mar 93 19:50:37 -0800
Date: Thu, 11 Mar 93 19:50:37 -0800
Message-Id: <9303120350.AA13705@netcom.netcom.com>
X-Mailer:  Eudora
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu (SFRaves)
From: mcg@netcom.com (Tiamat the Chaos-Ocean)
Subject: Review of "Law and Disorder on the Electronic Frontier"
Cc: ligr206@orange.cc.utexas.edu (Stephen Daedalus),
        jacobs@mcc.com (Nigel Jacobs)

This panel discussion took place last Sunday as a sort of "teaser" for
CFP '93 (The Third Conference on Computers, Freedom and Privacy) that's
running this Tuesday through Friday at the Airport Marriott in
Burlingame.  It was designed in equal parts as a general introduction to
the social and legal issues posed by the information and communication
revolutions that are being addressed by groups such as the EFF, and as a
book-plugging opportunity for cyberpunk whiz Bruce Sterling (who
commanded more speaking time than the other three participants
combined).  At $3-$5, it provided a financially reasonable alternative
to the CFP conference with its rather steep $405 cover charge.

From a social and legal standpoint, the most interesting presentations
were those by Mike Godwin and Mitch Ratcliffe.  Godwin is "employee
serial number 1" of the Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF), founded by
Mitch Kapor of Lotus and others to track issues in this field and to
lobby for legislation necessary to preserve our rights in the face of
incredibly rapid technical change.  In 1988, the year of the Internet
worm scandal and the year a German cracker was caught selling U.S.
defense information to the Eastern Bloc, he decided to enter law school
to further avoid "growing up".  He chose to specialize in criminal law,
reasoning it was the "least boring, if also least well-paid" area of the
profession.

By Godwin's graduation in 1990, "computer crime looked like a real
growth industry" -- this was the year of the AT&T system crash which
induced much paranoia about the possibility of cyber-terrorism, and the
year Steve Jackson, an entirely innocuous BBS sysop in Texas had his
entire system seized by the Secret Service and was effectively put out
of business.  Godwin successfully defended Jackson against all charges,
and was subsequently offered the position as legal council at EFF and
decided to snatch it up.  He spoke passionately for the need to
disseminate cryptography technology as widely and quickly as possible as
our first line of defense against governmental and corporate intrusion
into our electronically networked lives.  He also drew our attention to
the federal government's active attempt to mandate that future digital
telephony equipment be "wiretap-friendly", that is, designed to easily
allow monitoring of communications without those "unsightly and
inconvenient alligator clips."  (This, my friends and SFR comrades,
should give you some inkling about their attitude towards the
Internet...)

Mitch Ratcliffe is an editor at MacWeek magazine who has a deep interest
in privacy issues, and formed a local organization called "This!Group"
as a sort of Bay Area-focused grassroots version of EFF.  The bulk of
his talk consisted of a close analytical reading of a form letter sent
to him from Chase Manhatten Bank, with whom he maintains a credit card.
The letter thoughtfully outlined an opportunity to buy back from them,
for a "modest" annual fee, all kinds of information they've accumulated
about his credit history, Social Security status, DMV data, and perhaps
most insidiously, his medical records.  Needless to say he raised a few
eyebrows and prickly questions about exactly who owns this sensitive
personal information and who should have control over its distribution.

John "Cap'n Crunch" Draper is a legendary techno-pirate whose many
exploits include invention of the "Blue Box" in the early 1970's, and
participation in the Homebrew Computing Club in whose womb Apple
Computers incubated.  He designed a telephony board for the Apple II
that allowed Wozniak to harass Jobs by methodically calling and hanging
up.  He recounted his experiences in prison where his fellow inmates,
having viewed a TV news report of Draper's conviction on phone hacking
charges, pressured him into conducting classes to teach them the in's
and out's of ripping off AT&T, and what happened when he was discovered
giving them intentionally inaccurate information (all he said about that
was that he was made to regret that decision to this day.)  Aside from
that amusing anecdote, his chat was rather long on techno-babble and
short on social insight, and seemed designed to impress rather than
illuminate.

But it was Bruce Sterling who stole the show, not to mention the bulk of
the speaking fees.  He spoke eloquently and engagingly about his
interest in the Steve Jackson case, which he spent 1-1/2 years of his
life researching and writing about in his book "The Hacker Crackdown".
As a result of this experience, he joined the first (and due to a change
in bylaws, also the last) local chapter of EFF in Austin, Texas.  He
observed acerbically how quickly his book has become out-of-date, given
advances in technology and legal developments, commenting that, much
like dog-years, "one year in cyberspace is equivalent to seven years
anywhere else."

Having discovered the Internet as a result of his research, he found
that it was the "apotheosis of the science fiction fanzine scene", an
ideal medium for establishment of his "vanity press."  To his utter
delight, he managed to attend the first CFP conference, which he
described as a "science-fictional event", in which hackers freely
co-mingled with Secret Service and FBI agents and everyone seemed "as if
they were on psilocybin."  He enjoyed the first two CFP's so much he
actually decided to *pay* to attend this year's!

Referring to Hakim Bey, he described the likelihood of future
corporations temporarily forming to develop some new technology and
disbanding before the full implications of the technology and its impact
on society are fully realized.  This phenomenon, which effectively
allows corporations to dodge social accountability is described in the
recent book "The Virtual Corporation."  I wonder if Bey anticipated the
application of his paradigm by the dominator culture as well as by those
operating outside of it.

He reserved his sharpest contempt for the notion that the Secret
Service, much less any arm of the U.S. government, can have any control
over the proliferation of software piracy and other hacking-related
crime now that armies of Eastern European teenagers have unleashed their
talents in societies for which there is "absolutely nothing else for
them to occupy their time."  At the same time, and somewhat
contradictorily, he discounted the danger of American teenagers breaking
into systems such as the Internet since they'll quickly find there's
little money in it.

Although some mention was made of the need to preserve and protect
privacy in electronic networking, the emphasis in this panel discussion
was on BBS's and their role in software and telephone system piracy, and
as such had little direct connection to issues of interest to us
SFRavers.  Still, there was much of historical interest, and it struck
home to me when Mike Godwin waxed about how this era is potentially the
most democratically and technologically revolutionary in history, in
that for the first time the bulk of communication is shifting from the
top-down hierarchical paradigm to one that connects "many people to many
people all at once in every direction."  Sounds kinda like raving to
these ears...

The entire session, including a lively Q&A period, was recorded on
videotape. I asked the woman recording it if audio copies might be
available.  She said they would and I have her e-mail address, so if
there's enough interest out there, we can probably arrange for one or
more tapes to be circulated.  Send me e-mail if you're interested and
I'll try to organize either a bulk reproduction of the tapes or some
other way of distributing them.

----____----____--__--__--__--__-_-_-_-_-_-__--__--__--__--____----____----
         MykL G             Look to the future!      mcg@netcom.com
____----____----__--__--__--__--_-_-_-_-_-_--__--__--__--__----____----____

Hi

I went to Bro last week end in NYC and it was a blast albeit not a  
true scene.  Too, I was surprised to hear that NE-Ravers were there  
and I didn't bump into them  :(  .  ORB was supposed to play, but he  
didn't hence the transliteration--BRO.  The cool thing was that in  
the CHILL room they were playing jazzy hip-hop.  I hadn't really  
listened to that genre 'cuz limited airplay, etc. in the Boston area.   
In fact, my first exposure was on a Sunday morning news show  
featuring a rapper mixing with old jazz stars and their music.  I was  
surprised at how friendly the sound/lyrics were given ganster rap.

Anyway I bought Digable Planets, at FACE recommendation.  I'm very  
pleased with the purchase and seems to me this disc is jazzy hip-hop  
and very appropriate for Chill scenes.

Just my 1/2 p  or $.02     : )

Brendan

From: Glenn Fajardo,Cnslt on Fri, Mar 12, 1993 3:11 PM
Subject: The Seattle Scene
To: mcdougal@jensen.cc.brandeis.edu; SF Raves

This message was sent using a custom form that is not installed on your server.

complete message, ask your network manager to install the form on your server.

From: Glenn Fajardo,Cnslt on Fri, Mar 12, 1993 9:53 AM
Subject: The Seattle Scene
To: brendan mcdougall
Cc: SFRAVES


Hi Brendan,

We don't have a list server YET!  I'm working on setting up a NWRaves group. 
The scene up here is YOUNG.  Young in the sense that it is new to people here. 
There is a new sense of community arising from the raves that are being thrown
but, some people still don't get the idea that raving is viable movement and
not just another type of party.  It's about where the rave scene was in SF two
years ago.  Things are improving with time however.  Personally, my goal is to
help cultivate a good vibe and a strong sense of community.  The local
ordinances have been a pain in the ass.  There's a really harsh teen dance law
that's been killing the promoters as well as (Aaargghh!) the Seattle PD Rave
Task Force!  There's actually a a group of cops dedicated to busting raves that
crop up here.
The promoters here however, have started a dialog with these nazis.  Hopefully
we can turn them around to see that raves are not a threat, but an enhancement
to the city of Seattle. 

There are only several local promoters here.  So we're averaging 1 rave per
week, although small house parties have been proliferating as well.  However
some of the Bay Area promoters are starting to come up as well.  A Rave Called
Sharon will be held here this week (Sat. 3/13).  I'm looking forward to
checking it out.  We've had the good fortune to have had excellent DJ's from
down south come up.  Doc Martin, Garth, Spun, Jeno(!), DJ Pasta, Moonpup have
all been here within the last 3 months. The local DJ's here are very good as
well.  Dominator, Hebegebe, Tripper, Blade, to name a few have really been
polishing their craft and have done really good shows.

That's about it in a nutshell.  I would welcome any feedback from the sfravers
about ways that we can perhaps nurture the vibe and develop a strong cohesive
community up here. That's my primary reason for posting this reply to SFRAVES
as well. 

Peace, Luv & Ecstasy To You!

Tigger

  
_______________________________________________________________________________

NO I DON'T THINK IT'S DESERVED, COOL, OR ANYTHING ELSE ALONG THOSE LINES.


what i *said* is "i am NOT surprised it happened, given the rep and conduct
of those bouncers."

is that clear?  please don't ask me again if i think the bouncer "deserved
to die" or any other stupid shit like that, of course i don't, get real.

as for this:
-----------
FLAME ON

Wonderful attitude for a raver.  I've known some Door folks for at least a
decade including Tommy Vision who works at Bottom of the Hill and DNA, and
a fine person. He was shot in the face by some pycho while working the door
at Club Nine, (pre-Stud locaction).  I find if you treat people politely
and don't expect favors if you don't know them, (like getting in if you're
under 21), they treat you OK. I rarely have problems at the door, and if
you do perhaps you should re-align your own attitude.

I know door persons at several clubs, and they make mistakes just like the
rest of us, but I REALLY don't like you condoning or relishing the fact
that great harm was used against one of them, just because you had a
problem with them. If some one does you wrong it's on their karma, wishing
what you did just drags your own down.

Flame off
--------------
1st:my attitude is not what you think it is.  2nd: bouncers who feel the need
to randomly attack people at the clubs at which they work are *much* different
than the ones that do that admittedly difficult job properly.  3rd: i have
had *personal* experience with a bouncer at oasis and therefore *know* beyond
*any* doubt which kind of bouncer i dealt with, but you don't.  it was clear
at the time that the management *supported* the bouncers mistreating the
clientel.  people who physically mistreat others *may* find retaliation
directed at them, (tho NOT by me) which will NOT SURPRISE ME, get it?
and please....some of us believe in karma, etc., BUT...
good.


flame off?  nyaghh, it ain't that hot...

-=jack=-

	comfortably.  He can now be moved to St. Mary's.

	crank up those luv-phasers.  Set them on HIGH and go for it.

	people ravers really are.  Mal healing and recover process begins

	and advice, including medical, nutritional, legal, psychologica;,
	financial, etc.  Please e-mail me if you have special skills
	that you can donate or give at reduced rates.  If you know people

  The following is taken from the TAM NEWS (Tam High School, Marin County),
from an article on raves in the school paper:
  "Raves are the least of our problems.  We just stop by to make sure it's
safe, the access doors aren't crowded, there is proper security, and the
owners have the proper required permits," says Sargeant Steven Jones of
the San Francisco Police Department Task Force....
  "I find raves to be more of a mental excursion than an illegal one. 
They are definitely not a big problem for us," concludes Jones.
    *******
  This sounds encouraging to me -- or am I being naive?
  Thanx to my son Colin (hardcore techno fan) for showing me this article.

Subject: How I spent my Connection 2
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Date: Sun, 14 Mar 93 8:33:56 PST
From: "Pete Reiter" <megatest!plethorax!preiter@uu4.psi.com>
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]

This message is to answer all of those cries of where's Pete with the food?

Well, we all know the beginning of the story. The charter oak warehouse was
a bust. I went to Zanzibar's figuring it would be a good place to hang until
those in charge got their stuff together. I thought others might have the same
idea. When I got to Zanzibar's however I found that the music was really bad
pop hip-hop. So I cruised around SOMA for a while and checked the hotline every
once in a while. At 2:15 it hadn't been changed and I was feeling "motivated"
to get out of the car and find a place to spend the night.

The only non-connection choices were Ascend @ the fashion center and Love
American Style/Unification at 16th and Harrison. The fashion center lost..

So I went to 16th and Harrison, payed the obligatory $20, underwent the
obligatory strip search and was in. Inside I found Zak, Mike and a couple of
non-sfraver friends, John and Evelyn. The place was hot, humid and packed.
The crowd was better than expected for the venue (I guess the occaisional
love phaser made it through the search).

I caught the last half of Mark Farina'a set. He seemed to be alternating 
between chicago house, and that deep trance stuff
I love so much. Ernie Munson followed him followed by Jeno, but I didn't hear
much of their sets, cause it was too hot to dance.

Outside there was a chill space set up with its own DJ. Harry Who was on when
I got there, Rick Preston tore it up later on.

Spun was the last DJ on the main dance floor and he tore it up. He finished
the rave hard, no fade, no final song, just one beat left to reverberate 
through the warehouse.


Overall I had a really good time and hope everyone else had just as much fun
wherever they were. When I finally made it home I found a message from Brian
on the answering machine telling me where Connection went to, oh well. At
least I know now.

					Pete  (quietly munching zucchini bread)

From: Bob Ramstad <rramstad@us.oracle.com>
To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU
Cc: boccibob%groovy@us.oracle.com
Subject: Connection II tapes
Reply-To: boccibob%groovy@us.oracle.com


I'm still in the process of checking the DATs, but my best guess right
now is there is 360 minutes (6 hours!) of high quality stuff from
Connection II.  Thanks to all the DJs for performing above and beyond
the call of duty...

I'm also still in the process of sorting out getting cassettes made,
with a variety of companies sending me information.  (CDs require a
minimum pressing of 1000 before they get cost-effective, and I doubt
that 1000 sets could be sold.  Dang.  Besides, it would have to be a 4
CD set, which would be expensive anyway, or I'd have to cut a bunch of
music, which I don't want to do.)

Best guess at this point is that it'll be a 4 90 minute tape set, on
BASF cobalt + tape (type II tape) with Dolby HX pro (better high end).
Best guess on price is $25.  This price includes shipping, but more
importantly, it includes $5 per set to go to Malachy.  I think this is
an important part of this endeavor.  The DJs agreed to let these tapes
be released with the understanding that the sales of each set would
raise $5 for Malachy.  (DJs: I'm planning on tracking you down and
sending you a complimentary set once the tapes are done.)

I will make a real announcement, with more details, soon...  but
thought I should post as I've been getting a few inquiries about
copies...

I could use two bits of help... 1) if anyone has that text typed in
that Ameba gives out about raving, I'm thinking of using it on the J
card... or if anyone else has anything cool that's fairly short and
relevant, feel free to email it my way 2) if anyone out there has
access to gear and knows how to use it to produce composite printer's
film, I'll shortly have specs for the (4 color) J cards, and would
love to have someone work on it -- I've got some ideas for images to
use if you can convert a photo in a book to printers film, but if you
wanted to design something, that would be cool too.

Ground rules on both 1 and 2 is that they not reference anyone living
in any way, they can't reference SFRaves or C2, and I'd prefer that
they don't even reference SF.

Later on,
Bob

Bob Ramstad, Pleasure Seeker
boccibob%groovy@us.oracle.com (preferred) or rramstad@us.oracle.com
"Anything that's worth doing is worth fucking up completely."

	id AA08767; Tue, 16 Mar 93 16:00:37 PST
Received: by stout.cisco.com; Tue, 16 Mar 1993 16:00:36 -0800
From: Trevor Schulze <tschulze@cisco.com>
Message-Id: <199303170000.AA03875@stout.cisco.com>
Subject: White House
To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU (sanfranraves)
Date: Tue, 16 Mar 93 16:00:36 PST
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]

Well, due to the overwhelming response. here it is.

> ------ Forwarded Message
> GETTING INFORMATION TO AND FROM THE WHITE HOUSE
> FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS
> Updated March 12, 1993
> 
> A.  HOW TO SIGN UP FOR ELECTRONIC RELEASES FROM THE WHITE HOUSE: 
> 
> The White House Communications office is distributing press releases over an
> experimental system developed during the campaign.
> 
> You can sign up to receive press releases on this experimental system by using
> the automated computer server.  You will be carried forward onto the system
> that replaces it.  However, it would be appreciated if you used this
> service sparingly at this time.  The present system was not designed to handle
> high levels of message traffic.  In due course, a more powerful system will
> be available.
> 
> You can also find copies of the press releases in certain on-line bulletin
> board groups devoted to discussions of either national politics in general or
> President Clinton in particular.  
> 
> 1.  On USENET/NETNEWS, electronic publications are found on a variety of
>     groups:
> 
>         Direct Distribution
> 
>                 alt.politics.clinton
>                 alt.politics.org.misc
>                 alt.politics.reform
>                 alt.politics.usa.misc
>                 alt.news-media
>                 alt.activism
>                 talk.politics.misc
> 
>         Indirect Distribution
> 
>                 misc.activism.progressive
>                 cmu.soc.politics
>                 assocs.clinton-gore-92 
> 
> 2.  On CompuServe: GO WHITEHOUSE
> 
> 3.  On America Online: keyword WHITEHOUSE or THE WHITEHOUSE or CLINTON
> 
> 4.  On The WELL: type whitehouse
> 
> 5.  On MCI: type VIEW WHITE HOUSE
> 
> 
> If you don't have access to the these accounts or if you would prefer to
> receive the releases via e-mail, then the next section details how to sign up
> for this service.  The server is not set up to answer e-mail letters,
> comments or requests for specific information. To reach this server, send
> e-mail:
> 
> 
> 
>                 to: Clinton-Info@Campaign92.Org
>                 subject: Help
> 
> The server works by reading the subject line of the incoming message and
> taking whatever action that line calls for. If you want to sign up to
> automatically receive press releases, then your subject line would begin with
> the word RECEIVE.  You can then specify what kind of information you are
> interested in receiving. The categories of information are:
> 
> ECONOMIC POLICY
>                         Get releases related to the economy such as budget
>                         news, technology policy review, etc.
> 
> 
> FOREIGN POLICY
>                         Get releases related to foreign policy such as
>                         statements on Bosnian airdrop, Haitian refugee status,
>                         etc.
> 
> 
> SOCIAL POLICY
>                         Get releases related to social issues like National
>                         Service (Student Loan) program, abortion, welfare
>                         reform, etc.
> 
> SPEECHES                    
>                         All speeches made by the President and important
>                         speeches made by other Administration officials.
> 
> NEWS
>                         Transcripts of press conferences released by the White
>                         House Communications office, as well as the
>                         President's remarks in photo ops and other Q&A
>                         sessions.
> 
> ALL                     All of the above
> 
> So, if you wanted to sign up to get releases related to the economy your
> e-mail message would look like this:
> 
>         To: Clinton-Info@Campaign92.Org
>         Subject: RECEIVE ECONOMY
> 
> When you send a signup message to the clinton-info server, it sends you back a
> status message letting you know what distribution streams you are signed up
> for. If you ever want to check on what groups you are signed up for send the
> following message:
> 
> To: Clinton-Info@Campaign92.Org
> Subject: STATUS
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> You can stop receiving e-mail releases by sending a REMOVE message to the
> clinton-info server. The word REMOVE would be followed by whatever
> distribution stream you wanted to drop. If you wanted to stop receiving
> message about the ECONOMY then your mail would look like this:
> 
> To: Clinton-Info@Campaign92.Org
> Subject: REMOVE ECONOMY
> 
> You could substitute SOCIAL, FOREIGN, SPEECHES, NEWS or ALL for ECONOMY in the
> above message and you would be dropped from that distribution list. If you
> send the subject line REMOVE ALL, then you will be taken off the e-mail
> distribution system all together and will not receive further releases of any
> kind.
> 
> You can also ask for help from the automated server.  Send an e-mail query as
> follows:
> 
>         To: Clinton-Info@Campaign92.Org
>         Subject: HELP
> 
> The server will respond by sending you a detailed form that will guide you
> through the process of signing up for the various distribution streams.
> 
> B.  ARE THE WHITE HOUSE PRESS RELEASES BEING ARCHIVED.
> 
> Yes.  Various sites are archiving the press releases.  What follows is an
> incomplete list of some of the sites containing the documents that have
> been released to date.  This FAQ will be updated to reflect new sites as
> they become known.
> 
>          SITE                           DIRECTORY
> 
> 1. SUNSITE.UNC.EDU              /HOME3/WAIS/WHITE-HOUSE-PAPERS
> 2. FTP.CCO.CALTECH.EDU          /PUB/BJMCCALL
> 3. FTP MARISTB.MARIST.EDU
> 4. CPSR.ORG                     /CPSR/CLINTON
> 5. FedWorld BBS                 703-321-8020  8-N-1
> 
> 
> Notes:  The following are notes on how to log in and get
>         information from the above sites.
> 
> 1.      Office FOR Information Technology at University of
>         North Carolina Maintains the full collection of White
>         House electronic release available for search with WAIS.
>         (:source
>         :version 3
>         :database-name "/home3/wais/White-House-Papers" :ip-
>                 address "152.2.22.81"
>         :ip-name "sunsite.unc.edu"
>         :tcp-port 210
>         :cost 0.00
>         :cost-unit :free
>         :maintainer "pjones@sunsite.unc.edu"
> 
> 
>         :description "Server created with WAIS release 8 b5 on  
>                 Feb 27 15:16:16 1993 by pjones@sunsite.unc.edu
>         These are the White House Press Briefings and other
>         postings dealing with William Jefferson Clinton and
>         Albert Gore as well as members of the President's
>         Cabinet and the first lady Hillary Rodham Clinton, 
>         Chelsea, Socks and others in Washington DC. Dee Dee 
>         Meyers and George Stephanopoulos.  Other good words:
>         United States of America, Bill Al Tipper Democrats USA 
>         US These files are also available via anonymous ftp 
>         from sunsite.unc.edu The files of type filename used in 
>         the index were: 
>         /home3/ftp/pub/academic/political-science/whitehouse-
>          papers/1993 ")
>         Folks without WAIS clients or gophers that act as WAIS
>         clients may telnet to sunsite.unc.edu and login as swais 
>         to access this information via WAIS. 
> 
> 2.      No special instructions.
> 
> 3.      The CLINTON@MARIST log files which contain all the official
>         administration releases distributed through the MIT servers
>         are available via anonymous FTP. These logs contain in
>         addition to the official releases, the posts that comprise the
>         ongoing discussion conducted by the list subscribers. 
>         To obtain the logs:
>         FTP MARISTB.MARIST.EDU - the logs are in the CLINTON directory
>         and are named CLINTON LOG9208 thru CLINTON LOGyymm where yymm
>         stands for the current year and month. Problems should be
>         directed to my attention: URLS@MARISTC.BITNET or
>         URLS@VM.MARIST.EDU. 
>         Posted by Lee Sakkas - owner, CLINTON@MARIST
> 
> 4.      Computer Professionals for Social Responsibility is
>         providing all Clinton documents on technology and privacy
>         at the CPSR Internet Library, available via
>         FTP/WAIS/Gopher at cpsr.org /cpsr/clinton (and in other
>         folders as relevant). For email access, send a message
>         with the word "help" at the 1st line of text to
>         listserv@cpsr.org.
> 
> 5.      The White House Forum (GO WHITEHOUSE) on CompuServe is devoted to
>         discussion of the Clinton administration's policies and activities.
>         The forum's library consists of news releases and twice daily media
>         briefings from the White House Office of Media Affairs.  CompuServe
>         members can exchange information and opinions with each other in the
>         17 sections in the forum's message area.  The message board spans a
>         broad range of topics, including international and United Nations
>         activities, defense, health care, the economy and the deficit, housing
>         and urban development, the environment, and education and national
>         service.
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 6.      On America Online the posts are sent to the White House Forum, located
>         in the News & Finance department of the service and accessible via
>         keywords "white house" and "clinton."  The White House Forum on 
> America 
> Online contains the press releases from the White House, divided into the 
> categories "Press Briefings," "Meetings & Speeches," "Foreign Policy," "The 
> Economy," "Technology," "Health Care," and "Appointments." The area features 
> a 
> message board so you can discuss the releases with other AOL members, and a 
> searchable database for easy retrieval of releases in the topic that 
> interests 
> you.
> 
> 7.      MCI Mail users can access daily information on the administration's  
>     
> programs provided by the White House through MCI Mail bulletin boards.  The 
> available boards are: WHITE HOUSE ECONOMIC, WHITE HOUSE FOREIGN,    WHITE 
> HOUSE 
> SOCIAL, WHITE HOUSE SPEECHES and WHITE HOUSE NEWS.  A       listing of these 
> boards can also be obtained by simply typing 
>         VIEW WHITE HOUSE at the COMMAND prompt.
> 
> 
> C.  SENDING E-MAIL TO THE WHITE HOUSE
> 
> The White House e-mail system is under construction.  This is a new project
> and suffers from all of the problems common to a startup operation.  The
> Communications office is currently working on defining what this system will
> do, as well as trying to come up with equipment and staffing to make sure that
> it works.  E-mail messages are currently being printed out and responses
> are being sent out via US Mail.
> 
> Nobody wants this new venture to work more than the staff that has devoted so
> many hours to getting it up and running.  But much time and effort will be
> required before the system is truly interactive.  In the mean time, they will
> need a little patience from the electronic community.  If you send a message
> to the White House, please include a US Post office address for replies.
> 
>         You can send e-mail to the following accounts:
> 
> Compuserve:             75300,3115
>                         GO: WHITE HOUSE         finds White House forum
> 
> America OnLine:         clinton pz
>                         KEYWORD: WHITEHOUSE     finds White House area
> 
> MCI                     TO: WHITE HOUSE
>                         VIEW WHITE HOUSE        views bulletin boards
> 
> Internet:               clinton-hq@Campaign92.Org
>                         75300.3115@compuserve.com
>                         clintonpz@aol.com
> 
> 
> Please send corrections, deletion and additions to this fqa to:
>                 Updates@Clinton92.Org
> 
> 
> ------ End of Forwarded Message
>

>  We had at least two first-time ravers - a twenty-something couple had
> been hanging out in the parking lot when we arrived - they got curious
> as more and more cars showed up. Some ravers invited them to the
> party, and they accepted. They both looked like they were really
> enjoying it!  They must have stayed for about one or two hours.

Yeah, I talked to these folks, it was pretty funny, and made me feel
like quite a renegade... as I get out of my car in the parking lot...

"Hey, uh, hi, I'm (Bill?) and this is (Sharon? Shirley?)... we've been
hanging out and whatever and there hasn't been anyone around... why
all the cars showing up now?"

"Well, if you head down that way a bit, in about a half hour, you'll
see :-)  I'm Bob, nice to meet you.  Want a Blow Pop?"

"Uh, yeah, sure...  What are you guys going to do?  (I open the trunk
of my car, which is full with stuff.)  What's all the stuff for?  Do
you need a hand?"

"We're setting up a sound system down that way.  You should definitely
come check it out."

"A sound system?  How?"

"A generator and about 100 more people should be showing up any time
now :-)"

and on.  They did seem to have a really good time :-)

Bob

	id AA11669; Mon, 15 Mar 93 23:06:24 -0800
From: larryc@netcom.com (Larry Ching)
Message-Id: <9303160706.AA11669@netcom4.netcom.com>
Subject: CONNECTION II : Natural Man-Made High!
To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU
Date: Mon, 15 Mar 93 23:06:23 PST
Cc: prusmack@applelink.apple.com, larryc@netcom.com
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]


 I still have a buzz ... Connection II ( C2 ) will definitely be on my
all-time best rave list! No smart drinks, no video projections, no
fancy chill room - just good music and good people! ( The only special
effect was provided by Lee Fogel in the form of one little strobe light
).

 C2 wandered like a refugee from the original beach site, to the smaller
but dryer Charter Oak warehouse. After only about an hour of it's
starting time, it got closed down by the SFPD for being permit-less.
Recovering from this blow, the resilient organizers of C2 moved it to
the beautiful Berkeley Marina.

 It had been the first time for me at this site - I understand now why
people are so enthused about it. A convenient spot with picnic benches
that's just right for setting up a sound system. A grassy area that's
just the right size for 200 people, with space left over for picnic
blankets and sleeping bags. To chill, there are benches and boulders
along the SF Bay just a stroll away ; and if you're in a climbing mood,
a bushy hillock with some concrete benches and a great view.

 Of course, the view wasn't very good on this particular night, due to
the overcast. From the clouds came a nearly continuous , lazy drizzle -
thankfully, not enough to soak you to the bone or short out the sound
system. We managed to get a plastic tarp over the mixing table, but the
records still got wet ( and, a big "Thank-You !" to all the DJ's that
did C2 , even as their record collections got damper and damper. I hope
you got the vinyl dry as soon as you could - I used to live in Hawaii,
and I know that mildew will grow on records, given enough humidity ).
Actually, it may have helped to cool us off - I don't think anyone was
in danger of heat stroke at all. I was glad to get into dry clothes
afterwards.

 For some reason - call it vibes or second wind or whatever - I wasn't
as tired as I thought I'd be for someone who had been up since 8 AM 
without chemical assistance , not even caffiene. I usually like to zoom 
about the dancefloor at most raves, and the Berkeley site provided 
comparatively unlimited zoom space for me. I was dancing on shoreline 
boulders, and on the hillock trails. If my feet weren't hurting me, it 
would have been perfect. I tried dancing on bare feet , but the cold 
soaked into my feet and discouraged me real quick! That didn't stop some 
folks from barefootin' - I hope they didn't regret it later.

 We had at least two first-time ravers - a twenty-something couple had
been hanging out in the parking lot when we arrived - they got curious
as more and more cars showed up. Some ravers invited them to the party, 
and they accepted. They both looked like they were really enjoying it! 
They must have stayed for about one or two hours.

 The joggers showed up in the morning - for some reason , the site
attracts middle-aged and white-haired health enthusiasts. They didn't
give us a second ( or third ) glance. I offered some of them our left
over oranges , but only one of them took some, leaving me with about
thirty of them.

 One cop car did a spin around the parking lot and left - I guess he was
verifying that we had shut down. That, and the other two visits during
the night, was the sum total of the police presence that night. ( If
"the man" is reading this - thank you ! ).

 And, no little part of the event was meeting people who I had previously 
only knew as email entities. I'll have to get IDs from other folks after
I finally develop the film, as my poor memory for names has screwed me 
again ( although I'll definitely remember which one Dana Watanabe is - 
the folks at our table at the International House Of Pancakes know what 
I'm talking about :-) ). 

 I was glad to have been a part of this event, and I'm especially glad
that we were able to raise some money for Malachy. With better weather
and more luck ( and permits ? ), I hope Connections 3,4,5,6 ... ( some
ludicrous number ) matches the good vibes of this one!


                  Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

					managed to forget your name

Any takers?

Oh, and if you think you might have left something else there, let me know
and i'll look around again next time i'm there (probably sometime this week).

				putting off a longer post
				on the festivities,
				gregg

Subject: Re: GG Park Rave

	The reason the park started so late was because the authorities said
that due to the dampness of the grass, that the party must start a little later, 
after the grass dries up.  Actually, that was only part of the reason.  The 
other reason was that the truck we used to transport the generator didn't show up
until about 1 pm at the rental place.  Since nobody would dare flake twice, I
doubt that the park will be starting late on later dates.  
	Regardless, the park was a great success!  I haven't seen so many happy
people together in a while (probably since I missed Connection II ;) 
It was incredible to see that many people show up on a day that was so gloomy.
I can hardly wait for the sun to come out on sundays to come!

SPRING!!!!!!!!!!  almost.  =-)

happiness to all,

		Tai

From sfraves-request@medisg.Stanford.EDU  Tue Mar 16 21:50:04 1993

	id AA20365; Mon, 15 Mar 93 14:51:02 -0800
Date: Mon, 15 Mar 1993 14:41:25 -0800 (PST)
From: Arthur Chandler <arthurc@sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu>
Subject: GG Park Rave
To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU
Message-Id: <Pine.3.05.9303151425.B17630-b100000@sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII


  Like a simpleton, I took the "get there at 11:00" notice literally -- or
almost so.  When I drove by at noon, there was nothing but wet grass and a
sullen sky.  So my vanload left for the Richmond for lunch.  When we
returned after 1:00, there was equipment, a small crowd, but no power
generator.  A bit later, though, the generator appeared, fired up, and the
music started.  It was slow going to begin with -- though I did my best to
jumpstart the energy with my diabolo and juggling balls.  Saw Niels,
chatted, and then went off to do some serious juggling at the other end of
the park.  Returned about 5:15 to find the energy level jacked up several
notches, wih lots of dancing and a very good DJ (didn't catch his name). 
Everyone seemed to be hoping Jeno would show, but didn't (at least by the
time I left).  Ran into Derek, who smiled benevolently.
  "They don't dress as brightly as the hippes did," said my wife with a
dismissive sweep over the crowd.
  "Maybe it's just the overcast sky," suggested Derek.
  Highlight: a fellow with a ring in his nose hawking candy and
irridescent roses from a holder slung around his neck like the old
"cigarette girls" devices they used in night clubs in the '40s.
  Poor taste: a dude with a supersoaker squirting the ladies in a pathetic
attempt to get attention.
  But all in all, like, groovy, man (I never left the 60s.....)

drop, preferably somewhere between Mountain View and Redwood City, tho

Etc for example) rent boxes without needing ID or a name for the
owner?

outfit?  Would want to pay cash in advance for three months, low
volume, probably less than 10 calls / month.

greatly appreciated, a good friend asked me for this info, and as a
newcomer to the area myself, I couldn't really help him.

the list... (and apologies to all who consider this an inappropriate

This is a repost of the message I sent yesterday -- please ignore the
identical copy you'll get when soda comes back up.

------------

Niels brags:

>Just thought I'd try to be the first to post....

Damn! I knew I should've posted before taking that nap! ;^)

After 1-1/2 false starts, we proved beyond doubt that nobody outvibes
SFR -- that was a GREAT (if wet) party!!!  The third-eye-mounted
you-know-whats were standard equipment this time. There wasn't an
unfriendly, no eye-contact, bad attitude face in the house -- unless you
count that Berkeley cop who briefly joined us, but even he was won over
in the end by our vibe and once again Geoff's powers of charm, logic and
persuasion ;^)  THANX, GEOFF!!!

Music was great -- Moonpup turned in a strong set against fierce odds
(like a slippery slipmat), as did Lee, Jon D., BLURrrr (wish he could've
played longer.)  Too bad we missed a chance to hear Pat's acid jazz set,
but as breakfast was a no-show (you guys gave up on us for 16th &
Harrison???  How could you?! ;^) and the equipment was fighting a losing
battle against moisture, we were forced to bail at 8 am. Scott Hardkiss's
set at Charter Oak was first-class too, what little of it I heard.

Made lots of cool new friends last night -- the SoCal crew (Tamara,
Joachim, Dana, and Bryan), the East Coast contingent (Inhuman, Taylor,
Dave (?) from Mindvox in NY), the Davis faction (Laine, Matt, Tim, and
Roxanne) and a couple of recent non-netter transplants from New
Hampshire, Lee and Michael who've plugged right into the SF scene. And
some locals, Betsy, Ravi, and ... ? (I'm know I'm forgetting a few :( )

Joachim and Dana's insanely huge undulating bubbles rank among the best
visuals I've ever seen at a rave.

Having 27 of us invade the IHOP afterwards for breakfast was a stroke of
poetic terrorism par excellence! They never knew what hit them (namely
Susie's goopy slime...)  Then the ENDLESS group photo session...

My only criticism was that we probably should have changed the info line
before leaving the city -- unfortunately Gregg didn't know the secret
code to do this. We might not have lost Pete, Mike, Zak, Julie and many
others, although we possibly made the Marina a safer bet by delaying the
announcement (even that's open to debate...) I am *so* glad I finally
had a chance to experience that most excellent site (even if the view of
the bridges and city was fogged-out :( ).

BTW, after expenses we raised on the order of $200 for Malachy's
recovery -- Brian will have the final tally later.  Thanks for pitching
in, everyone! And thanks to the hard-working crew, especially Brian, for
perservering and not cracking under pressure, and most of all...

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> HAPPY BIRTHDAY, SFR!!! <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<

You are the most beautiful virtual community on the planet, along with
our cousins across the country!

P.S. I think we should organize a role-playing workshop so Geoff can
transmit some of his skills to us. I tried my best to apply his
technique at Charter Oak, but only seemed to made the situation there
worse :(. Of course, it seems they already had it in for that place...

P.P.S. Laine - make sure you e-mail me your address, net and postal.

----____----____--__--__--__--__-_-_-_-_-_-__--__--__--__--____----____----
         MykL G             Look to the future!      mcg@netcom.com
____----____----__--__--__--__--_-_-_-_-_-_--__--__--__--__----____----____

> But Connection II was successful
> 	once it got started (even though it was wet).  Did anybody
> 	go to GG Park afterwards? 

The GG Park party seemed to pick up right where Connections2.0 left
off.  Where Connections was a intimate and magical family gathering, 
the GG Park party was a spiritual tribal affair.  The Vibe was 
incredible, with all of the best elements of the SF house scene present. 
A strong contingent of sfravers added ammunition to an all out luv
phaser war from which no one was safe.  

It was set up closer to the street in full view of public.  What PR!
Curious bystanders seemed mesmerized.  One very straight-looking couple 
with a young boy put their blanket down next to us and just soaked it up.  
I indroduced myself to the father and asked him what he thought.  Looking
over at the field of dancers, he seemed to be hypnotized, "I like it." he
simply said.  They stayed for 2 hours. An eldery impovershed-looking man 
pushing his cart full of bottles and cans hits a bump sending it crashing 
to the ground.  Immediately he is smothered by ravers who rush to his aid.  

Maybe it's just the beginning of Spring, or maybe it's the beginning of 
the next step in the evolution of the entire Universe.  Whatever it is, I 
am convinced that the special spirit of the SF rave scene is well 
established and is here to stay for a while.  

What a weekend!

- leg of eel

From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.sf.ca.us>
Message-Id: <199303150735.AA08093@well.sf.ca.us>
To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU
Subject: UHF/Portland

Well, the Big Event in Portland last night was a bit of a letdown, but
no surprise in that really.  It was in a converted warehouse in southeast
Portland near the river that used to be the Euphoria live music place
(later went through many reincarnations such as sports bar, under-18 dance
place, etc.).  It's got carpets all over the place and an old disco-type
dance floor with the multi-colored squares.  Kinda hard to imagine raving
in a rec-room for us hardened vets of the SoMa plywood acres ;-)

I was working late so I didn't arrive until about 3:30.  only caught Markie
who spun through til just after 5, so I can't report on Bones or others
(if they were there).  Jeno was smart and stayed in SF, I gather -- better
to save him up for a better event.  Markie was noodling along when I arrived
but flew up to cruise altitude around 4 am, so I got in a good hour plus
in The Zone.  Right at 5 he quit, then did a short ragga-oriented encore,
and that was it.  The afterparty moved over to Park Ave but I wasn't into
waiting for some kind of spark to light there after my last couple of
relatively uninspiring trips there.  

The crowd was about one-half rave vets and about half college-type partyers,
from what I could guess, but everyone was mellow in that typical portland
way.  No booze being served.  

A pretty good time overall but frankly, m'dear, I'd rather be at the Marina.

Subject: Connection II <---> East 2 West
From: inhuman@mindvox.phantom.com (Inhuman)
Comments: Feed Your Head
Message-Id: <4T1F1B3w165w@mindvox.phantom.com>
Date: Mon, 15 Mar 93 02:47:38 EST
Organization: [Phantom Access] / the MindVox system

        Well, after a stop in Cleveland while Dulles airport tried to 
figure out how to get their runway lights working again, I'm back in 
mundane ol' Washington, DC.  It's hard to believe that about 18 hours ago 
I was looking out over San Francisco bay, dancing with all my new sfraver 
friends.

        I started out the night taking a bus down Haight St to CalaFoods 
with a friend who wanted to see what raves were like.  We got there and 
got our little instruction/direction cards.  A friendly guy offered us a 
ride there (sorry, I can't remember your name now!).  Once we got there, 
there were cop cars outside and the rave was getting shut down.  
Bummer... I quickly spotted Susie, though and got introduced to all you 
sfravers.  From there, Mike gave us a ride to CalaFoods and then to the 
Berkeley Marina where the rave was being moved.

        We got there and everything was already set up!  That was fast!  
I was expecting something along the lines of the FMR, which took hours to 
set up.  After some initial problems with the needle, things got 
moving.... "And away we go!"  That was some cool hip-hop style stuff at 
the beginning.  I liked it.

        After an hour or two, though, I got really tired and went and sat 
down on Susie's blanket.  I didn't know I could fall asleep with my head 
on my knees, but I did for quite some time.  When I woke up with a sore 
butt, it was light out and this song that I had heard at the FMR was 
coming on and I liked it a lot.  I got up and I was really cold and 
started dancing.  I got really warm quickly and immediately fell into the 
vibe.  I wish this had happened earlier, but there was a nice stretch of 
about an hour where I was so blissfully happy...  Joachim was up on this 
hill making giant bubbles.  Seagulls were flying around.  It was so foggy 
and misty.  It was really wonderful...

        And then IHoP afterwards... That was fun.  Who would have thought 
those pancakes could have tasted so good?  What a cozy morning....  You 
SF ravers really have it together.  It's going to be hard to go to 
anouther hardcore east coast rave after that.  I guess the only option is 
to create our own scene... there's some promise of evolution.

        Thanks Mike & Brian for the rides!  Thanks Mike again for the 
vision tapes which I am eagerly looking forward to.  Thanks Chris for the 
Renu-You which will brighten up the sunshine microrave here in DC.  
Thanks everyone for your company and smiles and hugs and stuff!  
Hopefully I'll make it back out there again sometime!

....sorry for the massive cross posting, but I'm too egotistical to only 
send it to one list.  :-)

Michael                         |  "I've begun to wonder if we wouldn't
(inhuman@mindvox.phantom.com)   |   also regard spelunkers as desperate
                                |   criminals if AT&T owned all the
...trance form...trance send... |   caves."   --John Perry Barlow
