From: mcg@netcom.com (Tiamat the Chaos-Ocean)
Subject: Re: connection2 mothership has landed!!

Niels brags:

> Just thought I'd try to be the first to post....

Damn!  I knew I should've posted before taking that nap!  ;^)

After 1-1/2 false starts, we proved beyond doubt that nobody outvibes
SFR -- that was a GREAT (if wet) party!!!  The third-eye-mounted
you-know-whats were standard equipment this time.  There wasn't an
unfriendly, no eye-contact, bad attitude face in the house -- unless you
count that Berkeley cop who briefly joined us, but even he was won over
in the end by our vibe and once again Geoff's powers of charm, logic and
persuasion  ;^)  THANX, GEOFF!!!

Music was great -- Moonpup turned in a strong set against fierce odds
(like a slippery slipmat), as did Lee, Jon D., BLURrrr (wish he could've
played longer.)  Too bad we missed a chance to hear Pat's acid jazz set,
but as breakfast was a no-show (you guys gave up on us for 16th & Harrison???
How could you?!  ;^) and the equipment was fighting a losing battle against
moisture, we were forced to bail at 8 am.  Scott Hardkiss's set at Charter
Oak was first-class too, what little of it I heard.

Made lots of cool new friends last night -- the SoCal crew (Tamara,
Joachim, Dana, and Bryan), the East Coast contingent (Inhuman, Taylor,
Dave (?) from Mindvox in NY), the Davis faction (Laine, Matt, Tim, and
Roxanne and their delicious water-bottle) and a couple of recent non-netter
transplants from New Hampshire, Lee and Michael who've plugged right into
the SF scene.  And some locals, Betsy, Ravi, and ... ?  (I'm know I'm
forgetting a few  :( )

Joachim and Dana's insanely huge undulating bubbles rank among the best
visuals I've ever seen at a rave.

Having 27 of us invade the IHOP afterwards for breakfast was a stroke
of poetic terrorism par excellence!  They never knew what hit them (namely
Susie's goopy slime...)  Then the ENDLESS group photo session...

My only criticism was that we probably should have changed the info line
before leaving the city -- unfortunately Gregg didn't know the secret code
to do this.  We might not have lost Pete, Mike, Zak, Julie and many
others, although we possibly made the Marina a safer bet by delaying the
announcement (even that's open to debate...)  I am *so* glad I finally had
a chance to experience that most excellent site (even if the view of
the bridges and city was fogged-out  :( ).

BTW, after expenses we raised on the order of $250 for Malachy's recovery
-- Brian will have the final tally later.  Thanks for pitching in, everyone!
And thanks to the hard-working crew, especially Brian, for perservering and
not cracking under pressure, and most of all...

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> HAPPY BIRTHDAY, SFR!!! <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<

You are the most beautiful virtual community on the planet, along with our
cousins across the country!

P.S.   I think we should organize a role-playing workshop so Geoff can
transmit some of his skills to us.  I tried my best to apply his technique
at Charter Oak, but only seemed to made the situation there worse  :(.
Of course, it seems they already had it in for that place...

P.P.S.  Laine - make sure you e-mail me your address, net and postal.

----____----____--__--__--__--__-_-_-_-_-_-__--__--__--__--____----____----
         MykL G             Look to the future!      mcg@netcom.com

From: pashdown@slack.sim.es.com (Pete Ashdown)
Message-Id: <9303151926.AA15118@slack>
Subject: connection 2
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu (SF Raves)
Date: Mon, 15 Mar 1993 12:26:33 -0700 (MST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL21]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1886      

> neither rain nor sleet nor pain in the butt police officers can stop
> the mighty sf-raves posse.

It sure was a wacked up weekend.  A local clothing shop here threw a garage
party.  Some straight-edgers sprayed pepper gas on the crowd and almost
started a stampede.  A friend had trouble breathing, she had the liquid all
over her face.  Thankfully, we found out who did it and had a chat with their
parents (the two of them were underage).  They're going to be banned from all
future events.  What really bothered me is the fact that they call themselves
"straight-edge" yet did such a violent act for no reason.  Hypocrite bastards.

Then the cops came a few hours later.

Pig: "Party's over folks, get out."
Me: "What is the reason?"
Pig: "THE PARTY IS OVER."
Me: "Is there a reason?"
Pig: "Are you going to get out, or am I going to have to haul you off to
jail?"
Me: "What's the charge?"
Pig: "Disorderly conduct."
Me: "Asking questions is disorderly conduct?"
Pig: *dirty silent look*

Later

Me: "We're any warnings served tonight?"
Pig: "We do not have to give a warning."
Me: "Yes, but that is not what I'm trying to establish.  This officer just
stated that you haven't been here previously tonight, but you just stated this
is your third time here.  When I file the complaint, I would like to know if
any warnings had been served."
Pig: "We do not have to give a warning."
Me: "Yes, I realize that YOU DO NOT HAVE TO GIVE A WARNING.  But DID YOU GIVE
ANY WARNINGS TONIGHT?"
Pig: "WE DO NOT FUCKING HAVE TO GIVE A WARNING!"
Pig in car: "Do we need to take someone downtown?"
Pig: "No, we've got some sort of illiteracy problem here."
Me: "What is your name officer?"

The jerk hesitated then gave me his name.  I'm writing a formal complaint
today.  I've never dealt with bastards on that level.  I nearly thought the
guy would billy club me just for asking him questions.

Yeah, so the night got off to a slow start...I got to Charter Oak just in time to see Brian getting his ID taken down by our friends in blue (actually five cars worth...you'd think they were busting a crack house...do i smell bacon??)..anyhow,it was good to get a chance to say hi to everyone hanging outside the warehouse...so myself and the never-say-die possee went to lyons, downed gallons of coffee, and finally dashed off to berkely in fits of excitement...yeah, the marina is great place..too bad we lost a bit of the crowd  by the time things got going, but it was great..we had the tent set up, but it was such a high just watching people grooving in the morning (strobe) light that i opted to get wet over hiding from the rain...john and moonpup, the only ones i can remember spinning, were cool, of course...also the huge bubbles floating around were great--little orbs of shimmering colors floating in and out of our dancing madness...all in all a big hug/pat on the back to Br!
ian for not giving up on the night
 and making things go on....till the end...peace
					aaron

Hm, glad to see everyone's really pleased about
Connection... I thought it was interesting, but I can't
really say I was super-psyched about the affair... 

I guess that in general I think we can do better... we
should've had back-up locations planned in advance to avoid
the necessity of things like re-grouping at Cala Foods.
If we'd gotten the word out a bit more smoothly about the
changes then we might've gotten more than 100 people and
$200 dollars for Malachi.  

It would've been cool if we could've left some personnel
behind at each abandoned location sending people on to the
latest connection.  I know it's kind of a lousy job, and
Ravi put in quite a bit of time on this, but a friend of
mine showed up later at the beach, and she says she just
wound up hanging around with a bunch of other lost ravers.
I imagine the problem at Charter Oaks may have been worst...
someone else was tellig me they "woke up someone sleeping
inside who was really pissed" trying to find out what was
going on. 

A detail I found confusing: I wanted to give someone the
info number, but it turned out that for some reason the
sfraves number in Derek's latest list is out of date.  I'd
never realized it, because I didn't really need the
info number, myself.

Subject: cII DISCOnection

fuck.  I wanted to be at CII so bad, and did alot to try and be there, but
it wasn't to be.... my karma must be real low...

It looked good on Friday when Mark and I had headed over to the site just to 
hang out and chill when we ran across all the sfravers who were gonna check
it out that night.  We hadn't checked mail or anything, just coincidence.  We
said hi and left since we had already been there for about 2 hours hiking and
stuff, but felt the energy of the next evening looming.  We were psyched.
So Saturday rolls around, no word from anyone, and Mike and I head out for the
site at around 10pm.  We park at the bottom of the hill and walk up only to
find out that it has been canceled, head over to the Charter Oak warehouse.  I
told Mike that I knew it'd be busted, but what the hell, let's go.  We called
everyone we knew and told them about the fiasco and headed over.  Got there,
saw all you friendly types, felt psyched and hung out for a little bit.  I
left to go pick up friends, come back, and the place is crawling with cops.
We leave, go to a friends house, call the number, nothing.  It was getting late,
like around 2:15 or so, and we HAD to go somewhere, if you know what I mean.
So we went to Love American Style.  Oops.
Scene was all gangster.  Bare chests, tattoos of dead homies's names, all that
shit.  Not too negative, just intimidating.  Saw Pete, cooled it with him for
awhile, and just got rocked out by the Dj lineup.  Packed like you wouldn't
believe, and HOT.  Had fun anyway, despite the 20 buck throwdown.  Place shut
down at 6:00, and we went to go eat.  I then went home and slept....
woke up at 1:00, went to the Park, saw Niels and Jackie hanging out, no music.
Talked and relaxed.  Didn't actually move a dancing muscle the entire afternoon.
Music started, was good, Carlos is so cool.  Saw Taxi and kicked it with him 
for the rest of the day until 5:00 when it was drizzling and I wasn't really
in the mood for moisture.  What a cool event!  i will go to this always.

Well, I hope it works out better for everyonenext time.  I vote for Bonny Doon
all the way for whatever comes next.

Peae
Peace
Zak

We got to the golf course at 4'ish and found out that Connection got
moved or cancelled.  Next we hit 16th & Harrison which looked to be
populated by bad-ass kids and fading fast, so we decided to chill and
then go to Afterlife at the DNA.  Afterlife was fun, good tunes and
a good crowd.  It started getting crowded around 9 and we split for food
around 11.  Dropped by Marx Meadow but found it wet and empty.
Maybe next time...

From: Bob Ramstad <rramstad@us.oracle.com>
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: C2
Reply-To: boccibob%groovy@us.oracle.com


Quick summary: (I'm still recovering, so I'll leave the gory details
to someone else...)  Due to rain, the location was shifted to Charter
Oak.  Mark was concerned, but thought that we'd be OK if we kept
things pretty small.  Well, we had set up and Scott Hardkiss had been
spinning for a little less than an hour, the vibe was pretty strong,
and then the cops came.  They were pretty unreasonable.  Two things I
heard were "anyone left inside in 30 seconds will be arrested" and "we
have to decide if we're going to confiscate the equipment or not".
Both without any legal legs to stand on, it seems, too.

In an amazingly organized fashion, the planner type people and the
hardcore went to Cala Foods, the original map point, in the Haight and
discussed options.  The Berkeley Marina was settled on pretty quickly,
mainly due to a desire to get the f*ck out of SF county.  The hotline
message wasn't updated until we were there and set up and knew things
would happen...

and happen they did!  Excellent sets from Moonpup, Lee and Blur, lots
of different styles of music and all, and Jon Drukman deserves a medal
of DJ honor for spinning for about 40 minutes with one turntable (!)
while someone went to get a needle -- Jon also dealt with the worst
part of the rain, it seemed to me.  It seemed that everyone had
exceptional willingess to just deal with the situation and have a good
time.

"Boy, it's starting to sprinkle a bit.  Shouldn't you guys shut down?"

"Ahhh, yeah, we'll probably shut down if something blows up."

I had a great time, and great to see some of you again, and meet
others of you...  (and I really love to think that we now have a **
great ** spot that's unused for the next event!  one nice side effect
of all the activity)

Bob Ramstad, Pleasure Seeker
boccibob%groovy@us.oracle.com (preferred) or rramstad@us.oracle.com
"Anything that's worth doing is worth fucking up completely."

well hello all...i'm haing an absolute blissful time here on the west coast..
i could talk for hours.. obviously.. but, this post is about the rave last
night.. my first west coast rave..


like my usual rave posts..it's hard to sum it up.. and remember it in one
piece...

but...compared to the skating rink, warehouse , etc.. raves out east this one
was....

outside
in the rain (blisssss!!!)
in a clearing
near a hill of flowers


on the coast...

with rocks and waves... and fog.. and fog beeps (sorta like a fog horn.. but
it beeped)..

it was rather beautiful...

the music really wasn't very different than what they play out east..like i
thought i would be...there was no hardcore.. and no breakbeat...

just trance.. (.lots of beautiful trance) and housey trance.. and progressive
house...the music was amazing....all djs i have never heard before...

john drukman, jay (?), dave kelly.. and moonpup....wow on all of those guys..
wow.
wow.
wow.


it was a small, totally underground (and illegal) rave...witha  small
turnout...cozy small.. a couple hundred tops(?)..

i met lots of sf-ravers and experienced much of the same big happy family-
ness that we have out east...everyone was realllllly cool.. and i was very
happy to meet you all..you really made my visit completely worth it...now 
there are more friends, more faces to login names.. and well.. more love all
around...

the rave in the rain was so nice..i've always loved rain...and this was just
so magical....

mm..

well.. i don't wanna take up too much space here.. and it's hard to sum it up.
comparisons to east coast raves would be dumb.. 'cos it's just different..
no better..no worse.. just different..i had a GREAT time...


here's leah to say a few words:

god do I love the marina.... it makes me so happy.... 

I was happy to begin with -  I knew that no matter what, I would have a 
great time.  after all, look at all the wonderful people I got to meet.  
to start out with, taylor is here, which is wonderful in itself.  and I
finally got to meet joachim, inhuman, dana, tamara, bryan, blur, susie,
derek, ovid, (uh oh - I'm having trouble remembering everyone) and I got
to see so many people I hadn't seen in forever (hi and *hugs* to all and
I'm sorry if I forgot lots of names... brain damage =)  meeting and seeing
everyone made the night.  then we went to the marina.

it was so amazing to see everyone working together and setting up and being
a family - I love that.  no one grumbled, everyone smiled... =)  the music
was fantastic.  jon started things out right (what a guy - he can make things
happen with only one turntable! =) and played some soooper dope shit.  then
moonpup came on and totally amazing stuff (taylor thinks he's great).  then
it was lee and oh my god what the hell can I say about that set.  all the music was great, but it was his set that completely blew me away.  the trance just
took my brain out fucked it all up and put it in backwards.  it was the
perfect music for that time period- I had amazing energy (anyone else notice
that?=) and I was sooooo happy.  (I couldn't dance much in the beginning but
that was when I really got going.)  all I can say is wow.  thank you... and
dave spun some wild stuff - it's just too bad he had tsunami action on the
turntables.... I still loved his music.

the rain was funky and the fog was soo cool too.... we couldn't even see the
city.  I found out that I am insane (hee brian =) but in a good way.  I like
that.  when it was over we all piled into the ihop on university.  there were
28 of us... it was so much fun!!!  we really are one big happy family... it
made me feel all warm... then I got hyper and we all know what that means.
(hey, anyone want a rooti tooti shake yer booty? =)  it was sad to say good-bye
to everyone, but I know I'll see you all again.

again - sorry to any one who I met and didn't mention....  and to everyone
who I did see and talk to... *hugs*  *****BIG HUGS!!!***** (heh joachim =)
I love you all!

always, leah



taylor back here:

this is getting WAY long.. but.. i just wanted to end by saying thank you
to everyone, especially brian, for setting htis uop... and introducing me to 
the sf rave scene.  i really loved it.. and i REALLY appreciate your friendli-
ness and love and it was just great..

thanks again...really.

:)

love to everyone..

hugs to everyone..

and east coasters.. come out here and check this out..

:)


peace.

>>taylor.808

between Charter Oaks and the Marina, but I met some folks at C 1.99
briefly, too briefly. I'm a recent (and hopefully not temporary)
transplant from Chicago -- where my husband must stay until we save
enough money to move -- so I'm really looking forward to many days of
happy dancing to fill the empty space inside. I promise not to lurk any
longer if you promise to dance with me till dawn.

urg.

After shgowing up at ten and being informed that we were not using the 
legion beach anymore, zak and I scurried (after making a billion calls
to tell poeple to go to Charter Oak) to Charter Oak and enjoyed it
for awhile...I guess it is safe to assume that some cop is on the new, or
at least getting the calendar...I wish they would quickly get a life and 
start busting bull shit parties like the one we ended up at (we ddin't
know that conection was moved....we called the number but at that time 
tehre was no change...we went to Love American Style, more aptly
named Hate w/Attitude Bile...more gangster kinds than ever...what is
the deal?  When I was 14 I couldn't stay out all night...
lame lame lame
sound was good...space was trippy, but I was too bummed by all the nasty
kids glaring at me for some reasn or another...about a million kids
wtih little blinking red lights too...jeez...

anyway..I hope all had a good time whatever they did...
Apparently the AIDS danceathon raised over a million dollars in five hours...
my friend was all up on that...I was thinking what some real ravers coould
raise in one NIGHT...

grumpy and bumpy in a finals week,
mike

From: Derek Yu <derek@ocf.berkeley.edu>
Message-Id: <199303170847.AA04349@lightning.berkeley.edu>
To: -v@lightning.berkeley.edu, sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: C2


this has to be the best rave i have been to since i got back from NYC during
winter break...  the energy was so intense that even non-ravers could not help 
but be mesmirized by it..  (much like that Berkeley police officers that came-
are you are out there> thanks for keeping the vibe alive)

the light rain was great.. it was just so refreshing having that misty rain 
cool you down.. and it was a good thing we got out of SF b/c i heard it was raining much harder out there...

i had a pretty nightmarish time getting to C2 too.. i went to the Beach site
in SF first and i was totally lost..  i must of spent 1.5 hours there just looking for it..  it was lucky i ran into a few fellow ravers who directed us the right way..  if you are reading this- thanks for making the night possible..
so it was back to Berkeley and i did not arrive there until 2:30..  i was
at first drowsy but as i neared the site, my adrenaline started pumping as that
music starting getting into my head..  i was zooming on the vibe and music 
before i even got to the dance area...

what made this rave so special was the people i met.. it was my first chance to meet so many SF Ravers..  I like to extend my greetings and gratitude to Leah,
Brian, Mykl, Derek, Cindy, and Pat..  :)  = and to all those i cannot remember.
just those happy, smiling familiar faces that will be forever etched in my mind.

keep the vibe alive...

**********DEREK************

We definitely got the last laugh on this matter.  Devin and Greg went and
looked up the ordinances for Salt Lake City regarding the way the police are
supposed to react to a party.  THEY ARE REQUIRED TO SERVE A WRITTEN WARNING
BEFORE RETURNING TO BUST IT UP.  Keep in mind that the cops were telling us
that it was completely optional.  I've written a complaint and the people who
threw the garage party have written one as well.

We've got a copy of the ordinance to keep by the door now.  I wouldn't be
surprised if San Francisco (this is republican Utah we're talking about) has
something similar.  Go to your local library and look up the ordinances!
There's nothing a cop hates worse than someone who knows the law better than
they do.

From: Bob Ramstad <rramstad@us.oracle.com>
To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU, ne-raves@gnu.ai.mit.edu, dcraves@american.edu
Subject: ** C2 tape announcement **
Reply-To: boccibob%groovy@us.oracle.com


** Connection II cassette ordering info **

DJs: Scott Hardkiss, Jon Drukman, Moonpup, Lee, BLURrrr

345 minutes (almost 6 hours!) of music on 4 BASF cobalt + (type II)
tapes, recorded with Dolby HX pro.  Mastered direct from the mixing
board to DAT at 48 khz, then professionally duplicated, boxed with a
full 4 color insert card and shrinkwrapped... suitable for gift
giving...  :-)

There have been some very strong reviews of the music played at this
event...  and the master DATs sound great.

$5 from each set will be donated to Malachy, a SF rave promoter who
was involved (as a passenger) in an automobile accident after the last
Full Moon Rave.  He has extensive hospital bills and no insurance.
The DJs have agreed to the release of this material with the
understanding that $5 per set would go directly to benefit Malachy.

To order, send $25 cash per set, in a security envelope or wrapped in
carbon paper to:

Bob Ramstad
P.O. Box 390931
Mountain View CA  94039-0931

Include a LEGIBLE return shipping address on a separate piece of paper
inside the envelope.  

If you have email access and would like email verification of the
receipt of your funds and email status updates, send mail to
c2%groovy@us.oracle.com like this:

To: c2%groovy@us.oracle.com
Subject: tape order
---------------------------
1 set
jane@likethis.nyc.ny.us
Jane Raver
988 Moby Dr
New York, NY  02139

The address given ** must ** match the shipping address included with
the payment.

Wholesale inquiries (purchases of more than 20 sets) can also be sent
to the PO box above, or emailed to me at boccibob%groovy@us.oracle.com
(preferred) or rramstad@us.oracle.com.

For everything to work out right, it's ** imperative ** that you place
your order as soon as you can... if sufficient orders are not received
by April 15th, I may be forced to refund everyone's money and withdraw
this offer.  

Professional duplication and printing takes time, and also have
minimum quantity requirements.  The tapes will be shipped out by the
end of May at worst, and hopefully earlier.

I look forward to hearing from each and every one of you!  Peace.

Bob Ramstad, Pleasure Seeker
boccibob%groovy@us.oracle.com (preferred) or rramstad@us.oracle.com
"To rave is to affirm."

worth the $20 just to hear him..

sven vath, the guy who runs harthouse records, is spinning too, and while 
i am not a fan of much hardtrance stuff (except hardfloor) he could get 
interesting..

XDZebra Review #25

        Addiction
        266 Delmar Ct.
        Salt Lake City, UT 84101-1817

When in Utah call the T A S T E hotline 801-461-3375.

Trying to find these releases?  Try Ear/Rational Music:
FAX 805/893-8553, Phone 805/564-4949, email angst%cs@hub.ucsb.edu

Back issues are available from me by mail or by ftp'ing to soda.berkeley.edu.
They're in the pub/sfraves/music directory.

This is all my opinion.  Flames against a review are pretty pointless, so
don't bother.  Let me know if you have any other comments though.

The number next to the index is the "dance factor". 5 = high, 1 = low

XDZebra Reviews may be reproduced without permission under one condition,
they remain intact and unchanged.  If you publish this in print, mail me a
copy via "Addiction".

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Review #25 Contents:
Compilation 1
Psychick Warriors ov Gaia: Obsidian
From Our Minds To Yours Vol. 2
Drome: Anachronism
D-Shake: Nite & Day
Exquisite Corpse: Reassembling Reality
Probe Volume 1
Vicious Vinyl Techno-Rave Compilation


Compilation 1
Project Style: PK 08/01 (FAX +49-69/450464)
1   5   07:45 Deltraxx: Altered States (Unfused & Tuned)
2   4   06:39 Limelight: Limelight (Holy Guitar Mix)
3   4   06:07 Subsequence: Invocation (Dance 4 Trance Mix)
4   5   06:17 Hearts of Space: With a Medium Into Trance (Drop Out Mix)
5   4   06:07 SynSyl: Breakout II
6   5   05:23 4Voice: Music Hypnotizes (Hypnotizing Mix)
7   4   08:27 Escape: Escape to Earth
8   4   06:36 Sextant: Drug Oriented Society
9   2   09:49 Silence: Santur

Comments:  One of the oddest compilations I've purchased.  It looks as if
someone named Pete Namlook in Frankfurt gathered several of his favorite
producers together and thus put out a compilation of his favorite music.  The
whole package is very homebrew, but what is amazing is the fact that it
contains an astounding array of trance.  Probably the best use of etherial
vocals I've heard is presented by Deltraxx.  Limelight and Subsequence aren't
too shabby with the medium either.  All of the tracks manage to stay trancey
with a driving rhythm, except for "Santur" by Silence which is more Arabesque
ambience.

Summary: 9/10.  Namlook states that if they ever has to compromise, he'll shut
down the label.  I'm anxious to see what the future brings.


Psychick Warriors ov Gaia: Obsidian
Kk-Records: KK090mcd
1   4   20:31 Obsidian (Deconstructure)
2   5   06:09 Patience (First Step)
3   4   08:49 Challenge (Kala Mix)

Comments: PWOG starts to worry world record holders The Orb with a twenty
minute remix of "Obsidian" from their album, "Ov Biospheres and Sacred
Grooves".  Nothing really new in style here for the Warriors.  Exemplrary
tribal rhythms with a slow as tar buildup is what the title track is about,
and it sure feels good.  "Patience" ironically jumps into the groove
relatively quick, and as a result comes off as the most pumping track on the
single.  Last "Challenge" is immediate, but a lot deeper toned than
"Patience".

Summary: 9/10.  I'm not sure if Cargo has picked this up domestically, but you
do get a lot of time with this single, even at an import price.


From Our Minds To Yours Vol. 2
Plus 8/Plus 8 Europe: PLUS8022CD
1   4   06:16 Speedy J: Spikkels
2   3   05:46 Psyance: Gates of Heaven
3   3   05:13 V.F.T: Location
4   3   04:24 G-Man: Bio-Fidelic
5   2   07:24 F.U.S.E: Xntrik
6   4   06:38 V-Room: V-Shaped
7   5   05:53 Gary 7: Let The Circle
8   4   05:03 Sysex: Dallas
9   5   04:07 Sysex: Fever
10  3   04:31 Cybersonik: Red Alert

Comments: A slight improvement over Vol. 1.  I especially enjoy the tracks at
the beginning.  "Spikkels" is the best out of the lot, Speedy J has definitely
shown that his trance is better than his hardcore recently.  "Gates of Heaven"
is simplistic, but moderately nice.  "Location" is deep and moody, its rhythm
line is almost out of place though.  Things start to turn with G-Man though.
Random bleeps, pounding beat, and nothing new, sort of a transition between
the beginning trance to the ending hardcore.  The rest of the tracks are
fairly standard Plus 8 hardcore.  Gary 7's "Let The Circle" is very ripping
with a beat that threatens to bust cinderblock.  Closing things off, Sysex
gives a large hunk of sampled _Alien_ in "Dallas" which leaves you wondering
what their motive was.  "Fever" is fierce, but reminds me a lot of Moby's
harder stuff.  Last "Red Alert" by Cybersonik is pathetic, must have been
thrown together in an afternoon.

Summary: 7/10. There are a few better tracks than Vol. 1, but there are two
tracks in particular which are just lame.


Drome: Anachronism
Pulse Soniq: SR9224
1   4   05:27 Optimism
2   4   06:55 Dreams
3   3   06:41 9to1
4   5   06:15 Drugs
5   3   05:39 Target
6       00:52 Tele...
7   2   04:00 Scanners
8   2   06:24 Disposition
9   3   04:03 M.O.B.
10  3   05:45 Anachronism
11  3   04:28 Shy
12  4   05:10 Information
13      00:55 Optimism

Comments: A very dark, pulsing album from another band who looks like
Sprockets.  Much of Drome's sound is rehash, endlessly repeated soundbites
which seem to lend any relevance to a theme.  Where they especially excel is
in their sculpting of noise into perfectly fitting additions to clockwork-like
rhythms.  The first track "Optimism" and "Dreams" are more upbeat than the
rest which mainly stay in a darker ClockDVA realm.  "Drugs" is especially
interesting in moving from a bleepy trance into some serious hardcore.  The
latter half of the album really sags from hypnotic into bland.

Summary: 7/10.  If you like ClockDVA, you'll enjoy this.  There are also
elements similar to Aphex Twin, Biosphere, and PWOG.


D-Shake: Nite & Day
Go Bang/Sonic: SNC-2011-2
1   3   05:39 Club Mix
2   4   06:34 Hardcore Mix
3   4   04:52 Supersonic Mix
4   3   05:45 Knight at Nite Mix
5   3   05:40 Speedub Mix

Comments: The problems with kids these days!  Look at the crud they're
listening to.  Seriously, this is formula techno at its worst.  This stuff
makes me especially nauseas due to the fact that a particular local club DJ
will grab garbage like this and play it for the next six months repeatedly.
The mixes don't help either.  D-Shake isn't as bad as some groups I've heard,
but it is a real wool-over-the-eyes miracle that someone thinks they have
enough talent to press several releases.

Summary: 2/10.  Not terrible, just not good.  D-Shake doesn't have an
innovative bone in their body.


Exquisite Corpse: Reassembling Reality
Kk-Records: KK029CDS
1   4   11:08 What a Life
2   3   07:15 Anxiety
3   3   08:43 Traditional Ties With Dreaming
4   3   08:49 Honeymoon

Comments: A very surprising piece of work.  With the name and the shoddy
cover, I was half expecting gothic grunge to come wafting over my ears.  What
I found instead was highly hypnotic, at times beautiful, with a deep
undercurrent of rhythm.  Exquisite Corpse is very similar to label mates
Psychic Warriors of Gaia, except it is more upbeat, but also at times too
repetitive.  It is a fine line between hypnotic and boring, Exquisite Corpse
falls on both sides.  "What a Life" is the best piece with two minutes of deep
chords as an intro to a uppy, dancey, trancey melody, overlaid with different
variations on the theme.  "Anxiety" and "Traditional" tend to annoy with a
sudden sharpness in instrumentation that seems out of place here, but are
still mostly good.  "Honeymoon" is musically the most bland of the four, but
uses a Native American storyteller to good effect.

Summary: 8/10.  Tantalizing stuff, I'd like to see what else they come up
with.


Probe Volume 1
Probe Records: pro11
1   2   07:06 Circuit Breaker: Open Your Mind
2   3   07:43 Up!: Spiritual High
3   2   05:14 Public Energy: Three o' Three
4   2   05:04 Spawn: The Thinking Man
5   2   05:24 Deko!: Panik
6   3   04:31 Dbx: Annexia
7   4   05:13 0733: Record Bass Story
8   4   04:34 Texas Audio: Assassin
9   4   04:08 Public Energy: Hemi-Sync
10  4   04:30 Spawn: Tension
11  5   05:06 Circuit Breaker: Trac-X

Comments:  Hardcore, you know the bore.  This compilation stands out as a
prime example of dicking around with synths in order to make something
releasable.  Although they could be credited with not using the soundbite
method of music production, they can't be credited for making anything
especially interesting.  Two of these tracks, "Open Your Miind" and "Assassin"
date back many moons to the 1000 Ohm! comp, I'd suspect that everything else
is similarly dated or leftover.  Still, Public Energy's "Hemi-Sync" has some
worth and Circuit Breaker's "Trac-X" is hard enough to overlook its
repetition.

Summary: 4/10.  I can't recommend this at all.  However, it isn't so bad that
I'm going to get rid of it.


Vicious Vinyl Techno-Rave Compilation
Vicious Vinyl/Sonic: SNC-2012-2
1   4   05:57 Vertigo Hypo: Hypo Rhino
2   3   05:57 Ground Level: God Intended
3   4   04:49 Astral Project: Come With Me
4   3   05:25 Aqua Labs: So Good
5   4   05:03 Eternal: Mind Odyssey
6   5   05:57 Tomorrow People: Blood Rush
7   4   04:54 Vertigo Hypo: Sinewave Express
8   3   05:25 Ground Level: Out of Body
9   2   06:14 Cosmic Transmission: Force Feel
10  4   05:06 Eternal: Eternal
11  3   06:33 Tomorrow People: Spain

Comments:  I guess I should have been wary of anything containing the title
"Techno-Rave", but this was on Sonic and all the music was from Australia's
Vicious Vinyl, so I figured the combination of the two would help a little.
Well, it didn't.  Although there are a few gems here, they aren't that great,
and everything else is in the standard clubhouse vein.  Tomorrow People is the
only name that could be worth looking into.  Vertigo Hypo's tracks start
promising, then rapidly die.  Only other track of slight note is Aqua Labs "So
Good" which uses the "You make me feel so good" sample AGAIN, but loses its
charm in a hurry.

Summary: 3/10.  Standard fodder for the "Techno-Rave" buying masses.

From sfraves-request@medisg.Stanford.EDU  Thu Mar 18 01:19:36 1993

	id AA28281; Thu, 18 Mar 93 01:15:06 PST

Date: Thu, 18 Mar 93 10:37:58 PST
From: Derek Chung <dhchung@us.oracle.com>
To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU
Subject: public property?


<Interesting note:  A cop showed up at the original site
< at 9:30 to warn me that I was illegelly on Federal
< property...so we would've had trouble early on.

I understand the kind of social conditioning which leads
to and leads us to accept such rules, but doesn't it seem
like sort of a bizarre concept that there's this land that
is called a "recreation area" (Golden Gate National Recreation
Area), doesn't belong to anybody except the people of this
country, and where we wouldn't be disturbing anyone or 
destroying the environment -- but a group of fine, upstanding
members of the community can't gather at night, play some
music, socialize and dance?

I understand that they don't want people vandalizing the
property and spoiling it for other people, or actual 
criminal activity going on, but isn't it strange to think
that there's this part of the Earth that is "closed".  I
can easily accept that somebody's home should be private,
but in this supposedly free country, isn't our freedom
severely restricted, when there are all these public lands
where you are NOT ALLOWED to be?  When positively-contributing
members of the society need a permit to gather in an     
isolated warehouse to play music and dance?

I don't want to get into all the other aspects in which
we're in a police state because of the War on Drugs or the
Cold War, etc. but this is an example of where we can't
do something which we would consider really, really basic -
even more basic than most of our Constitutional rights, 
since many of those deal with rights necessary within the
societal framework that already exists, and these issues -
the right to go somewhere, the right to be somewhere, the
right to assemble with people ought to be fundamental,
regardless of the social structures.

-Derek

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 o  derek chung  o  oracle graphics  o  dhchung@oracle.com  o  415.506.6195  o
 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------

From: dms!curly!grigsby@netcom.com (Spiral Death Trap)
Message-Id: <9303181951.AA16664@curly.agames.com>
To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Legalities


The problem with American "justice" is that it goes to the highest
bidder.  If you have sufficient money to hire squadrons of lawyers
you can get almost anything you want to happen.  Either that, or
you are lucky and/or persuasive and get people to help you gratis.

Notice that the Feds got slapped hard for messing with Steve Jackson
Games.  They figured that they could just do what they wanted because
SJG was too small to fight back, and they were -- but then Mitch Kapor
and some other heavyweights (their wallets are heavy, at least) formed
the EFF, and the tables were turned. 

That's the same reason SF cops mess with small, diffuse, cool events
like CII and leave the big promoters alone -- they have money and are
authoritarian enough themselves that they're not a threat to the
status quo.  Sadly, lawyer/revolutionaries like Bob Black who are 
willing to tweak the Establishment for the hell of it are rare.

We are talking about power here.  Right now, _they_ have it.  The ways 
I can think of to get power over the situation include money, prestige,
and mass action.  Anyone have any other ideas?

// g

For Connection II cassette orders, acceptable forms of payment are
cash in a security envelope or carbon paper (greatly preferred), money
orders or cashiers checks.

Also, if you are interested in buying a set, it's really important
that you put your order in the mail as soon as possible -- most
likely, there will not be many "extra" sets made up for later sale.  I
will absolutely fill all orders received at the PO box before April
15th.  If I receive your order after April 15th, I may end up
refunding your money, though I'll try to fill your order.

I'm shooting for a tape shipment date of the 15th of May, so most
people in school should be able to use their school address.

Shagga rasta,
Bob Ramstad, Pleasure Seeker

From: mcg@netcom.com (Tiamat the Chaos-Ocean)
Subject: Re: go derek...!!!

> why can't i party on the beach or the park...hmmmm and why dose
> one need a permitt to do so??? lets start challenging those laws...

I also think it's high time we found a lawyer to do some research, and
eventually challenge police actions in court.

Along those lines, there was just an annoucement on KALX (a ticket
give-away actually) of an all-night event Friday at 16th and Harrison
called Rhythm Empire, with Ernie, Tony, Josh and Buck.  Supposedly
it's a benefit to raise a legal fund to challenge the law prohibiting
dancing after 2:30 am by people under 21 (although there are obviously
loopholes in that law).  I don't have any way of confirming this.

Keep in mind that one main reason the cops enforce these arcane permit
laws is that the "legitimate" (i.e. alcohol-pushing) club owners paid
big bucks for their licenses, and have been known to pressure the city
into shutting down unlicensed events which they believe are causing them
to lose revenue.  This is the original reason Mayor Agnos formed his anti-
underground club task force in the spring of '91, hoping that the club
owners would reward him by supporting his campaign for re-election.

Komotion on 16th St (a performance venue, not a rave site) was closed for
several months until they went through the whole permit process -- after
over five years of unmolested operation.

Just another data point,

Subject: Re: public property?

Derek:
> I understand that they don't want people vandalizing the
> property and spoiling it for other people, or actual 
> criminal activity going on, but isn't it strange to think
> that there's this part of the Earth that is "closed".  I
> can easily accept that somebody's home should be private,
> but in this supposedly free country, isn't our freedom
> severely restricted, when there are all these public lands
> where you are NOT ALLOWED to be? 

The only possible logical reason I can think of is liability.  
I think that the government has the right to protect themselves from
lawsuits which can happen if they allow "unsafe" (i.e. night 
time) activites to occur on recreational lands.   Of course, 
you would think it would be a simple matter to let us sign waivers 
or something.  Unfortunately, the day will come when the parents of
a young raver who gets hurt at an illegal rave will sue...

> When positively-contributing
> members of the society need a permit to gather in an     
> isolated warehouse to play music and dance?

Liability again?  I don't know, it's pretty fucked up; questionable
laws are selectively enforced against harmless people simply
for the *sake* of the reinforcement of authority ==> enforcement
for the sake of enforcement.  It kinda legitimizes crime-for-the-
sake-of-crime, which is certainly *not* what most ravers ever 
intend to do.

        I think the key words in Derek's and Susie's posts were "without 
disturbing anyone" and "peaceably assemble".  Peace = Quiet, and we're 
anything but quiet.  Obviously, in most cases we actually AREN'T 
disturbing anyone because we're miles away from civilization, but that's 
the justification the cops use.  It's sort of impossible to argue 
against, because all the cops have to say is "It's disturbing my peace!" 
and that's justification.  Just playing devil's advocate to a certain 
extent.  I would encourage you all to go clear things with the police 
dept before hand, though, and have a backup site ready if they say no.  I 
mean if you explain it as a friendly dance party with no alcohol, etc, 
then they are likely to say yes.

> Along those lines, there was just an annoucement on KALX (a ticket
> give-away actually) of an all-night event Friday at 16th and Harrison
> called Rhythm Empire, with Ernie, Tony, Josh and Buck.  Supposedly
> it's a benefit to raise a legal fund to challenge the law prohibiting
> dancing after 2:30 am by people under 21 (although there are obviously
> loopholes in that law).  I don't have any way of confirming this.

I can confirm this, sorta.  I have recently become the "rave promotions
guy" at KALX and was the one behind this announcement.  I talked to the
promoter, who told me all about this "benefit".  Nothing about this is
mentioned on the flier, however, so I can't say exactly how much of the
proceeds will go towards this cause, but it sounds like a good thing.

If anyone has knows of any raves or related activities that could use some
radio promotion, email me or give me a call at home (510-549-6223).  

I'll be doing a radio show this monday night/tuesday morning from about
12:45am-3:30am.  I'll be taping the first 90 minutes of my show in order
to get approved for other time slots, so I'll have to go easy on the
acid-house (the show reviewers aren't too hip to it).  At about 2:15,
though, I'll be doin the mixin' thang till 3:30.  My only time to practice
is on the air, so go easy on me if I don't sound like Jeno.  The first
part of my show will probably consist of random weirdness (experimental, 
industrial, and occasional jazz or hip-hop).  
Also, if you're interested in winning tickets to Rhythm Empire, a pair
will be given away sometime tonight between 12:30 and 3:30am, and another
tomorrow during Nommi de Plume's show.

Finally, I'd just like to say hello to MykL, who I met at the pre-C2
party. Hello.  There, I said it.  Hope to meet more of you soon!

"LovE is thee Law, LovE under WILL"           -Seth/MescalinaanilacseM\hteS

From: Seth Joshua Horvitz <acid23@uclink.berkeley.edu

I am a DJ at KALX Berkeley (90.7fm) and have just recently become the
"rave promotions guy" for the station.  The first promotion offered to me
is for RHYTHM EMPIRE this friday at 16th/Harrison (DJ's are Ernie Tony
Josh and Buck).  The lineup sounds decent, but not breathtaking.  The
promoter for this has told me that all proceeds from the event will go
towards hiring attorneys to "beat the law so that kids can dance past
2:30."  That includes everyone under 21 (myself included).  Sounds like a
good enough cause if its legitimate.  Does anyone know anything about this
rave?  KALX will be giving away four pairs of tickets tomorrow over the
air, so if you're interested, tune in!  And if anyone knows of any raves
which would like to be promoted on KALX, call me at home (510-549-6223) or
email me (acid23@uclink.berkeley.edu).  

Also, I will be doing a radio show this coming monday night/tuesday
morning from about 12:45am-3:30am.  My air name is Mescalina.  Please
listen and call me with requests! (510-642-KALX).  I will be taping the
first 90 minutes of my show so that I can get approved for other time
slots.  This means that the first 90 will not include that much
house-related stuff (the show reviewers aren't too hip to it).  I'll play
lots of weird experimental and industrial shit. Once the 90 minutes is up,
though, it'll be MIXMIXMIX (or an attempt anyway).

OTHER NOTES: I want to know why no raves ever START at the Marina.  It
seems like many people's best experiences have been there.  Does this not
make sense or what?  A friend of mine is hoping to throw a party there in
a couple weeks.  Also, I'd like to say hello to MykL and Derek, who I met
at the pre-C2 party.  After all those directions, I still couldn't find
the damn warehouse.  Never even found the 101 (pathetic, I know). Oh well, I
wish I had known about the move to the Marina sooner.  Hope to meet more of 
you people soon.  I would've stayed at the pre-party for longer,
but I had someone illegally parked waiting for me.  Oh well, next time...
			
          -SETH/Mescalina    "Love is the law, love under will"

I saw this and thought some of ya would be interested...

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Hi, this is from a flyer sent out by California NORML and MAPS...
 
PSYCHEDELIC SUMMIT: A weekend of Events Celebrating the 50th Anniversary
of Albert Hofmann's discovery of LSD
 
April 16th, 17th
 
Sponsored by MAPS (Multidisciplinary Association for Psychedelic Studies),
 The Island Group and California NORML (National Organization for the
Reform of Marijuana Laws) plus Millbrook West and Media Kaos to Benifit
Psychedelic & Marijuana Research.
 
Santa Cruz: April 16th: "LSD: 50 Years and Beyond".  Friday, 7 p.m.-11:15
p.m.: UC Santa Cruz Performing Arts Theater.  Highlights: Leary, Naranjo,
Anton Wilson, too many other legends to name..
 
and:
 
San Francisco, April 17th:  "Psychedelics and Cannabis; Sprirituality,
Medicine and Policy"
An all-day exposition with Psychedelic Media, Art, Music, Vendors,
Refreshments, Meditation Area. 11AM 'til quite late.  I dunno, though
Mills college around sunset would be nice.   
  This SF event features a number of presentations by some of the most
knowledgeable in the field: Metzger, McKenna, Brownie Mary Rathbun, Peron,
etc. etc.
 
Reservations: MAPS c/o California
NORML, 2215-R Market St. #278, San Francisco 94144
Credit card sales through Hemporium, 442 Haight St, SF (415)552-7487
Event Information: (408)427-1942--Vendors:(415)563-5858
 
Happy trails!

------------------------------------------------------------------------

Date: Fri, 19 Mar 93 00:35:07 -0500
From: jp@darkstar.com
Message-Id: <9303190535.AA09056@uu.psi.com>
Received: by darkstar.com (FernMail); Thu, 18 Mar 93 20:50:33
To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: Public Property?

It's not just beaches and warehouses either. Right before Bush left
office, some pretty nasty laws were being considered which
severely limited the rights to peaceably assemble in national forests.
It's unclear at the moment whether they will be pitched out by Bill, but
if they do go into effect,it'll be a real pain-in-the-ass for groups
such as Rainbow (members of which certainly aren't out to vandalize,
don't do *that* many illegal things and are definitely better for a
national forest than a bunch of weekenders taking the 4x4 out for a
spin). Rainbow has a pretty decent system for alerting the tribes about
these legal hassles and then organizing mass letter-writing campaigns.
If they can do it on a national level with some success, I'm sure we can
do it on a local level.
---
Once in a while you can get shown the light,
in the strangest of places if you look at it right...
Julie Petersen  jp@darkstar.com

Date: Thu, 18 Mar 93 17:56:06 -0800
From: Joachim Vance (The Underdog) <jvance@einstein.oac.uci.edu>


> Derek writes:
> > isn't our freedom
> > severely restricted, when there are all these public lands
> > where you are NOT ALLOWED to be? 

Lee writes:
> The only possible logical reason I can think of is liability.  
> I think that the government has the right to protect themselves from
> lawsuits which can happen if they allow "unsafe" (i.e. night 
> time) activites to occur on recreational lands.  

  Interesting little article in the paper yesterday:

     "  The California Supreme Court has given landowners broad
     protection from lawsuits by hunters, hikers and other people
     injured while using land for recreation.
        In a 4-3 decision that overturns numerous lower-court rulings,
     the high court Monday said landowners are immune from such
     personal-injury suits even if their property contains potential
     hazards and is not suitable for recreation.
        The court based its decision on a 1963 state law that created
     the immunity to encourage landowners to open their property to
     recreation."

  I don't see why this wouldn't apply to the government as well.  This
seems to open up lots of potential sites for use since liability isn't
as much of a problem. 

  Anyway, all the recent discussion of permits, curfew laws and what
not has moved me to go to the library soon and do some research.  We
are definately a political force to be reckoned with, so we might as
well network like one.  :)  
  If everyone were to spend a little time looking up the appropriate
local municipal codes restricting parties and dancing, we would have a
great resource and a better understanding of what we're up against.

Joachim

Subject: This week's RAVE guide

I bet you thought it'd never get here.  Most of you are still waiting for
my C2 post :):)  Well Soda has been up and down, and threatens to be down
more frequently than it should be.... they've been having disk problems,
but everything on the FTP site looks okay, except it appears we're missing
the archives from January.  If anyone had downloaded them somewhere and
has them, I'd really be happy if I could get them.  They will be backed up
on a safer site (floppies, maybe) very soon.  Anyways, I again encourage
everyone to use the sfraves@sfraves.stanford.edu alias instead of anything
else; this is the most reliable address around, and all the usual -request 
stuff goes through that too.

Anyways, my prediction for the weekend:

	Friday night looks kinda, er, dull.  I mean, lots of parties
happening, none that appear to be sure-winners but some possibilities.
"The Vibe" has a good history... and "Rhythm Empire" looks to be big if
that's your style, while "Ernie's Retro" appears to go the other way :)

	Saturday night could be better; there's a Wicked which are always
tres cool (and this I presume will be a benefit for Malachy) and Gemini
looks somewhat promising vibe-wise....

	Brian

Here are some weeklies - whether or not they count as real "raves" is 
debatable, but they were advertised by fliers and the music could be
good. If anyone can provide reviews of them, i.e., their 
appropriateness in being on the list, let me know....

	Bagels * Fruit Salad * Espresso * Smart Bar * Chill Room

	and Paul (afterLIFE) - Sunday Mornings at 1015 Folsom  
	6am until early afternoon. - Dancing downstirs, 
	Full breakfast cafe upstairs - Call 979-8845 for DJ lineup 

Sunday nights - boat parties thrown by Eddie of Bulletproof - $20
	(no idea where to get info about this - I think Bulletproof is
	a store on haight that throws this)

	3rd @ Harrison, 315 Harrison (City Nights), 21+ ID; Brought to 
	you by the people who promoted "Carefree", $8.00 admission.  
	Carefree alternative Style

        full house w/dj - 10pm-2am, 21+

	Funk and Rare Groove

	1st & Harrison

        8pm - ?    Guest DJs + Henrick
        Natoma, between 1st and 2nd (probably 55 natoma, back of DV8)

To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu, acid23@uclink.berkeley.edu
Subject: Re: RHYTHM EMPIRE/ other stuff

> OTHER NOTES: I want to know why no raves ever START at the Marina.  It
> seems like many people's best experiences have been there.  Does this not
> make sense or what?  A friend of mine is hoping to throw a party there in
> a couple weeks.  Also, I'd like to say hello to MykL and Derek, who I met
> at the pre-C2 party.  After all those directions, I still couldn't find
> the damn warehouse.  Never even found the 101 (pathetic, I know). Oh well, I
> wish I had known about the move to the Marina sooner.  Hope to meet more of 
> you people soon.  I would've stayed at the pre-party for longer,
> but I had someone illegally parked waiting for me.  Oh well, next time...

Raves HAVE started at the Marina, the first grop to use the Marina was the
FMR several months ago.   The key is to not piss off the cops.  Mostly
we have been able to convince the cops that we were a bunch of responsible
law abiding "kids" with enough "adult" (read old  folks) supervision to keep
things under control.  The main way we did this was by keeping the access road
clear and NEATLY PARKED and discouraging people from bringing alcohol which
will get you shut down QUICK!  If you follow those guide lines you most likely
won't have any problems.

Subject: ASS_U_ME


Well here is the scoop:

First off DONT EVEN THINK that the WICKED posse has ANYTHING to do with
Mal's Recovery or recent attempts to raise money....While at a certain
meeting of all the BIG promoters in the area ALL the club promoters decided
to cancel their events on the 20th to do a benefit for Mal....There was one
samll thing...Wicked did NOT want to cancel AT ALL.  Everyone was kinda
dissed, but oh well.  When asked would any of the proceeds go to Mal, a rep
from the posse said , and I quote "No, the money is going toward a sound
system".  I am NOT going to draw any conclusions I will let you be the
judge.  Anyway there has been GREAT speculation in the community as to WHNE
this sound system will be purchased.  From another conversation I have heard
that their sound system will REQUIRE a $30,000 down payment in full, and
that they are no where near this goal.  I really never knew that you had to
put down so much money to reserve anything other than a HOUSE, but oh well.
More about Wicky and the big picture as things begin to degrade in SF...

On the list it is mentioned that Team Green happens each Sun...this is and
has not been the case for a while.  Team Green is gone, period.  I wish I
could elaborate, but I can't.

I am certainly staying home this weekend, and every weekend until, a good
party comes along...hope to cuwhenimthere.

Peace.

From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf (Vitamin B))
Date: Fri, 19 Mar 1993 03:02:29 -0800
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)

Subject: This week's RAVE guide

I bet you thought it'd never get here.  Most of you are still waiting for
my C2 post :):)  Well Soda has been up and down, and threatens to be down
more frequently than it should be.... they've been having disk problems,
but everything on the FTP site looks okay, except it appears we're missing
the archives from January.  If anyone had downloaded them somewhere and
has them, I'd really be happy if I could get them.  They will be backed up
on a safer site (floppies, maybe) very soon.  Anyways, I again encourage
everyone to use the sfraves@sfraves.stanford.edu alias instead of anything
else; this is the most reliable address around, and all the usual -request 
stuff goes through that too.

Anyways, my prediction for the weekend:

	Friday night looks kinda, er, dull.  I mean, lots of parties
happening, none that appear to be sure-winners but some possibilities.
"The Vibe" has a good history... and "Rhythm Empire" looks to be big if
that's your style, while "Ernie's Retro" appears to go the other way :)

	Saturday night could be better; there's a Wicked which are always
tres cool (and this I presume will be a benefit for Malachy) and Gemini
looks somewhat promising vibe-wise....

	Brian

These are all events I have heard of over the net which in someway or
somehow celebrate the 50 years since the first bike ride of Albert
Hoffman.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
There's also going to be a show at 1015
Folsom featuring World Entertainment War, Crash Worship, and Robert Anton
Wilson doing a reading, on April 18th.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
8:00 PM, Saturday April 17, 1993
"Your Life Up To Now: The Debate on Composition"
MFA Thesis concert by Christopher K. Koenigsberg
free admission, reception following
Mills College Concert Hall
5000 MacArthur Blvd.
Oakland CA. -- between High St. & Seminary Ave., just off of I-580.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Well, without realizing it, I also scheduled my Thesis Concert, for my
M.F.A. in Electronic Music degree, on the night of April 17th, which I
presume is Bicycle Day? at Mills College.

So, if you're in the East Bay, come to a free psychedelic concert of
electronic music, modern dance, & a "Debate on Composition" woven into
the performance. Pieces include "Your Life Up To Now" conceptual work,
"LCM" for 12 piano sampler, "Basement Artifact" 1 & 2 derived from a
16-second noisy pump, "October Surprise" for HyperUPIC sound, a video
soundtrack, slide show study in yellow, & an attempt at techno-rave
dance mix production to close out the show.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
I am in the midst of planning my spring weekends, and
remembered hearing here that the following events were
being planned but not yet finalized. Does anyone have
any further information about when and if they will 
occur?  	

1. Friday April 16: program sponsored by MAPS in SF or
Santa Cruz with speakers on psychedelics.
   Saturday, April 17: Related bicycle day celebrations.

2. Conference sponsored by the Albert Hoffman Foundation
in LA on LSD. Was to be some time in May.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Hi, this is from a flyer sent out by California NORML and MAPS...
 
PSYCHEDELIC SUMMIT: A weekend of Events Celebrating the 50th Anniversary
of Albert Hofmann's discovery of LSD
 
April 16th, 17th
 
Sponsored by MAPS (Multidisciplinary Association for Psychedelic Studies),
 The Island Group and California NORML (National Organization for the
Reform of Marijuana Laws) plus Millbrook West and Media Kaos to Benifit
Psychedelic & Marijuana Research.
 
Santa Cruz: April 16th: "LSD: 50 Years and Beyond".  Friday, 7 p.m.-11:15
p.m.: UC Santa Cruz Performing Arts Theater.  Highlights: Leary, Naranjo,
Anton Wilson, too many other legends to name..
 
and:
 
San Francisco, April 17th:  "Psychedelics and Cannabis; Sprirituality,
Medicine and Policy"
An all-day exposition with Psychedelic Media, Art, Music, Vendors,
Refreshments, Meditation Area. 11AM 'til quite late.  I dunno, though
Mills college around sunset would be nice.   
  This SF event features a number of presentations by some of the most
knowledgeable in the field: Metzger, McKenna, Brownie Mary Rathbun, Peron,
etc. etc.
 
Reservations ( e-mailing me will do ya no good): MAPS c/o California
NORML, 2215-R Market St. #278, San Francisco 94144
Credit card sales through Hemporium, 442 Haight St, SF (415)552-7487
Event Information: (408)427-1942--Vendors:(415)563-5858
---------------------------------------------------------------------

If I hear anything else I'll forward it.
Later Dayz...
Have fun!!!!  I AM!!!

To: ianc@cats.ucsc.edu, sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re:  a finals inspired flare

The long post from ianc is almost illiterate, defies logic, and truly
a bunch of crap.  As if raving sprang from nothing and can call itself
first generation.  

The truth is raving sprang from the bastard loins of  N'Awlins cathouse 
mothers and hermetic poet fathers.  (Matrilinear descent:  New Orleans
whorehouse mixes afro-creole traditions w/ eurogenes > spawns jazz > 
flappers >  hoboes > beatniks > hippies > yada-dada > ravers.
Patrilinear descent:  European hermetic traditions (Knights Templars,
alchemy, rosicrucians, onward) comes to America, mixes with noble native
traditions of absolute individual freedoms > add a dose of several centuries
of utopian experiments >  dose of Walt Whitman > German psychedelic
experimentation > Aldous Huxley > Resurgence of Native American Shamanism 
>  Xerox PARC  > MIT Media Lab > Techno-ravers.

Yo!  Ianc.  You're free to believe whatever you want.  You might want to 
do some homework before putting it out as gospel, however.  next time you
reinvent the wheel, do a patent search first.

Before the Orb went from playing buck's CHURCH to megamedia blitzes, there
was nothing but the rest of us f*cking in the primordial slime.  Thank gopod
raving sprung from cosmic lightning to show us mud suckers the way home.

peace, ianc.  there's a lot of warmth in this heart that's attacking
your flawed thesis.

alpha-10

From: Trevor Schulze <tschulze@cisco.com>

Subject: The weekend
To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU (sanfranraves)
Date: Mon, 22 Mar 93 15:41:55 PST

After fighting off a nasty cold for the last part of the week, I decided
to shake off my cabin fever with Wicked on Sat.  The event left me with
mixed feelings.  On the one hand, Garth and Jeno put down one of the
best sets I have heard from them in a long time.  FUNKY.....  On the
other, tooooo many men with their shirts off looking for a fight or a
girl on X.  I guess I'm a little sensitive to these types since I am a
little taller than most and they seem to want to bump into me a lot
trying to start something.  There have always been a number of SM
(Shirtless Men) at any gathering, but there numbers are growing....
People have complained lately about various things that are killing the
vibe- mine is the growing number of SM.  I hate to generalize or classify
anybody, but the Gangs of SM are becoming to much to bare (no pun).

Well, about the good things at Wicked.  Met a couple from Seattle who
are on the net, hello Glenn.... Hope you had a great time in SF.  The
suprisingly low alcohol consumption....  Clear and loud sound system....
But HEY WHAT HAPPENED TO HATS.....?????  One of the things I love about
raves are the different hats...  Where have they all gone?

Afterwords, went to 1015 Folsom. Definately worth checking out.  Anyway,
hope everybody had a good weekend.
--

From: Bob Ramstad <rramstad@us.oracle.com>
To: jondr@sco.com
Cc: boccibob%groovy@us.oracle.com, sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU,
        ne-raves@gnu.ai.mit.edu, dcraves@american.edu
In-Reply-To: Desi the Three-Armed Wonder Comic's message of Mon, 22 Mar 93 13:35:23 PST <9303221335.aa03031@scotty.sco.COM>
Subject: ** C2 tape announcement **
Reply-To: boccibob%groovy@us.oracle.com


Ah, good question...

Jon Drukman started out the Connection II Berkeley Marina set with a
bustin' tune ("Ampex alignment tape... begin at 700 hz"), after about
5 minutes, he attempted to mix to the other turntable, with a hashed
needle (!)  Really cool skating sounds followed.  Jon then DJed (for
lack of a better term, he only had one turntable) for another 28
minutes until the emergency needle squad arrived on the scene...

Precisely, there were gaps of 15-20 seconds between songs for about a
23 minute period (from the end of the first non-mixed song to the
start of the last non-mixed song, which ends one side of one
cassette).  To evoke the memories of being there, the first song ends
in about 5 seconds of skating noise, followed by 5 seconds of silence,
then the second tune.  Subsequent non-mixed tunes (again, about 28
minutes worth) have less than 1 second blank space between them.  I
decided to do it this way rather than remixing everything together
because I wanted the tape to be a somewhat accurate reproduction of
what happened (I hate "live" albums which are overdubbed, and it would
be weird to have remixing done after the fact) but the long gaps are
really distracting and so I made the listenability tradeoff of short
gaps between songs.

It would have been easy to make the decision to not include the
non-mixed portion of Jon's set -- but the tunes were absolutely
killer, and when 'with much rejoicing' the first tune blared out of
the (relocated) sound system, everyone was way stoked, so these tunes
evoke some of the best memories I have from C2.  Consider these 33
minutes as 'substance over form'.

This is the prospective layout:

1A  Scott Hardkiss 44 minutes
1B  Scott Hardkiss 11 minutes + Jon Drukman 33 minutes no mixing

2A  Jon Drukman 42 minutes + Moonpup 3 minutes
2B  Moonpup 45 minutes

3A  Moonpup 38 minutes
3B  Moonpup 17 minutes + Lee 21 minutes

4A  Lee 45 minutes
4B  BLURrrr 45 minutes

All sides, except for 1B, are unbroken and completely as played at C2.
All sides in order represent ** everything ** that was played at C2
except for about 10 minutes of Lee's set where there was so much water
on a record that it was skipping (!)  The splits onto cassette at this
point are fairly set in stone, I've listened to them extensively, and
this will give the best result aesthetically.  Yeah, I know, it would
be cool to have each DJ restricted to a side or a whole tape or
something, but there's no sane way of doing that -- I've already
looked at it.  Part of the problem is set lengths -- none of the DJs
did a nice 30, 45, 60, or 90 minute set, except for BLURrrr, and he's
all nice on a side by himself.

Also, one more thing: sets are $25, but if I get enough orders, I'll
probably be refunding a few $$ per set.  This cost is based on a
really low minimum number of orders, which I've already gotten :-) and
a small run of tapes costs more per tape than a larger run of tapes
(Professional Duplication 101) It'll be a bit longer before I can
ascertain if there will be enough orders to make it economically
feasible to do 4 color insert cards -- doesn't really make sense
unless I get 100 orders or so -- but as this would be one of the more
fun parts of the project, I'm hoping.

Send me email if you've been living in a bubble and missed the
ordering info, it was posted all over the place last week :-)

Bob
boccibob%groovy@us.oracle.com (preferred) or rramstad@us.oracle.com

From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>


interesting point about the family tree that lead to "rave"...
but what about the rave-elements that sprang from
	(1) juke joints (from which early extemporaneous rapping occured,
	    including "dissing" and "nasty lyrics" and other rap precursors.)
	(2) Underground black disco/funk in the early 70's.
	(3) Reggae Dancehall Culta / Reggae Dub (e.g. Lee Scratch Perry).
	(4) Gospel and gospel/dance inducing group trance states.
	(5) Jazz/Speakeasy 20's underground culture (afterall, not everybody
	    was a flapper).
	
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==           Niels Mayer -- netcom!mayer -- mayer@netcom.com               ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Medicine and Policy"
An all-day exposition with Psychedelic Media, Art, Music, Vendors,
Refreshments, Meditation Area. 11AM 'til quite late.  I dunno, though
Mills college around sunset would be nice.   
  This SF event features a number of presentations by some of the most
knowledgeable in the field: Metzger, McKenna, Brownie Mary Rathbun, Peron,
etc. etc.
 
Reservations ( e-mailing me will do ya no good): MAPS c/o California
NORML, 2215-R Market St. #278, San Francisco 94144
Credit card sales through Hemporium, 442 Haight St, SF (415)552-7487
Event Information: (408)427-1942--Vendors:(415)563-5858
---------------------------------------------------------------------

If I hear anything else I'll forward it.
Later Dayz...
Have fun!!!!  I AM!!!

Date: Mon, 22 Mar 1993 19:56:49 -0800
From: John S. Lee <jslee@well.sf.ca.us>
Message-Id: <199303230356.AA09212@well.sf.ca.us>
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu, wicked@netcom.com
Subject: ASS_U_ME The final chapter

 
First, it was not my intent to imply that the reasons behind Wicked of
Sat 3/20 were not pure at heart.  All that was said is that there was
confusion and questions being raised as to exactly what the event of
3/20 was all about.  Whether it was for Mal or the Sound System... the
case is closed on that subject, although MANY are still asking (of those
that attended) the intent.  Well you can't please everyone...
 
As for the purchase and use of the sound system, GREAT.  Finally a
public statement has been made to the intent and NOW it can be
communicated to all concerned how the system is to be used and to what
end.  Really though, this should have been made public a while back, or
at least some attempt made to communicate to the general public who
support Wicked and FM, for these are the people who should know how
things will be done once the goal of the sound system becomes a reality
(I consider myself one of those people BTW).
 
The reason why this whole subject was brought up is due to the  continual
lack of caring that some party-throwers (i.e. promoters/crews/posses)
have when sponsoring an event.  This place is becoming more and more
like LA (due to many unscrupulous  LA promoter types moving in, but
there are others in SF as well), and when people have questions about a
party that on the whole represents the BEST of the SF scene then it
behooves us to think about why we are going out and who, in the long
run, does it serve.   Does it serve to enhance the community or is it
cash lining the pockets of a  promoter?  When these questions arise
about parties that are respected then communication needs to be
increased/enhanced so that confusion can be avoided. In the case of
Wicked this is particularly important since they have created a public
trust, and a public goal of obtaining a sound system to be enjoyed by
all. They were NOT being singled out for the sake of being
mean-spirited (I have defended this scene's clubgoers/DJ's/promoters
publicly in URB a few weeks back so...).
 
I must add (yes, I MUST), that the primary reasons for staying home this
weekend had nothing to do with parties.  It is always better, in my
estimation, to spend time with family than going out, period.  Being
with my wife and child is the ULTIMATE vibe :)
 
I am glad that this dialog has taken place.  I am glad that Wicked
responded and hope that they communicate this info to the rest of the
community if for nothing else than to ease some confusion.  I know I
will do my part.   For confusion when left unchecked creates distrust. 
And in a climate of distrust we become more and more like other scenes
which have since left the planet.
 
MORE later...
 
Peace.

Bob asks:
> Golden Gate Park is BIIIG... 25th and Fulton is a bit more specific,
> but if I go there, will I definitely see / hear everything?
> 
> 1 pm -> sundown, right?

You can just head into the woods at 25th & Fulton and you're sure
to hear it.  Or you can take the 25th into the park, bearing right
until you hit a stop sign at JFK blvd.  Make a right, and about 
1/4 mile on yer right is will be Marx Meadows.  That's where the
party is.  The official start time is 11:00am, but 1pm is a good
time to arrive.  See ya there.

- leg of eel

From: Seth Joshua Horvitz <acid23@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Rhythm Empire (so cool!)
To: Seth Joshua Horvitz <acid23@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Cc: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU
Message-Id: <Pine.3.05.9303201051.B2474-b100000@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

My friday night went as follows:

First, my girlfriend and I went into the city to see the Festival of Short
Films at the Palace of Fine Arts.  Some rich bastard got the bright idea
to rent out the Exploratorium for a private party, complete with cheesy
all-cover song band (I caught 'Surfin USA' on the way to the car), so the
Film Festival was cancelled.  We hung out for a while, went to eat
dinner, and decided to check out RHYTHM EMPIRE, since we were on the guest
list.  So is this what $20 raves have become?   I hadn't been to one in
several months, and I don't think I'll be going to another any time soon.
The space was OK 16th/Harrison}. There were two separate rooms with
dj's (Buck and someone else I didn't recognize) but not really enough
people to fill either room.  And the people... ahhh, the people.  The
perfect blend of teeny boppers and boys standing against the wall with
their hands in their pockets watching the teeny boppers.  Flyers were
posted everywhere for 'Birth of the Sun' and a moving sign made of little
red lights flashed "RYTHYM EMPIRE" (note the spelling).  The music was
decent, but the vibe was nonexistent, so we danced for 10 minutes or so
and left.  The whole time we were there, I kept thinking 'what if I had
actually PAID for this?'   

Warning: the same people who were responsible for this disgrace are
throwing "The Birth of the Sun" tonight, so unless you REALLY want to see Mark
Farina, I would recommend finding something better to do.

    			-sEth/MescalinaanilacseM\htEs

From sfraves-request@medisg.Stanford.EDU  Mon Mar 22 20:56:16 1993

From: wicked@netcom.com
Message-Id: <9303201852.AA18228@netcom2.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU
Subject: RE ASS_U_ME


	Dear All, 
		We need to clarify the content of John Lee's letter.

	Firstly, Malachy is a very close friend to all of us at Wicked and the
thought that we're not concerned about his recovery we find extremely abhorent.

	There have to date been two 'Promoters' meetings. At the first, the
idea of holding a large event to raise money was dicussed. A date of April 17th
(Not March 20th or April 20th) was put forward. There was some indecision at thetime because Wicked were the only ones who had a large event planned for that
day to coincide with the 50th anniversary of Albert Hoffmans first bicycle ride.The possibility of a different date that would be amenable to all was raised at
the second meeting. The date of May 1st was suggested (to coincide with the
Whole Earth Expo - a day when the Healing Community gets together) but the 
venue to be used was unavailble for that day. So it was agreed by ALL that 
Saturday 17th April would indeed be the day to hold the benefit.

	In regards to the purchase of a sound system - the total cost is about
$30,000. This includes 4 full-range cabinets, 2 sub-bass cabinets, amplifiers,
cross-overs, graphic equalizer, monitors, cables, and casing. On top of that
we now have to buy two new turntables and a van due to the crash on Monday 8th
March. As anyone in the business will know, the purchase of professional sound
is not cheap.

	The sound system is to be run as a viable business concern to provide
a quality of sound we feel cannot be obtained from other rental companies. This
will enable us to continue to put on free events such as the FMR, as well as nowbeing able to secure a regular income for Malachy long into the future.

	We only needed to throw two more parties to realise this, but we are
now set back two months as the proceeds from Wicked on March 20th will be going
to Malachy and the April Wicked has been cancelled.

	As for Mr. Lee, it is probably better that he stays home this weekend,
but, if he would like to come to next promoters meeting he'll be more able to
accurately report the proceedings.

	Yours with love and peace,

				     Markie and Jeno   :)

	Yup, People's Park!  The authorities are giving my friend a hard time
with the permits to hold it in Golden Gate Park.  Last week, after the party
was over, the police tried to tell him that the party was unauthorized.  The
park police said that the permit that he had purchased should not have been
sold to him for such an event.  They basically have changed the type of permit
necessary to hold such an event, and that new type of permit costs $$$$$$$$$

From: wicked@netcom.com

To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: RE: ASS_U_ME


	Dear All,
		We need to clarify the content of John Lee's letter.

	Firstly, Malachy is a very close friend to all of us at Wicked and the
thought that we're not concerned about his recovery we find extremely abhorent.

	There have to date been two 'Promoters' meetings. At the first the idea
of holding a large event to raise money was discussed. A date of April 17th
(Not March 20th or April 20th) was put forward. There was some indecision at the
time because Wicked were the only ones who had a large event planned for that
day to coincide with the 50th anniversary of Albert Hoffmans first bicycle ride.
The possibility of a different date that would be amenable to all was raised at
the second meeting. The date of May 1st was suggested (to coincide with the
Whole Earth Expo - a day when the Healing Community gets together) but the venue
to be used was unavailble for that day. So it was agreed by ALL that Saturday
17th April would indeed be the day to hold the benefit.

	In regards to the purchase of a sound system - the total cost is about
$30,000. This includes 4 full-range cabinets, 2 sub-bass cabinets, amplifiers,
cross-overs, graphic equalizer, monitors, cables, and casing. On top of that we
now have to buy two new turntables and a van due to the crash on Monday 8th
March. As anyone in the business will know, the purchase of professional sound
is not cheap.

	The sound system is to be run as a viable business concern to provide a
quality of sound we feel cannot be rented from other companies. This will
enable us to put on free events such as the FMR as well as now being able to
secure a regular income for Malachy long into the future.

	We only needed to throw two more parties to realise this, but we are now set back two months as the proceeds from Wicked on March 20th will be going to
Malachy and the April Wicked has been cancelled.

	As for Mr. Lee, it is probably better that he stays home this weekend,
but, if he would like to come to the next promoters meeting he'll be able to 
more accurately report the proceedings.

	Yours with love and peace,

				     Markie and Jeno   :)
