Subject: more4realthangingereal...

Look,  I understand if they had a change of heart...In this case I would
hope so.  I hope that every penny they collect goes to Mal, and I mean every
penny.  None of this 10% shit, I mean 100% should go to Mal (sans the sound
rental, space costs...DJ should be FREE!).  I do know what was said at that
meeting of the areas promoters.  And I can only go by that...if they have
changed their mind in some way then things will swing back towards the
positive.
 
As for "..got something to say say it" :{  I said everything I wanted to
say.  This SCENE, when examined close enough can be a GRINDER.  Promoters do
NOT want to cooperate with each other, and in reality it is nothing but
egos, egos, egos.  Maybe I am too close (which is likely) to the shit not to
smell the stink sometimes, but overall I do remain positive about the
possibilities.  I mean CII and other parties thrown by the newer "kids" are
examples of what the scene can be about,,,connection.
 
I will NEVER name names, because I am not a name dropper.  I know enough
people, and respect enough people that I would never use someones name just
to validate what I say.  Just as I would never use anyones on the nets name
to validate what I say.  Let's just call it a qualified confidentiality.
I do NOT have anything against wicked, except that it is increasingly
difficult to see that the people who want to throw parties have a hard time
getting SOME of the DJ's on that lineup because their primary thang is
wicked...fair enough for the DJ's and wicked, but what about for the scene.
Music should be shared universally...there should be no ONE gathering place
to hear the sounds, and the quality should always be top notch, no matter
how many people are on the dance floor, no matter where the fucking party
is, no matter if there are other "star" dj's or just some starter DJ's, it's
about a feeling, not the FAME.
 
If I know something, I will post it.  If you know who I'm talking about,
fine, if not then don't worry a name is just a name, the scene is too
special for any ONE personnae, so get off of the naming names tip.  Just
worry about where the next party is, and if your friends are going, and if
you'll be able to catch a positive vibe with them.  Beware of cheap (ala
many mega-raves) imitations...either it's got the spirit, or it's shit.


Peace...


Hey, is anyone going to the Gath...oops I meant Vision...
Peace.

From: "Stewart, Scott*" <stewart#m#_scott*@msgate.corp.apple.com>

Warning: the same people who were responsible for this disgrace are
throwing "The Birth of the Sun" tonight

I have heard rumors that these same people are the one responsible for getting
the others like Groove Kitchen and Ascend shut down.  Is this just a rumor,
Know the commericial attitude of this space I wouldnt be suprised.

Think about it, lets say they have some pull in getting the others shut down
(payoff to the police, etc..)  Then a few weeks later they hold a rave saying
that proceeds will go to lawyers to allow to prevent this from happening.  I
doubt very seriously that any of this money goes to lawyers.  Do any of you
remeber the First Walley World Flyer?  This was the first time this space was
used and they said there was going to be rides and $10 before 10.  Well if any
of you have been there you know that there is no way they can fit rides in that
building.  Probably less than half of the people who get there before 10 get in
free especially since they dont start letting people in till 9:30-9:45 after a
thoroug search, which is probably to slow the line down even more.  The more I
think about this space the more I get sick to my stomach what these guys are
doing to the scene.

NUT

From: taifarm@cats.ucsc.edu (Tai Farmer)
Subject: Re: GG Park NonRave

	The reason the Park hotline began was to make it unnecessary to guess
of the location of the party.  The person who's voice that you hear on the voice
mail is the same person who puts together the party.  So, whatever he sais on
the message IS the place where the party will be.  There is no possibility that
the sound system would just show up at Golden Gate Park when the message said
that it would not happen there.  The reason it didn't happen there was because
the authorities changed the type of permit necessary to hold such an event.  
Trust the message!  (415) 749-7670

  	Hopefully, future parties will be held back at the original location at
Golden Gate Park.

happy equinox, spring is here!!!!

-Tai

Subject: a finals inspired flare


     I found a good quote in a computer rag today::

     "The first generation learns from experience;
      the second generation receives by inheritance;
      the third generation expects convenience;
      and the fourth protests nuisance."

      Apply this to raving. The emergence from underground. The bad but
   fecund rave acts. The total lack of rugged individualism in raves that
   PREACH a 'Love,Unity,Peace' focus. The missing rebellion from those
   mindsets that miss that raving in a sweeping away of the old as much
   as making a future. We are not here to fight issues. We mock issues
   as being media-made. We scare your parents. We dig a/the generation gap.
   
   There are no roots, no genders, no races, only a technological cressendo
   that by eliminating toil, eliminates issues/differences.

   Stop being so flaccid and politically correct Mr. Rave. You're not
   a "community" (totally loaded word for conflictionist sociology),
   your the son of middle-class nerd boredom that realized western
       ^e  ,that is OUR, culture is the basis from the next revolution.
   The information revolution that bring to the notice of those
                                  ^ we
   too passive or too stodgy or too ignorant will change the nature
   of society (insert favorite logrithmic change quote here) and put
   the altrusim and lack of difference except through differentiation
   behavior of humanity on a high density monitor in 32bit clarity.

   Raves are as much conspiracies as parties. Few understand them.
   The young can feel the pull; they will respest us only if, by
   being first generations, we keep away from culturual ideaolgy
   (namely hippie) and instead imbue them with power.

    A raver should pirate, hack, mock, be liberal ("information wants to be
    free") but not radical ("Unity amongst the Unwarshed"), that is, 
    understand what is the fat-of-the-land and exploit it. 

    Too nerdy to be cliquey. Too white-collar crimed to get burned.

    Realize cos we're at the outset of this revolution, we must stay
    1st generation. Minimal inhertance. No convience. 

   this tends to describe a sfraver actually... except for the hippie bit,
    uh-huh, like it's non-toxic.

ianc flame-off.

    oops. didn't finish one point, it's that "Realize 'cos" paragraph.
  We being first will have children more into raving than we will ever be.
  Aprreciate that.

From sfraves-request@medisg.Stanford.EDU  Mon Mar 22 22:24:53 1993

Received: from sco.sco.COM by relay1.UU.NET with SMTP 
	(5.61/UUNET-internet-primary) id AA05072; Mon, 22 Mar 93 17:26:05 -0500
Received: from scotty.sco.COM by sco.sco.COM
	id aa18307; Mon, 22 Mar 93 14:04:01 PST
To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU
Subject: ken dated wee pu
From: Desi the Three-Armed Wonder Comic <jondr@sco.com>
Sender: jondr@sco.com
Date: Mon, 22 Mar 93 13:57:37 PST
Message-Id:  <9303221357.aa03234@scotty.sco.COM>

went to deep faith on thursday.  james from tweekin was kicking it
hard - most enjoyable.  the jon williams came on and continued to kick
hard - also most enjoyable.  then the hardkiss bros came on and...
kicked it hard again!  out of character for them, but (as the man
sez)... most enjoyable.  all in all, a most enjoyable time.

i blew off friday nite, although a formidable contingent of sfraves
scenesters (including Pete Ashdown, on holiday from the confines of
Salt Lake City) dropped by Ultraviolet HQ to check out our setup and
hear some great music.  nice to see y'all.

saturday - wicked, of course.  markie mark was laying down a trancy
vibe when we got there which might not have been too smart considering
the hour, but i didn't mind that much.  i expected the place to really
get packed and uncomfortable after 2, but surprisingly, it didn't.  in
fact, it remained at a crowded-but-not-uncomfortable density for the
entire evening.  it was sweaty on the dance floor, but never really
unbearable.  i was pleasantly surprised.  garth really cut loose with
some severe funky stuff - and he kept the disco to an absolute
minimum, so i was a truly happy camper.  go garth!  jeno was also a
master of the funk, with a very very low jazz factor, which also
brightened my day.  not that i mind acid jazz, but i find that i
prefer to sit down and listen to it, rather than dance.  being
chemically unassisted, i split at 6 AM and didn't get to hear what
thomas is up to these days.  can someone enlighten me?

on sunday, we heard via the grapevine that golden gate park had been
nixed and people's park would be taking its place.  this sounded
rather unappetizing, so we decided to have a mini-picnic in golden
gate park and bring along a boom box and some mix tapes.  we saw a few
ravers, informed a few inquiring ones that the rave was happening over
in berkeley (typical reaction: "oh darn."), and even hooked up with
sfrave mainstays Mykl G and Giamma for a while.  so, a pleasant day in
the sun with some grooving tunes and a classy picnic lunch (baguette,
brie and pate).  not bad, but i would've liked a more booming sound
system.

Jon Drukman (in stereo where available)                         jondr@sco.com

If you want to touch the sky, just put a window in your eye.           - Coil

Forwarded message:
From jslee@well.sf.ca.us Sat Mar 20 23:29:44 1993
Date: Sat, 20 Mar 1993 23:27:49 -0800
From: John S. Lee <jslee@well.sf.ca.us>
Message-Id: <199303210727.AA29117@well.sf.ca.us>
To: wicked@netcom.com
Subject: Re:  RE ASS_U_ME

Thank you for the clarification.  I think that THIS type of thing needs to
be done every now and then for ALL concerned.  Not accusing the wicked posse
of anything of course, but there have been valid questions raised as to tyhe
proceeds of the party and how things were to be run AFTER the sound system
was purchased.  MAny have thought that FREE parties were going to be thrown,
many thought that the money was to go to another purpose.  This does not
need to be the case.

All promoters concerns are their own, but when stated publicly that
something is to be done some type of clarification as to how things would be
carried out, I think, is in order.  This has been the FIRST time, to my
knowledge, that and actual policy has been stated.  And I am glad.

As for Mal, I am truly sorry for what has happened to him and his
circumstance.  I have done what I can (made a video for him of his friends
saying hello and get well wishes) for him, and supported some of the events
where I have known that the proceeds were going to him.  I wanted to go out
tonite, but this weekend turned out to be a bad time all around.

I was told that the event (wicked) tonite was at first, for the purcahse of
the system, then later it was communicated that the event was a benefit for
mal...a bit confusing to say the least.  What I see happening is that some
promoters will use Mal's name to promote their event, for this type of
exploitation is NOT uncommon.  I think that IF promoters are going to do a
benefit on his behalf then they should explicitly state what portions of the
proceeds go to him...especially since the economy is so underground, and
many of the organizations are NOT business entities.  There are many waiting
for a chance to bust these eveits for any reason.  ANd considering the
status of some of the scenes citizenry this can be hazardous (who need the
IRS or the INS involved).  Therefor to keep things honest and for protection
of ALL involved things need to be as expolicit as possible to avoid
confusion and chaos.

No I did NOT attend the last meeting, but someone was there in my stead.
I kept the conversation limited to Mal and the sound system for these were
the things that MANY on the scene are/were confused about.  And I only
raised questions that many were asking amongst themselves.

As for concern about Malachy's health and well being/recovery there was
nothing in the origianl post that said that the posse was NOT concerned.
Just that there were questions as to what tonite's event was all about, and
who it was for...plain and simple.  Most people know that the "promoters"
are getting together to throw a large benefit for Mal.  It was not my intent
to say or imply that you/group did not care.  If you read the post you would
clearly see that.  But whenever things are not clearly stated, and one thing
is said while another is done, then it can lead to confusion...which by my
estimation you have created order out of such chaos.

Well, I'm done.  Now it's time to go out get a couple of beers, smoke some
J, listen to Garth's new tape, and chill out until next week.


On a side:  I have TRIED on several occasions to contact dy-na-mix.  They
have YET to return my calls.  I will try again...if you are still interested
that is...let me know.

Peace.



--

Subject: ASS_U_ME response..


I have already mailed Markie and Jeno a response, so I'll be brief.

As for the 'charge' that I insinuated that the wicked posse didn't care
about Mal, no such assertion was made.  The only assertion is that minds
were changed but it was not clear, aat least from my viewpoint and of others
that I know, what tonite's event was about.  They have NOW made it clear.

As for the soundsystem of wicked, to my knowledge this is the first time the
intentions have been made in public clearly to a wide audience.  And in my
assertion, long overdue.  The only point of the whole series of postings was
that there are many grey areas within the scene, some less so than others.
Wicked began putting out flyers with a stated intent.  Sometimes notes were
made on the flyers as to how well there stated goal has been going.  But
more often than not the info was sketchy at best (how much can you put on a
flyer).  But the info about the business entity portion of Wicked (i.e. the
stated intent as to how the system would be used) was NOT so well known.
Maybe now it will be.  All that I am saying, and justifiably so since many
who go to wicked respect what they do, is that IF a promoter has a stated
goal for throwing parties and is relying on the public to fulfill that
promise, then they OWE it to the public to let them know the status of such
a goal, AS WELL AS what will happen after the goal has been reached.  Wicked
so far, are the ONLY people who have had such a goal and  stated it
publicly.  I am not being mean spiritied when I ask that the info be
revealed on some level.  I would hope that GREATER atempts at communicating
with their public can be done in the future. This would avaoid all chaos and
miconceptions.

As for staying home this weekend, I did for the most part because I needed
to chill out after  a long week.  Parties generally don't influence these
decisions, but family does.

I think overall this has been constructive and I hope that others will voice
their concerns about what THEY  see as a problem or a potential problem.  We
all know there are great parties, so-so parties, and downright awful ones.
If communication is kept flowing it an only enhace the scene and make it
better.  This should be especially so with those indiviauls/organizations
who have garenered a certain level of respect within the community.

Peace...and MORE later.

(BTW I will be at the next meeting =)

Am I the only one who actually went to this thing?  I live less than a
block away from People's Park, so it was just a short stroll.  Got there
sometime after 2, and there were probably about 100 or so people there. 
The dj was good, although he seemed really nervous.  There were only a few
people dancing until about 3:30 or so, when things started to pick up.  A
different dj had come on.  Not sure who he was, but he played a wide
variety of things, most of which was heavily based on soul and reggae.  By
4, there were several hundred people, and a big crowd dancing.  I'd never
seen People's Park this crowded!  I was actually having a pretty good
time, although I kept looking at my watch, wondering if Garth would show. 
He finally came on about 4:30, so I was happy, until 5:15 that is, when he
threw on a Bob Marley track to end it.  5:15??? The sun was nowhere near
setting, and I was definitely not done dancing.  Oh well, I guess I
couldn't expect too much from People's Park.  Hopfully it will be back in
Golden Gate soon...

		        SETH/MescalinaanilacseM\HTES

Date: Mon, 22 Mar 93 03:10:34 -0800
From: saeedi@shell.portal.com (Steven J Saeedi)
Message-Id: <9303221110.AA04890@jobe>
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: my weekend in review

Hello all,

Here's my update to this weekend.  I barely have time to read all 
the mail that goes through, let alone write something.  So, here 
goes; my first real posting to this list:

I also want to thank everyone for giving their opinions and 
updates on different events, as they have helped me in making 
decisions as to where to go.  

In the past three months since I have been on this list, I think I 
have attended 80% of the raves around town. (sorry, I got lost at 
C2).  One of the recurring themes is the dislike for club-type 
places.  I now know what those feelings are like, based on my 
experiences as well.  I hate those organized-rip-off-the-people-
with-$20-cover-charges-let-me-search-your-body places as well.  
They're too stressed!  However, for some strange reason I like 
going to Sound Factory once in a while.  I went there Friday night 
and although the crowd was mostly interested in showing themselves 
and finding the right boy/girl to take home, there were areas on 
the floor where people seemed to be truly interested in the 
dance/rave aspect of it.  I mostly hung out in that area and once 
in a while ventured out to get water, etc.  The sound system is 
awesome, the lighting effects are cool, and the DJs can spin.  I 
had a good time with some of the friends I went with and others I 
met there.  I am curious if there are others on this list who like 
going to SF as well?

Anyways, Sound Factory was fun, and we left at 5am and headed for 
Smiling Thru.  Geez, I wish more people would attend.  It was 
pretty dead as we crashed on the couch in the front room waiting 
for more people to show up.  I thought the donation for Malachy was 
a nice gesture.  I don't know who he is, but from everyone's feelings 
towards him, he seems quite a great guy.  I wish him the best and most 
speedy recovery.  Back to ST.  The music was great, but I was too tired 
to move a muscle.  One complaint tho', there was so much of that smoke 
stuff in the main area, I could hardly breathe and had to walk out every 
now and then for air.  I wish they wouldn't smoke everyone out like that, 
'cause it lingers for a long time.  It doesn't seem healthy to me to suck 
in that stuff into our lungs, does it?  Disappointed, we left at 7:30.  
Maybe Saturday mornings are just not right.

Sunday morning got to AfterLife (DNA) around 9am.  The place was 
bustling.  It was a new concept for me to get a good night's rest 
and get up in the morning for more...  I like the idea of the 
breakfast/juice bar outside and finally doing something about the 
turntables inside.  Stayed there 'til 1PM and went home.  I couldn't 
make it to the Rave at People's Park.  Hope it went well.

Well, that was my weekend.  Thanks for tuning in...

-- Steve

> interesting point about the family tree that lead to "rave"...

Not very ravey but the good one were underground.


> 	(2) Underground black disco/funk in the early 70's.
Definitely in the lineage, there was a vibe in these places even though
it was mixed with attitude.  The Gay discos kept the disco flame burning
after it was co-opted by the record companies, it eventually metamorphasized
into House.

> 	(3) Reggae Dancehall Culta / Reggae Dub (e.g. Lee Scratch Perry).
I don't know much about this.

> 	(4) Gospel and gospel/dance inducing group trance states.
YES most definitely.  Especially the Black Pentacostal "Holy Roller"
churches.  The service in these churches is very much like a rave
in structure if not in form and content.  The music is intense and
highly "soulful" when it get cookin the beat gets up to around 130 BPM,
people get "happy" which is a trance state where they are "filled
with the holy ghost", this is accepted and often it is the older folks
thattt this happens to.  I don't think I could go to one of these services
now without this happening to me.  Once you learn how to go into this state
you can fall into it REAL easy.  I find myself slipping into trance at
the most unlikely moments during a rave, it feels like I'm sliding down
a ski slope or hill and then I'm gone.  I come back into ego consciousness
sometimes 30 seconds sometimes maybe a minute or so after but since I'm not
sure how much time has passed this may not be accurate.

> 	(5) Jazz/Speakeasy 20's underground culture (afterall, not everybody
> 	    was a flapper).

These clubs had there own for of the Vibe as well.

Received: from medisg.Stanford.EDU by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA26407; Tue, 23 Mar 93 04:09:56 -0800

Received: by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA24040; Tue, 23 Mar 93 03:36:37 -0800
Message-Id: <9303231136.AA24040@soda.berkeley.edu>
From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf (Vitamin B))
Date: Tue, 23 Mar 1993 03:36:36 -0800
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: Dead Net Up Week

        Well, soda.berkeley.edu appears to have returned for a little while
at least - it's been having trouble with it's boot disk (for all you fellow
geeks out there, everything with /etc, /usr, /tmp, and /).  The have a new
disk so it should be mostly fixed - the FTP site remained largely unscathed
(except of the January archives which I'm getting a copy of from people, and
last May's archives which hopefully someone else has) so I've backed up the
archive off-line as well.  

        I am _still_ going to suggest that people use the 

        sfraves@sfraves.stanford.edu

        alias from now on.  It's faster and more reliable.  I may ask about 
moving the FTP site/archives there too when that machine gets upgraded.



	Okay, and now for my weekend update:  Friday was spent in the Twitch
studios showing SLC Big Wig Pete Ashdown the Twitch studios.  He came away
going, "I can't believe I turned down an offer to live with these people" so
I guess he liked it :):)  There was basically nothing else going on that 
night - Rhythm Empire looked way too commercial, a "breakin" it turns out was
going to try to use Charter Oak (without Mark's consent - we stoppped by
there and put an end to that hope of theirs), and the Vibe was at the stone,
so there was really nothing to get excited about. 

	Saturday night we went over to Wicked - I left early to help set up.
I had never been in 177 Townsend; it was an interesting space, but the bar
is featured a little too prominantly for my tastes.  Other gripes about the
space: the sound system was pretty shoddy to my ears, compared to others
I've heard (even right next door at the King St. Garage), and the DJ was 
tucked away in this small booth.  It didn't seem like the DJ's liked being
there either - all the closeness and attention the DJ gets when he's in 
front of the stage area like at Come/Unity is lost.  Somehow some drums found
their way to the dance floor and about three drummer syncopated to the
rhythms, which was the nicest part about the whole evening in my mind.  
The lighting was quite nice, even with that cheesy spinning-plane-of-
rainbow-light I last saw at the Edge.  But the fog was on overdrive and 
caused me to stop dancing more than once.... 

	The music was, er, interesting.  I liked what Markie played, even if
it seemed to confuse the dancers a bit :)  After his set I went to the upstairs
lounge and chilled for about an hour into Garth's set - I heard him play some
incredibly hard stuff, much harder than I would have expected; his second
half was slightly more mellow but still aggro compared to what he normally
plays.  I was shocked but I think it's a good thing..... Jeno's set was
great als always but he kept messing up at a couple of points (as did the
other DJ's).  I think the setup in the booth was really frustrating for them,
as the turntables are placed _behind_ the mixer rather than next to, causing
the DJ to reach abut 10 inches farther than usual.  Plus they are on a wooden
table about 10 inches from a huge woofer - recipe for trouble.  I didn't stay
for Thomas's set either, so I can't comment on the "morning vibe" which is
usually my favorite part of a rave.

	The GG Park thang was interesting - I got there around 3pm to find 
maybe 200 people there.  I would estimate at least 50, maybe 75 or 100 of those
were people who were just in Berkeley at the time or casual observers who got
sucked into the idea.  I think this is great, as most of these people were
the archtypical Berkeley "60's aren't over maaaan" types.  The DJ spinning when
I got there was Adonis, spinning an incredibly funky set, perfect for a 
Sunday outdoors thang.  This solidifies my conviction that there's so much
good talent out there it's scary.  At about 4:30 Jon Williams, not Garth,
took over (they both have long hair but Garth has a sharper face).  Now my
understanding was that it was moved to People's Park as a last-minute 
"well, we don't have any place to put it, is there a safe place we can put
it where we can say it's a political action and we won't be bothered" locale,
but I saw people wearing Tshirts saying "Sunday May 21st - a day of giving".
I asked one of those wearig the shirts what the story was, and he said this
had been planned for weeks.  Humm.  Whatever.   Also, there was a curious
lack of two things:  one, someone walking around to collect money for the
benefit (besides the usual Telegraph Ave. denizens) and no one was handing
out trashbags or cleaning up.  Now I know People's Park isn't a clean place
to begin with, but imagine what sort of impact cleaning the park would have!
Sadly, I saw no one do it, and _tons_ of trash everywhere.  I sure there would
have been some tweakers who would have had tons of extra energy to clean up
with :):)

Anyways, it was an average weekend...... next weekend I'll be in LA, but
I'm looking forawrd to Vision on the 3rd....

	Brian

Subject: Recycle


Hi again.

I was wondering what you all think about the Recycle weekly,
Wednesdays at the Stone...or if anyone has actually been there.

I stopped by last Wed., and found a decent crowd for the size (they
have walled off some of the club with plastic sheets - maybe for a
more intimate feel?), sets by Dutch, Carlos, and I can't quite
remember who else.

The crowd was a little younger, probably because it is an 18+ event
and Housing Project is 21+, also on Wed.  The attitude was
surprisingly laid-back; no one seemed to be too stressed about
anything (OK, so it was a Wednesday).

This week, the promoters Melissa, Kyle, and Laurie said they will
be donating the proceeds from any recyclables (requested at the
door for $2 off) to the Malachi fund.

Comments?

I went to Martin's Lift last Thursday at the Sound Factory and it
can be a cool place if the right people show up - good sound, 
well-designed (although perhaps overly designed).  I'm not sure
what Martin's doing wrong though, because not very many people
showed up, even though it was free.  At the peak, around 1 am,
there were maybe 100-150 people but only about 50 dancing, even
though the music was pretty good.  It tapered off quickly and
was down to about 50 people total by 2 and only a few dancing.
(whenever this happens, it seems like SFRavers end up being a 
majority of the people dancing :)   I think there's been enough
flyering for it, and Martin has a good reputation, so I guess it
must be the Sound Factory which has the bad reputation...

-Derek

one of the most interesting experiences i've had was going to GLIDE after
a full nite of raving. the vibe in the church was as friendly and positive as
what i've felt at the most friendly/fun rave i've been to. and the music
really cooks! and am not even xtian ! it also helps that cecil williams is
kinda easy and the j-man quotes and heavy on the spiritual part. i have not
been there recently, so can't tell  what is it like now, but the vibe is there.
take care/rave on/keep the vibe strong
ovid

Date: Tue, 23 Mar 93 12:54:52 -0800
Message-Id: <9303232054.AA12112@netcom.netcom.com>
X-Mailer:  Eudora
To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU
From: mcg@netcom.com (Tiamat the Chaos-Ocean)
Subject: Fog Machines (was Re: Dead Net Up Week)

Jon Drukman:

> i *like* that cheesy spinning-place-of-rainbow-light!  i don't like
> the fog though.  i've *never* liked it, but it seems to be de rigeur
> for some weird reason.

I agree!  What's the deal on these things?  Unlike what many people
believe, these fog machines do not use dry ice (which would be relatively
harmless and more effective) but some kind of liquid gunk that gets
atomized into particles and goes directly into our lungs.  Do you
really believe this stuff is safe to breathe?  Plus, it's a pretty
cheezy effect anyway -- give me strobes, intellibeams, projections,
lasers, etc. over this anytime.  I can't tell you how many times I've
been totally grooving on the production until the fog comes and spoils
it for me!

I can see using it maybe once or twice in a night, if the room is
ventilated well enough so that it clears out after a minute (not the
case with Townsend or King St.)  Above that it's really a nuisance --
far worse than whistles.

Do other people feel this way too?  You'd think with all the environmental
consciousness in the scene people would be concerned about this.  I've
talked to a few promoter/friends about this, but they believe it adds to
the "atmosphere" (cough, gasp!)  Maybe if a bunch of us get together and
call more attention to it, they'll start phasing it out...  Let's leave this
dinosaur effect to the industrial scene and look to the future!

----____----____--__--__--__--__-_-_-_-_-_-__--__--__--__--____----____----
        MykL G                Use your wings.        mcg@netcom.com
____----____----__--__--__--__--_-_-_-_-_-_--__--__--__--__----____----____

Date: Tue, 23 Mar 93 15:04:09 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>

Re: townsend audio system.... 

When i was at the recent audio eng. society show in SF, i stopped by a 
booth that had an interesting kind of subwoofer. it was operated by an
electric servo motor with a "camshaft" that translated the servo's
rotational motion into pistonic motion, and that was coupled to the
speaker cone to  drive it back-and-forth. They claimed this could
deliver huge amounts  of subsonic energy in a very efficient manner.

As to how the servo control electronics could accelerate and decelerate
the rotational mass quickly enough to generate nonsinusoidal
waveforms... don't know. It's possible  that they just assume that
you'll be generating sinusoids from 10-60Hz with the higher harmonics
being filtered out by the crossover and reproduced by a normal woofer.
(which sounds incredibly tricky... esp. with the phase-lag inherent in
a servo system).

If anybody really gives a shit, i can probably dig up the name of the
manufacturer.

Anyways, I asked them who uses their system and they mentioned that
townsend does...

PS: speaking of soundsystems, whatever they used at the first GG-Park
event wthis year was damn nifty -- someone with good taste in audio
eqiupment put the system togehter, and it was pretty clear that they
didn't have a limited budget.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==           Niels Mayer -- Mayer Design Media Associates, Inc.   :-)      ==
==				mayer@netcom.com                           ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

chemical fog is made out of a PETROLEUM-BASED GUNK that gets heated
until it vaporizes.  i had a chance to get Up Close And Personal with
a rented fog machine when my friend threw a "cyberpunk" party several
years ago.  pretty much convinced me that one should avoid these
machines as much as possible.

>I can see using it maybe once or twice in a night, if the room is
>ventilated well enough so that it clears out after a minute (not the
>case with Townsend or King St.)  Above that it's really a nuisance --
>far worse than whistles.

well, if you rent the machine, you can't return the excess goo, so the
tendency is to use it all up in one night.

>Do other people feel this way too?  You'd think with all the environmental
>consciousness in the scene people would be concerned about this.  I've
>talked to a few promoter/friends about this, but they believe it adds to
>the "atmosphere" (cough, gasp!)

bulldada!  i *like* to see the people in the crowd.  nothing bums me
out more than getting lost in a cloud of sweet-smelling chemical crud.
how can you make contact with a smiling face if all you can see is a
white haze?

>Maybe if a bunch of us get together and
>call more attention to it, they'll start phasing it out...  Let's leave this
>dinosaur effect to the industrial scene and look to the future!

yay!  i'm going to mention it to the promoters i know and maybe in a
short while we'll start seeing rave flyers with "NO SMOKE MACHINE!"
printed on them.

From: John S. Lee <jslee@well.sf.ca.us>
Message-Id: <199303240157.AA21736@well.sf.ca.us>
To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Environs, SM's, etc.


It's always interesting to see what people think about the various parties.
I had heard nothing but good things about the Wicked event, and the things
that went on the next day as well. Hmmm...

Well you can't blame wicked for a shoddy crowd.  First off they held the
event at TOWNSEND, and when you hold events in the front of that place you
tend to get a TOWNSEND crowd.  This account for the SM's (Shirtless Males)
scouting about.

As for the TOWNSEND sound system (I know I am gonna piss someone off now),
it's OK, but it ain't great.  I'd rather have the M&M highs&mids coupled
with the Community 415's bass bins.  This provides (when all is said and
done) a system that meets or exceeds the expectations of the serious
dancer/ravaholic.  Plus the system is clean.

The front of TOWNSEND was REALLY not meant for thelikes of
Garth,Jeno,Markie, & Thomas since their sound system (TOWNSEND'S that is)
cannot handle the levels these guys tend to drive.  Next time they are
closer to the dance floor check out the VU meters.  Markie & Jeno esp.
drive the fuck out of a system.  Unlike most DJ's though they do it evenly.
Some like SPUN, pump up the bass (usually by playing with the onboard eq) so
fucking loud it distorts.  TOWNSEND should have done a proper soundcheck
with the boys to adjust their system to accomodate the levels they are used
to playing at.  Garth tends to be fairly even...Thomas varies, I have heard
him play the MOST tweeter oriented music bound to bring blood to the ears at
times.  The last time I heard him play was when wicked FIRST moved to
Townsend Garage.  That, as well as the otyher played incredible sets.

Last time Wicked was in the TOWNSEND space a similar event happened.  The
sound began to distort.  I just think that the front needs to adjust to the
playing style of the DJ, not the opposite.

As for all the environmental BS with fog machines...fog is the way!  There
is NOTHING more psychedelic than a nice laser, PLENTY of fog, some cool
lights.  This is TRUE underground acid.  The true atmosphere.  I love it.  I
get annoyed by it as well at times, but overall the effect (esp when
altered) is mind-boggling.  You're in your own world, and you must admit
sometimes that is wehre we all want to be.

The lights in the front are a bit corny, that is because the front is REALLY
geared towards a more stylish crowd (as in gay, as in beautiful people, as
in suits).  Parties have the option of not turning on any of those lights.
The person running the show creates the environ and they have control.

I have a question...what IS everyones favorite spot, or at least the spot
where they have had the most fun/memorable experience?

Peace.

In-Reply-To: <9303240420.AA01542@lila.us.oracle.com>; from "Robert Jesse" at Mar 23, 93 8:20 pm

I vote NO on fog machines.  Late last year, I was at a Wicked in King St.
that made extensive (like, two stints of 45 minutes each) use of fog.  The
day after, I couldn't stop coughing...and didn't for a week.  That stuff
fucked me up, and bad.  I run out of joints that use fog machines now, as
fast as I can.  I will NOT get sick because of anybody's "cool".

Some of you all may be less sensitive than I am (and this is the first
"environmental" illness I've ever had), but if I get blasted by this stuff,
you can imagine that others will, too.

BryceR
TAZ 1260
"It makes me wanna scream!"

Date: Tue, 23 Mar 93 20:20:20 -0800
From: Robert Jesse <rnj@us.oracle.com>
Message-Id: <9303240420.AA01542@lila.us.oracle.com>
Received: by NeXT.Mailer (1.87.1)
Received: by NeXT Mailer (1.87.1)
To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: Fog Machines, fog juice
Reply-To: rnj%lila@us.oracle.com

>I'd like to add my voice to the NO smoke machines movment.

>I kind of like the fog, especially when the lasers are going.  But I do
>wonder what it's actually composed of!

ok, i don't like the stuff when it's overused, either.  i have, though, seen  
it put to great effect.  at one time DV8 had (still has?) an obscenely large  
number of Dataflash mounted here and there - two 5x5 matrices on one wall,  
and dozens more overhead - in a room not all that huge.  once in the evening,  
the crew loaded up the room with really dense fog, and strobed all of the  
Dataflash on *full power* simultaneously.  instant whiteout!   intense  
radiation, but with no detail - couldn't see my hand in front of my face.   
way cool - and the effect was used only briefly, while the blast of fog was  
at its densest.

about Fog:  one of the machines you see around a lot is the Lightwave  
Research F-100. the company sells a fog juice called Atmospheres for use with  
this machine.  here are a few paragraphs from their literature:

"Atmospheres lighting enhancement fluid is a water based fluid that was  
formulated in 1986.  The F-100 Performance Smoke Generator was subsequently  
designed to work with the fluid.  It is manufactured with U.S.P. food grade  
components under stringent conditions to insure a high level of purity.  Each  
container used in the manufacturing process is used exclusively for that  
purpose to reduce the risk of introducing any contaminants into the final  
product.  The water used in the formula is processed through mixed bed  
de-ionizers [....] Carbon based additives such as flavored scents and colored  
dyes are specifically not used because the sticky, gummy residues that they  
leave behind will cause blockage in the heat exchanger.

"Atmospheres is not colored, but it is lightly scented because most users  
prefer some scent.  Lightwave Research lab technicians conducted lengthy  
tests and developed a proprietary scent from [a] wide variety of scent  
samples.  It was specifically selected for its low carbon content and its low  
outgassing properties, which result in less residual deposits.  For these  
reasons, the warranty for the F-100 fog machine is only valid if it is being  
used exclusively with Atmospheres smoke fluid.  The Atmospheres formula is  
non-toxic and contains polyfunctional alcohols that are commonly used in the  
food industry as a thickening agent for various products such as cream soda  
and vanilla extract."

of course, this is not to say that all fog we encounter in clubs are made  
with as much apparent care as this stuff....

             <199303240454.AA11603@well.sf.ca.us> 
Date: Tue, 23 Mar 93 23:57:03 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>

Bryce Ryan <brycer@well.sf.ca.us>
>I vote NO on fog machines.  Late last year, I was at a Wicked in King St.
>that made extensive (like, two stints of 45 minutes each) use of fog.  The
>day after, I couldn't stop coughing...and didn't for a week.  That stuff
>fucked me up, and bad.  I run out of joints that use fog machines now, as
>fast as I can.  I will NOT get sick because of anybody's "cool".
>
>Some of you all may be less sensitive than I am (and this is the first
>"environmental" illness I've ever had), but if I get blasted by this stuff,
>you can imagine that others will, too.

I've had the same reaction on 2-3 occasions, though the coughing only
lasted for a few days... I believe two of the occasions were Wicked at
the King St. location. For this reason, I often leave or stop dancing
when the fog machine kicks in. On those occasions, I also happened
to observe that when I blew my nose, there was black/brown/mud-colored
mucus indicating that I'd inhaled alot of dust.

In addition to being spewers of foul chemical pollutants, I believe fog
machines also have the potential of being effective transport for
viruses and bacteria that happened to be growing or extant in the
fog-water. There's a good chance that nasties which might never have
made it when exposed to air get a free ride on an atomized water
droplet; when inhaled, those droplets can transfer nasties right into
your lungs. This is conjecture on my part... comments?

So... unless they fill the fog machines with hash oil, I too think we
should just say no to fog machines.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==           Niels Mayer -- netcom!mayer -- mayer@netcom.com               ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Subject: fog machines
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu

i recently bought a fog machine and the dealer told me the gunk he sold was
'water' based, but there must be something else in it-wonder what? i clean
it periodically with plain water and nothing comes out but hot air (no fog,
no steam). fog is necessary, without it the 'beams' from lights and lasers
cannot be seen since there the particle level in the air is low. smoking
lots of cigarettes might be an alternative, but second-hand actual 'smoke'
can only be worse. too much fog is a problem however, but some fog is
necessary to maximise lighting effects.

fog machines are not a problem, the people who abuse them are!

dan (milwaukee)

Date: 24 Mar 1993 10:39:22 -0700
From: "Stewart, Scott*" <stewart#m#_scott*@msgate.corp.apple.com>
Subject: My  $0.02 on FOG.
To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU



I am inbetween on the Fog, I am with those people who think Fog with light add
cool effects but I also think that conservation is the key and also adds to the
affects.

Here are two experiences that I had with lighting and

I was at a Sharon Rave in Tracy on a large ranch where there was a few strobes
and a fog machine by the DJ.  I was standing a distance away (30 meters) and
they started playing the Opera Techno tune (forgot the name) at the same time
the introduced some fog into the crowd and used the strobes.  Watching this
from a distance while hearing this tune for the first time was awsome, I will
always remember it.  When I describe my best raves I always describe this
scene.  By the way the dancers were going crazy.

Another time I was at King Street and they did the Usual smokeout, I'll admit
they did this a little to often.  I was dancing on the dance floor Jumping all
around.  I thought I was bymyself, I couldnt see another soul as the fog
disapated there were people right up close to me.  It was bizzare and cool.

I was at Wicked last weekend and everytime I went out onto the dancefloor, the
humidity, lights, smoke, fog and especially the pumping music sent me through
the roof.

FLAME ON!

I belevie if you Smoke cigarretes you cant complain about the Fog Machines. 
FLAME OFF.

NUT

From: mcg@netcom.com (Tiamat the Chaos-Ocean)
Subject: SF Permit Madness

Maybe we ravers aren't being singled out for this recent wave of permit
extortion, after all.

I saw a story on the local news last night about the growing trend in
SF coffee houses of having open poetry readings.  This trend has been
nipped in the bud by city officials, who cracked down and started demanding
$800 permits for this activity.  One coffee house, the Blue Monkey, was
able to fork over this sum, but many others were forced to stop holding
these readings.

$800 for the privilege of reading poetry out loud?  Where can this insanity
possibly end?

Are any of you college-age ravers thinking of law school?

----____----____--__--__--__--__-_-_-_-_-_-__--__--__--__--____----____----
        MykL G                Use your wings.        mcg@netcom.com

Here's the prospective text for the back of the Connection II j-card:

all in all, rave is the greatest antidote yet for urban anonymity.
when you open your heart, and trust the whole group you dance with;
when you feel love with everyone, and they return it, a higher
vibration can be reached.  dance is the supreme gesture of abandon,
the embrace of the moment, the abeyance of work and the annihilation
of guilt, neurosis, and the burden of the past.  no one can write a
{\em rave manifesto}\ldots there is no unified voice to rave culture,
and there are no rules.  ranting is the opposite of raving.  remember,
the scene is still growing.  just keep it going, don't give up hope.
you might think to yourself sometimes, man, the scene is fucked, it's
dying, it's changing, it's shit.  just hang in there and change with
the times.  don't get caught up in the good old days.  they were good
but keep the scene happening all around the world.  to rave is to
affirm.

Most of this is from the compilation of sfraves quotes that doom made.
I want everything to be anonymous, i.e. non attributed, so this mail
message is cc'ed to the authors of the various portions, when known
and online:

all in all, rave is the greatest antidote yet for urban anonymity.
  -- AstroBoy rpcaras@srv.pacbell.com
dance is...
  -- Russell A. Potter rapotter@colby.edu
no one can write a rave manifesto... there is no unified voice to rave
  culture, and there are no rules.
  -- Kevin Goldsmith kmg@cilmi.esd.sgi.com (is this email address right?)
ranting is the opposite of raving.
  -- Bill Coderre bc@apple.com
remember, the scene is still growing.
  -- Howard Ching howard@netcom.com
to rave is to affirm.
  -- Arthur Chandler arthurc@sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu

non-net stuff:
when you open your heart... a higher vibration can be reached.
  -- HOUSE MUSIC and PLANETARY HEALING
just keep it going...
  -- DJ Abel, UOS #7

I'd really appreciate it if the authors could get back to me as soon
as possible and let me know if they mind me using their quote -- non
attributed -- in the fashion referenced above, i.e. that paragraph
will appear pretty much verbatim on the back of the j card.  If you
have a way of contacting the non-net references above, please contact
me right away too -- I can be reached at work at (415) 506-2784.

Other things on the back of the j-card will include a reference to
this event being thrown by a "cybertribe", that it was held in the
rain, and that the DJs worked under very harsh circumstances, which
was very appreciated by the crowd, but might have affected a mix or
two here and there.

There will also be an explicit reference to the tapes being recorded
with HX pro, and to playback without any noise reduction engaged.

"Salvador Dali: Dream Caused by the Flight of a Bee around a
Pomegranate, a Second before Waking Up, 1944" will also appear in the
j card text, as this is the 4 color image on the front of the j card.

So -- if you are an author, please send email as soon as you can and
let me know if you would prefer that I not use your quote.  If you
know one of the non-net authors, or a net address for one of these
people, please get a hold of me as soon as possible.

Otherwise, if you have any suggestions or additions for improvements
for the j card text, let me know, I'd love some feedback, which is why
I posted this to sfraves... the j card text will be going to the
printer very very soon!

Later on,

Bob Ramstad, Pleasure Seeker
boccibob%groovy@us.oracle.com (preferred) or rramstad@us.oracle.com

This city is definantly permit-happy.  About 3 weeks ago I was talking
to a street performer up at pier 39 and he told me that in addition to
the city required street entertainer permit, which is free for some
types of act and not for others, the businesses around the Wharf had
some kind of deal with each other and the city hall that requires a
separate permit to operate up there.  And they actually use the
gestapolice to enforce it.

From: Bob Ramstad <rramstad@us.oracle.com>
To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU
Subject: one last c2 thang
Reply-To: boccibob%groovy@us.oracle.com


To clear up any confusion: the lion's share of profits from these
tapes will go to Malachy.  Everything is still pretty up in the air,
especially as I don't know the ultimate number of orders (and probably
never will :-) but I'm guaranteeing that regardless of the overall
situation (i.e. if I lose money due to problems selling all the sets
made) that at least $5 per set will go to Malachy.  I'm not looking to
make a killing, if I do make a profit, it will be a reasonable profit
based on the amount of effort and time that I put into putting the
cassettes together and dealing with all the hassles and orders.

Sorry if this wasn't absolutely clear.  Even the price per set isn't
totally firmed up yet -- it depends a lot on the number of sets sold.
I may risk about $3K to get a bigger batch of tapes made so that the
overall price will decline -- but that will put me at a bigger risk as
well.

Just mulling it over, and thought I'd share.  In any case, I'll post a
full financial disclosure statement to this list sometime in mid May
or so once I've settled everything in stone, so you'll be able to see
exactly how much money was given to Malachy and so forth.

Later on,
Bob

> nipped in the bud by city officials, who cracked down and started demanding

> these readings.

> 
> Maybe we ravers aren't being singled out for this recent wave of permit
> extortion, after all.
> 

I just want to add something to Mykl. As some of you already know I was
planning to do a big benefit rave in GG park on April the 10th. I tried
to get a permit following the right procedure.
This is what happen:
They told me to send a letter with all the info about my event.
In the meantime the put down my name to hold the place (The Band Shell).
I sent the letter specifying that was for benefit and I also mention
the charity group and a contact in this group. Of course I didn't say
it was a rave but just a dance benefit party.
After two week I called few times and finally they told me that they
didn't get any letter. So I promptly fax it. They said they were gonna
call me. I called and finally they told me how much would have cost me:

	$300 one day fee (unrefundable)
	$2,000 deposit (refundable)
	17% or $250 out of the money collected (it doesn't matter
			if is for charity)
	$1,000,000 proof of insurance (I asked my agent and he
			said that he could find someone to do it
			but it would be at least $500)
	sound permit (from SFPD)

The woman said, "if you are still interested you should come here and we can
talk about it". She really sounded like she was trying to make it impossible.
In fact I had to give up (at least for now) because, even if I could get
DJ's and sound system for free (or almost), it would have been not worthy
(not much money left for charity). Basically she didn't care that was 
for charity at all.


					Gianmaria

Subject: Breathing Permits


If I lived in San Francisco, I would do some things:
1) Call the Police Department and find out which laws give them authority
   to bust poetry readings.  The whole thing may turn out to be bogus.
2) When the law is found, organize reading/protest in front of City Hall
   and the police department.  This would be fun!  Just when we thought
   that words had become impotent and flabby, they regain their power to
   cause emotions.
3) Mail lots of poetry to various City Council members with the notation:
   "WHY IS IT ILLEGAL TO SAY THIS IN A COFFEEHOUSE?"  Pick classical stuff
   that conservative people would like.
4) Imagine the press.  "POETS JAILED FOR READING EMILY DICKINSON"

Once the facts are known, the media can be well used to your advantage.
Since poets look awfully innocent next to the current demonized class of
drug users, publicity is probably a Good Thing.  

// g

> $800 for the privilege of reading poetry out loud?  Where can this insanity
> possibly end?
> 
> Are any of you college-age ravers thinking of law school?
> 

Folks,
	I think its time that we seriously think of banding together,
	raising money, if necessary and trying the city's hand with
	some of these things.  Someee of these fee border on extortion
	and seem to come very close to interfering with our right to 
	peaceable assembly.  Lawyers are not cheap but maybe we can
	find some young ones who can represent our cause  "at cost".
	We may be moving toward a situation like in Milwaukee (I hope not)
	where the city gets so bold as to arrest the lot of us at an event.
	I hope it doesn't take something like this to galvanize us into
	political action like it took the Malachy tragedy to get us all to
	focus our heart energies and reflect on just why we are all here.

and listen to polka music, (don't get me wrong, sometime I really crave a 
good polka,;)), in the park, and not get hassled, and folks who listen to 
a different drummer do, something is wrong, then perhaps we can see if the ACLU
would like to get involved with our problem.

	First, I'd like to say Hello to everyone on the list.  I've been
	getting it since soda came up (prayers to the silicon gods!) and am
	glad that there is a forum like this to promote commUnity here in
	the Bay Area.  (Thanks Brian!)

	Secondly, I've been laying really low (I've actually been on a
	healing binge) since January when I went to the Sound Factory for
	the first time.  It was part of a long farewell weekend to a good
	friend who's moved to Oregon. 

	Anyway, my impressions then were mixed: the before 2:00am crowd 
	was _too_ cool - all dressed up with everywhere to go.  It was also
	hard to find good chill out space.  Post 2:00am people were vibe.  I
	met a few really cool people that night.  I was really impressed
	with the sound: the suspended tweeters and ceiling fills are great
	as well as the immense subs (try sitting inside of one with your
	back up against the speaker!)  I don't know how things have changed
	since then (have been too far removed until recently), but I think
	that was the Love Factory night.  Is it still Life/Sound Factory/Love
	Factory?

	Lastly, I was able to catch Garth on KSCU and found it hella-cool.
	It started the vibe tingle in the base of my neck again and I'm
	looking forward to a really good party to reintroduce myself to.
	Any suggestions in the forthcoming month?

	-p&l

-bS						"A happy face,
brians@ios.convergent.com			 a funkin' bass,
A lowly raver without a glowstick.		 for a loving race."
**************************************************************************

Hi everyone...
I have a slight problem that requires some creative energy to resolve.

I am a frequent user of vrave. Unfortunately, the sysadmin from the site at which 
I make the telnet connection sees a log file that says:
     plui... telnet 76.0.... 7282
Upon seeing this,  it is assumed by the sysadmin that I am playing a game.
Yesterday I received an email from him saying that if I log into this game site
again... my account will be disabled.  :(

He said that if I can prove it is not a game site (or a MUD site, what is MUD anyways!!!), 
then he would be so kind as to not disable my account. :|

How can I describe vrave? It really isn't a game. Is it MUD? 

what a dilema!
Any help is much appreciated.

-Cato
 plui@iossvr.gm.hac.com

(the technobird doesn wanna get his vrave wings clipped)

This is madness! madness! I can see it now... I'm walking down the
street w/ my girlfriend, and suddenly burst forth into Iambic
Pentameter. When... out of the bushes spring our trusty men in blue!!

	Pig: Son, do you have a poetry reading permit?
	Me: No sir! Actually, I was't reading, i was improvising...
	Pig: Aha! you need a street-performers permit for that!
	Me: Gee, I didn't know. I was just talking.
	Pig: Ignorance is no excuse. Hands behind your head and lie down on
	the ground... You have the right to remain silent.... anything you
	do or say will be used against you whenever we feel like it....

Just a note before I plow through 800+ pieces of mail...

Thanks to everyone who made my spring break so grand!

Brian, Greg, Cindy, Mike W., Jon, Leah, Taylor, Stevie, Jeff, CJ, Robert,
Geoff, Derrick, Moonpup, and all of San Francisco!

I had a great time at Wicked, a somewhat mediocre time at Together, was blown
away by Bonnie Doon, got a grand tour of the Twitch studios and mansion, had
fun on Haight, spent way too much money on *gasp* vinyl, and found some
vicious new sunglasses.

Apologies to everyone who I didn't get to meet up with.  Next time I'll warn
everyone I'm coming :-).

I would recommend talking to the ACLU before the riots begin ;^)
I dealt with them in college and they were very nice.  Someone should be
able to get a meeting with a representative who will be fairly knowledgeable
and will decide if the ACLU would get involved further.

What evidence is there that this is discrimination based on music?  If 
there is none then I would try the right to peaceably assemble angle.

My hunch is that unless the ACLU does see a civil liberties infringment
then there isn't much that can be done.  Those fees probably got jacked
up in the last few years when money for the city has been tight.

You may even get some good advice just over the phone.
Does the ACLU have email?
The local chapter guy that I spoke with (in LA) was a college prof.

Dave

From: Derek Chung <dhchung@us.oracle.com>

I'm a (card-carrying) member of the ACLU, and I've even gone to a 
couple meetings of the local chapter.  I can't really say I have any
pull or personal contacts there, but I'm somewhat familiar with what
kind of cases they're interested in, and how they're organized.  

I think in order to have them do something, we would have to have
an example of a clear infringement of our civil liberties, and a
test case or some way we could set up a test case.  I have the info
number for the local chapter with me, where someone could leave a
message - it's (415) 979-6699.  That's the SF chapter, which is 
really more of an activist group, while the ACLU Northern California
is the organization which actually handles court cases.  I can
get that number from home, if we come up with something we can
go to them with.

-Derek

:) I am a frequent user of vrave. Unfortunately, the sysadmin from the site at which 
:) I make the telnet connection sees a log file that says:
:)      plui... telnet 76.0.... 7282
:) Upon seeing this,  it is assumed by the sysadmin that I am playing a game.
:) Yesterday I received an email from him saying that if I log into this game site
:) He said that if I can prove it is not a game site (or a MUD site, what is MUD anyways!!!), 

Ya, we have the same problem here at SFU... Our sysadmin vanepp classifies
vrave as a game... A MUD is a mulit user dungeon.. an internet site with
multiple players that runs a dungeons and dragons like text simulation. As for
proving that it's not a game, it depends on what your sysadmin defines a game
as ( here it's anything not-academic ).... good luck... #(*& bureaucracy...

Feyd

I think in order to have them do something, we would have to have
an example of a clear infringement of our civil liberties, and a
test case or some way we could set up a test case.  I have the info
number for the local chapter with me, where someone could leave a
message - it's (415) 979-6699.  That's the SF chapter, which is
really more of an activist group, while the ACLU Northern California
is the organization which actually handles court cases.  I can
get that number from home, if we come up with something we can
go to them with.

-Derek

I was in D.C. for Interop and went to check out a couple of clubs
(thanks Susie and Rob for the info).

Tracks: very young crowd and the music was way too fast and techno for me.
I'm either getting too old or I just changed my taste so much.

Club Zei: there was the release party for this fashion/music magazine
called "Project X". The club is really nice (sort of like DV8 in SF)
and the people were tipical club-scene people, not bad but not particularly
interesting.

Anyway the interesting thing was that on the issue that they were giving away
(#24) these is an article about the Hardkiss Family.

***************************************************************************

For the Hardkiss Family
=======================

San Francisco's incredible underground dance scene is inspired by and 
simultaneously transcends the concept of "RAVE" and now there is a record
label which reflects this uniqueness.
Currently, San Francisco has been experiencing a regeneration of late
60's HIPPIE CULTURE and its dance scene today is an incredible diverse mix
of IDEALISTIC AND SPIRITUAL REVELERS.
The S.F. scene is radically different from its glossy, exploitative Southern
cousin, Los Angeles - it is a smaller, a more focused, and trully idyllic 
community.
Free parties in the sunny Golden Gate Park every Sunday afternoon and 
illegal monthly tribal gatherings under the full moon are typical of San
Francisco's celebrations.
Likewise, the musical taste of this city is unlike that of any other people
- its grooves are trancey, funky and very very trippy. The local DJs are
treated as techno-shamans, and the events often generate a truly magical
energy which must be experienced to be believed.
At the forefront of this movement are the Hardkiss revolutionaries -
a growing family of musicians, producers, DJs, artists and promoters
who are setting fire to a few million ears and hearts.
Hardkiss has brought together many of the world's finest dance artists
and DJs together in a continuing series of legendary events - all part
of struggle towards mass musical transformation.
Their unique collaborative sound is reflected in the label's debut 
release "THE TRIP", by the ULTRA - VIOLET CATASTROPHE. The UVC is a pseudonym 
for MIKE WERTHEIM, JON DRUKMAN and JEFF TAYLOR, the boys responsible for
the highly successful remix service Twich. This talented trio will be the 
in-house engineering and production team for all future Hardkiss releases.
Lok out for a (very) different Hardkiss Music release every month and 
meanwhile ....
			KISS HARDER.

***************************************************************************

					Gianmaria

Subject: This week's RAVE guide

	Hmmm... kinda slim pickins this weekend.  Make a Wish sounds good for
Friday night - Rick Preston annd Moonpup are the two most severely underrated
DJ's in the SF scene.  TTTTT has been flyered to hell, and sounds like it is
being run by the same people as Rhythm Empire (any bets it's at 16th and
Harrison? Hm?  :)  Raw Sugar definitely has the DJ talent factor on high...
but STAY AWAY from X-LAX.  What an AWFUL name for a rave.

	Saturday: if you happen to find yourself in Salt Lake City with
nothing to do there's this shindig going on there :)  Pure and Juice are
both outfits who have thrown large events before with mixed results, so
caveat emptor...

	Of course, we have Sunday to provide our salvation in the form of
the Golden Gate park thang. 

	Enjoy!


	Brian

good. If anyone can provide reviews of them, i.e., their 
appropriateness in being on the list, let me know....

From: tgrant@netcom.com (Tony Grant)

To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU

Well, I've been lurking for about a month now, and figured I'd jump in and join
the fray.  I'd read in several places about "ravers" getting the latest info
through computer networks, but until I met Brian, I'd never run into anyone who
could confirm this.  Anyway, this is a very groovy, very positive community, and
I'm looking forward to matching faces to the characters that I now only know by
name.  =)

I am one half of the visual crew Synergy, so if you see some trippy computer
graphics w/video, find the projector, and trace the wires over to our little
station (pay no attention to the man behind the curtain...  ) and say hello.
We're also both musicians trying to mine the deep ambient vibe, so I'm
particularly interested in talking shop with the others on the list who make
music.

Lee posted a message asking about Mission Rock...
We've been working there every week since it reopened, and it really is quite a
happening party- a nice appetizer for Friday night.  I'm really impressed with
James- I've yet to hear him spin a bad set.  Anyway, the doors open at about 10,
and it really picks up and gets kicking at about 12.  Unfortunately, I don't
think it's going to happen this week, as someone had previously booked the space
(but please don't take this as gospel-- I'll post again tomorrow when I find out
for sure)

Thanks in advance for more lively discussion and I look forward to meeting lots
of you and someday learning the secret handshake  =)

Dance, dance, dance,

Tony
(tgrant@netcom)

From sfraves-request@medisg.Stanford.EDU  Fri Mar 26 04:27:07 1993

Received: from remarque.berkeley.edu by medisg.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA18470; Fri, 26 Mar 93 03:55:13 PST
Received: by remarque.berkeley.edu (4.1/1.31)
	id AA16732; Fri, 26 Mar 93 03:55:12 PST
Date: Fri, 26 Mar 93 03:55:12 PST
From: nineball@remarque.berkeley.edu (9ball)
Message-Id: <9303261155.AA16732@remarque.berkeley.edu>
To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Recycle, last night


Went and gave Recycle at the Stone another chance Wednesday
night, and ended up having a really great time.  This is
starting to be a really decent alternative for a Wednesday
night, what with all the rumors about Housing Projects recent
decline and all.

Got a chance to meet yet another of our many sfravers (you know who
you are!) who also seemed to be having quite some fun.

There were at least a coupla hundred people there last night
with a huge turnout of recycled goods to be cashed in and
donated to the Malachi fund, stretching almost the whole length
of the lower hallway.  Again a somewhat younger crowd, probably
because of the 21+ Housing Proj, but definitely very little
attitude to be seen.

As for the tunes, Carlos was pulling off (for the most part)
some amazing scratching done with two copies of the same record,
where he'd fade in a table, scratch one heavy beat over the
other copy of the record and let it go in perfect time, fade it
in completely, grab the other copy, find the same beat, scratch
IT and let it go seamlessly, over and over.

Then came Ghost.  He had rumoredly promised to do his new house
set but changed his mind when he stepped up.  Man, he started
spinning the MOST vicious Belgian techno I've never heard
"SCREEEEEEP SCREEEEEEP YA! YA! ICH NEIN DER UBERLAND! SCREEEEEP
SCREEEEEP" you know the score.  Mixes in none other than phrases
from that old A-Ha tune Take On Me, just going craazy.  He's even
got these wide-eyed women with "GHOST" hats on leaning over
the DJ booth sucking it up.  Didn't last long before one of the
promoters gently (whack) reminded him of his promise and of
the feel they were trying to keep with the party, and he mellowed
out.  Good thing to hear every now and then, but it sure does
grate after a while.

Check this one out sometime.

To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU
Subject: more about fog
From: Desi the Three-Armed Wonder Comic <jondr@sco.com>
Sender: jondr@sco.com
Date: Fri, 26 Mar 93 15:09:39 PST
Message-Id:  <9303261509.aa23724@scotty.sco.COM>

so i asked scott hardkiss about fog machines.  (the hardkisses run
deep faith on thursdays at the DNA, and other parties from time to
time.)  actually, what i said was, "i'm on a crusade to stamp out fog
machines" and he said, "well, you'll have to get by me first."  he
loves them.  he says he fondly remembers the first toon towns where
they'd fill the place up with fog, blast the strobe lights and drop
the bass hard.  i said, "that sort of effect is great but nobody does
that these days.  they just leave the thing on until you're choking in
a big cloud of crud."  he said, "yeah, we probably should ease up on
it a little, but we do loooove our fog!"  he went on to tell me how a
typical club night can use $50 - $100 worth of fog juice and it does
come included in the price of renting the club.  in fact, one week
they were going to do Deep Faith and there wasn't the usual amount.
they went ballistic on the club owner and there's been a full amount
of fog juice every week since.  :)

i understand that you need foggy air to get the full effect from
lights/lasers, but i think most clubs are already so damn smoky from
all the cigarettes that you don't need to lean on the fog machine like
some places do.  just turn it on for a short time every once in a
while.

anyway, my conversation with scott didn't exactly convince him to
throw the machine out but at least i got him thinking about it...

Jon Drukman (in stereo where available)                         jondr@sco.com

If you want to touch the sky, just put a window in your eye.           - Coil

	id AA18387; Fri, 26 Mar 93 09:46:57 -0800
Date: Fri, 26 Mar 93 09:46:57 -0800
From: diva@uclink.berkeley.edu (Leah Jane Reich)
Message-Id: <9303261746.AA18387@uclink.berkeley.edu>
To: nineball@remarque.berkeley.edu, sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: Recycle, last night


my friend laura and I checked recycle out too.  actually, first we went
to hp but decided that we could not deal with the club scene/attitude.
(oh, and hi mykl and it was nice to meetch niels! =)  sooo, being the
adventurous type, we hopped a cab to the stone, knowing full well that we
had no way back to the east bay until the 6:00 bart but not really caring.

we were so glad we did!  immediately we knew things were gonna be good -
the doorman was so friendly and I gave him my flower (my favorite kind -
a calla lilly) and went in. the crowd was really young, but everyone was
really friendly.  it cheered me up immensely.  I got to meet another 
sfraver =)))).  I did see some attitude, but it was that "hi I'm in high
school but I'm out at a club so that makes me queen of the universe"
attitude.  kinda funny but it does grate.  that, and the heat, were really
my only complaints.  I also kinda like a younger crowd sometimes...

anyway, the music was really good - and I even liked the beginning of
ghost's set.  actually, I liked it a lot!  it had been forever since I'd
heard music like that - and it really energized me and made me go go go!
made me really really happy too - it was so funky and fun!  I guess I'm
the type who likes techno, etc when it's a novelty, as a break from the
music I normally hear.  after a while, I go a little nuts, but just the
right amount and it's great!  one minor music flaw - I didn't like it when
the techno and the house were mixed together.  I can't get into music w/a
groove + the hard edge of techno.  it really doesn't work, imo.  

but overall, I really had a great time.  and laura did too (she was/still
sorta is a virgin raver).  she really liked it - and she could tell the
difference between hp and recycle.  now she knows why I loooove going out!
she's visiting me from colorado and she'll be with me all weekend, so be
sure to say hi and convince her to move out here! =)  heh heh....


so that's leah's long winded review =)

have a delicious day!

always, leah

----------------------------Original message----------------------------
        Everyone be sure to be on V-RAVE the night of Friday the 26th
after midnight or so, EST.  We will have a terminal hooked up to v-rave
at Sunshine, a little microrave Susie and Doug from AU in Washington DC
are putting on.  It should be really cool.
        For those that don't know about v-rave, just

telnet sfraves.stanford.edu 7282

        Do it now, because your account will have to be validated.  It's
just an irc-style chatting system.  Let's see how many cool vibes we can
create at Sunshine!

Stone Design is planning another rave for Wednesday, May 26th in San

	(1.37.109.4/MCL.UCSB-HP-16.5) id AA18392; Sat, 27 Mar 93 14:48:11 -0800
From: *SAGE* <ulvbiskt@mcl.mcl.ucsb.edu>
Subject: 175mg of reality
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Date: Sat, 27 Mar 93 14:48:10 PST
Mailer: Elm [revision: 70.85]

                I've been on sfraves for a little while now and most
		of the time I just kind of sit back and sift the vibes
                ,kind of taking the pulse of the rave community and
		seeing what kinds of things people have to say. Most
                of the time there isn't anything outrageously intere-
		sting for me to say other than elaborating on everyone 
		elses opinions, which is terribly boring. So just this
		once. :)
		After having lived in sf all my life and spending the 
		last couple years actively participating in the rave scene
		I moved to Santa Barbara in September to finish jumping 
		through the bureaucratic hoops at UCSB(bachelors degree.)
		Occasionally there are local pseudo-raves here and there's
		always the heavily wrought-out guerilla rave scene of LA.
		Here in SB (which by the way is composed mostly of a severely
		wealthy Bev.Hills type aristocracy in remote competition
		with a very naive island of new wave "last grasp at the
		80's material dream" yuppie offspring college students) and
		especially in Los Angeles, there is a distinct flavor of
		escapism. In general the vibes I get are that people are more co                ncerned about the chemical support they desire and its pursuit
                rather than on just merging into the incredibly intense and 
		psycho-erotic media that the rave scene is all by itself, with
		out any chemical interference. Meth is big, and of course that
		in turn gives birth to a mood that is much more volatile
		and corrosive, and, by its very nature, quickly overshadows
		any of the positive vibes being released by nonusers and users 
		of mind-manifesting type compounds(aka. psychedelia).
		At this point, most of you who are already on this groove are
		probably just nodding and saying, yeah.... and? That's LA.
		We're San Francisco. And for the most part I agree with you,
		but not whole-heartedly.
		We're all well aware that it's long past due for the re-emerg-
		ence of the "underground" underground. It need not be reiterated                thatthe
		days of Disneyland type mega productions won't be numbered
		soon enough. And that the masses will either be swept away in 
		those capitalistic vortices forever or just get burnt out on
                their crystal and get tired of the whole scene, leaving the   
		rest of us to groove till we collapse in some stuffy basement.
                Enough said.
                Sfraves is a cool thing. And I commend Brian for making it all
		possible as well as everybody else with their brilliantly  
                colored re-creations of events that ooze with good vibes.
		But at the same time there seems to be another faction emerging
                (or maybe its always been there) that's beginning to be pretty
                negative and abrasive. These are all the whiners and ballistic 
		complainers. Okay so we all know how you feel about fog machines                and cops, and bad speakers, and meth users, and permits,  and
		all the other nuances that make the rave scene so precarious
		and unpredictable. Those things are all inherent in what's
		known as the underground. If everything was set and all promoters               s had a routine to go by every week then; for one it wouldn't
		be underground, and two it wouldn't be nearly as fun.
	        Now like I said before I ordinarily wouldn't even make a peep
		on this already slightly cluttered but potentially enlightening
		interface except when I feel that something worthwhile needs to                 be said. The only apparent reason for all the ranting seems
		to me that some of you guys are just plain burnt on the scene.
                If you attempt to squeeze more from the scene than is there then                the whole scene is phucked! That's escapism. And that's what's
		making LA such a negative place to be. 
		I don't necessarily want to bag on anybody. And I am well aware
	
	
	of the hippocrisy of writing a complaint about all the complainers.
		But I think it would be a good dose of reality if those of
		you who insist on injecting your negative two cents into 
		cyberspace everytime you see fit would just CHILL and sift
		the currents for a while and let those of us with positive
		things to say take the reigns for a while. If your so tired
		of the scene that all you can do to battle all the bumps
		and curves on the road to a good time is point the finger and
		offer no friendly assistance then maybe the rave scene isn't 
		really working for you the way you want it to. There's
		no way we can affect the entire rave nucleus on this little
		group we call sfraves. But the very least we can do is to
		keep it positive amongst ourselves. 
		Thanks to all of you for reading this and I do send everyone 
		up there the most positive vibes. Keep it real. =->.

Subject: Internet Census



Network Information Systems Center                             January 1993
SRI International                                    Internet Domain Survey

 The Domain Survey attempts to discover every host on the Internet by doing a
 complete search of the Domain Name System.  The latest results gathered
 during mid-January 1993 are listed.  For more information see RFC 1296; for
 detailed data see the pub/zone directory on ftp.nisc.sri.com.  This survey
 was done using the census program developed at the University of California
 on Santa Cruz; see technical report UCSC-CRL-92-34 on host ftp.cse.ucsc.edu.
 The statistics below were generated by running the collected host data
 through a number of utility programs.
                                                          -- Mark Lottor


         January 1993      Oct 92   Jul 92   Apr 92   Jan 92   Change (Jan-Jan)
 ==============================================================================
 Hosts:     1,313,000   1,136,000  992,000  890,000  727,000    80.6%
 Domains:      21,000      18,100   16,300   20,000   17,000    23.5%


                  Number of Networks (based on DNS IP addresses)

         January 1993      Oct 92   Jul 92   Apr 92   Jan 92   Change (Jul-Jan)
 ==============================================================================
 Class A:          54          52       60                      -9.0%
 Class B:        3206        2985     2714                      18.1%
 Class C:        4998        4468     3795                      31.7%
 Total:          8258        7505     6569                      25.7%
